author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: just gave birth is there posibility that i get pregnant?
content: Hello, Your doctor should have discussed this with you and made sure you had a plan for contraception.  You definitely can become pregnant soon after giving birth, especially if you are not exclusively breastfeeding your baby, which usually delays the return of ovulation.  I know it may be a shock at first but you will adjust in time and close spacing, while not ideal, can be just fine.  It is estimated that around 50% of all U.S. pregnancies are unplanned.  Yet, most women and infants do fine once they get used to the idea and get the help they need.  Consider a counselor or talk to your doctor or trusted family member, clergy, etc. about your fears.  If you are indeed pregnant (and positive pregnancy tests are usually accurate 4-5 weeks after the last period), be sure to take vitamins every day and get prenatal care by about 12 weeks.   At the next delivery, please breastfeed for the best outcome for both you and your baby and use condoms or other protection when you begin to have sex again.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Pregnancy without intercourse and on pill
content: Hello, I think you can rest easy that you are not pregnant.  The pill is a very effective method and used properly has only a 1% failure rate.  In addition, the likelihood of fertilization without intercourse is practically nonexistent.  The sperm needs a pretty friendly environment to travel up through the vagina and cervix.  Placement pretty much needs to be in that area for pregnancy to occur.    The combination of no intercourse and the pill makes this practically impossible.  Your period fluctuation is pretty surely caused by the pill and is nothing to worry about.  Things will probably level out a bit over the first few months of pill use and you will find out what is now your "normal" cycle soon.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Vanishing Twin Syndrome + High HCG
content: Hello, These are good questions.  First let me remind you that lab values are important but only part of the whole health/illness picture.  Each person has their own curve when it comes to HCG levels so while a pattern can help determine a viable pregnancy vs miscarriage, the values, especially in the case of vanishing twin or other complications can vary greatly.  Other lab values vary with the particular lab and their controls so it requires a doctor to explain them, in light of the lab particulars.   The values are really only useful as part of the physical exam and other findings from history, symptoms, etc.  It is misleading to try to interpret these alone and if labs told the whole story, technicians could do most of our health care.  Draw blood, get results and recommend action if needed.    Some experts believe that vanishing twin syndrome may occur in as many as 1/3 of all multiple gestations, often occurring before the woman is aware there were multiple fetuses.  In days past, most women did not receive pregnancy confirmation until they had missed a second period.  By then, this may have already occurred while she was unaware.    If it happens in the first trimester there is rarely any problem with the remaining fetus and the additional, non-viable one is reabsorbed into the placenta.   Later in the pregnancy there is a chance it could cause problems and sometimes the twin is removed surgically, though this is not without risks to the surviving twin.  Without intervention it would be impossible to predict your odds of carrying to term.  Minor bleeding happens in healthy pregnancies as well as impending miscarriage.  Only time will tell and unfortunately, there is little to be done to intervene if loss is inevitable.  Just do what you can to be healthy, eat good foods, take a daily vitamin, get exercise but not too strenuous, avoid bad habits such as smoking, drinking, drugs and use your seatbelt.  These are things you CAN do to make a difference.  Try not to dwell on the things you can't change.  High stress hormones are not so good on you or your pregnancy.  Best wishes

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: toxoplasma high avidity is it safe to get pregnant?
content: Hello, Because these antibody tests can be difficult to interpret, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that all positive results be confirmed by a laboratory that specializes in diagnosing toxoplasmosis.  I assume this was the case but you also need someone skilled at interpreting these hard to understand results.  Positive testing can merely show there has been infection in the past and immunity is now present; not just that there is current infection with this parasite.  High avidity actually means immunity to the disease so that in itself would not be cause to delay pregnancy.  It is helpful in confirming the diagnosis and to know that treatment was appropriate.  But, as for residual risk for pregnancy, you would need to consult with her infectious disease doctor to examine the lab results.  From what I see, it just states recent infection and I don't know of any particular recommendation for spacing between infection and conception.   I'm sorry I'm not able to fully answer your question but it would be worthwhile to discuss it in detail with her doctor.   Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Use of low-dose Topamax (migraine preventive) and Pregnancy
content: Hello, Risk of problems in pregnancy due to Topamax use is theoretical and there are no red flags, according to teratology resources I contacted about it.    You are correct that this is a low dose which would further reduce any possible risk and the benefits to you will surely outweigh, since they are known, while risks from this medication are not apparent.  Studies are not done on pregnant or breastfeeding women but this information about birth defects and pregnancy history is collected after pregnant women have used a medication, either because they needed it or did not know they were pregnant.  So, while these are not studies that would permit the drug manufacturer to state in labeling that it is safe in pregnancy you should be just fine to continue to use it, thereby reducing the risk of your illness which ultimately could be harmful to the baby.  You would also be fine to take the medication while lactating which has huge benefits for both mother and baby.    I agree with the folic acid supplementation.  Best wishes

title: finding out pregnancy a week after arthroscopy? damages!
content: Hello, This happens quite frequently and while we try to avoid such things when we are aware of pregnancy, we aren't perfect on this and sometimes pregnancy cannot be detected prior to a procedure. But, because it does happen quite often, we are able to feel quite confident that there would not be any serious results for the baby.  Keep in mind that there is about a 3% risk of birth defects in ANY pregnancy - even under the best conditions, but I would not expect this one procedure to increase your risk beyond the normal.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: i have pcos can i get pregnant?
content: Hello, Yes, it is possible to conceive with PCOS - plenty of women do.  But, it can be more difficult, as you have learned.  You should be evaluated by a gynecologist to see if you might benefit from treatment with Glucophage or Metformin because PCOS is partially caused by insulin resistence.  Many doctors also prescribe an ovulation stimulation medication such as Clomid to aid in conception.  These medications must be taken as prescribed by your doctor.  The potential risk is for multiples (and that means a higher risk of miscarriage, preterm delivery and infant mortality).  But, when properly administered and monitored it often results in a successful pregnancy.  Best wishes and good luck in your efforts.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Human Growth Hormone and Pregnancy
content: Hello, Since we do not do scientific studies of medications on pregnant or lactating women, our information is limited.  It is considered to be one of those areas where risks and benefits must be weighed.  If the mother needs the medication for her health, the benefit may outweigh any potential risk.  These drugs have not been reported as definitely being teratogenic (causing birth defects) but we usually take the cautious approach and suggest only taking meds when truly needed during pregnancy.  Even less information is available about the father's involvement.  Since a blood supply is not connecting between the father and the baby, it is rare for a substance he has used to be a problem with the fetus.  There are drugs that can damage the sperm and/or make the man infertile.  I have seen no literature to this effect with HGH.  If you take this drug and anticipate or are already pregnant, be sure to discuss it with your doctor.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Sun Dec 28, 2008 1:26 pm

title: Painful bowel movements, swollen vagina
content: Hello, I would not expect any complications from your delivery at this point.  If you are constipated there are measures you can take that should help.  Take a fiber supplement daily (like Metamucil) and improve your diets with the addition of fruits, vegetables, whole grains and more water.  Exercise daily. Try to avoid offenders such as perfumed products (including tampons and pads, underwear, toilet tissue), too-tight pants, etc.   Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 30 weeks pregnant, hurts to stand or walk, pain in back?
content: Hello, First of all, sex will not harm the baby unless you are having some complications that have caused your doctor to prescribe pelvic rest.  Sometimes this is needed in cases such as placenta previa or incompetent cervix.  If you had these conditions your doctor would have told you.  Comfort is another matter and you need to experiment with positions.  Many couples find it works better to use a "rear entry" or sidelying position.  As for the pain, it is always best to check these things out. Many times pain is just the result of stretching ligaments, position of baby on nerves and spine, etc. but there are times when acute abdominal pain can be serious so you should see your doctor.  You should also be doing kick counts and if it seems your baby's movement has decreased a bit, this is another reason to have it checked out.  Either call your doctor or go straight to the labor and delivery area of your delivery hospital and let the nurses know what your concerns are.  They can evaluate you and determine if your baby is being stressed for some reason.    Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Antibiotics, the pill and pregnancy
content: Hello, The chances of pregnancy while taking the pill are about 1%.  In other words, of 100 women taking the pill as prescribed, one will become pregnant in the year.  So, while it is a reliable method, it is not perfect so pregnancy can and does occur while taking the pill.  Antibiotics have been shown to decrease the effectiveness a bit, but it has also appeared to be mostly with a rarely used antibiotic, Rifampin.  This did lead us to wonder if others might also decrease the contraceptive ability of the pill.  We don't know definitively, partly because some become pregnant anyway - even without antibiotics.  So, it would be difficult to determine without some more extensive study, if it was related to the antibiotic use or just the random 1% pregnancy.  If you have relationship issues and trust is a concern, I would recommend couples thereapy with a certified family counselor.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Dec 23, 2008 11:50 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Nystatin cream for itching during pregnacy
content: Hello, It is always possible that a sensitivity can be there, though this would not be a common thing.  If you no longer need the cream and after discontinuing its use he is still having this problem, chances are it is unrelated as an allergic reaction should not persist after the offending agent is removed and should gradually heal.  He could also take Benadryl or another antihistamine to see if that helps speed up the resolution of itching.  Beyond this, consider any other exposure such as soaps or personal hygiene products, laundry detergent, etc. and encourage him to wash after sex to see if that helps.  Best wishes.

title: Is a DNC after miscarriage necessary?
content: Hello, I can't say how this diagnosis came about with all pregnancy tests being negative.  It seems unlikely a D&C would be needed and in most cases of early miscarriage the body takes care of it without intervention.  Only when it is clear there was not complete evacuation of the contents of the uterus or infection or bleeding are concerns is it needed. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: position of cervix in pregnancy
content: Hello, After ovulation, the cervix drops lower in the vagina and feels firm, like the tip of your nose. During pregnancy, the cervix will rise a bit and become softer, but the timing of this happening will vary from woman to woman.   This is one reason it is not a reliable indicator of early pregnancy.

posted_time: Post  by Vanna0407 » Sun Dec 14, 2008 5:25 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Implantation 4 days past ovulation?
content: Hello, Four days would be very early and I doubt that is what is happening.  The main reason for the difference is because we don't know exactly when ovulation occurred typically.  It is a common misconception that every woman ovulates at day 14 of her cycle.  There is wide variation here and there is slight variation at the cellular level as well.  In some cases the fertilized ovum does not implant at all and an early miscarriage happens.  It's just normal variation of the miracle of conception, development, and childbearing.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Dec 16, 2008 8:03 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: last period very light 4 months after pregnancy
content: Hello, Have you discussed these things with your coworkers to see if anyone else has experienced similar symptoms?  That would help you determine if it was an environmental issue.  If so, you could ask your local health department to look into environmental concerns there.    The period is probably just normal fluctuation.  Most women report unusual periods at times and this is considered within the normal limits.  It could also vary if you use hormonal contraceptives or the Mirena IUD.  These often result in reduced flow after a period of adjustment.   As you said, vague and varied symptoms can be hard to pin down but a good overall physical exam with a family practice doctor could rule out some of the more typical concerns, anemia, thyroid dysfunction, etc.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: having something move in my stomach but blood test was neg
content: Hello, The GI system (stomach, bowels, intestines) do make movements that truly are similar to feelings of fetal movement.   When you are acutely aware that the possibility of pregnancy exists, you can be especially tuned into such feelings and it is confusing.  If pregnancy tests are negative and you haven't had other symptoms you can probably rest assured it is normal peristaltic movement as food, gas, etc. passes through the system.  Best wishes.

title: Profuse Sweating four months after giving birth
content: Hello, I too am puzzled since you have already seen specialists about this.  The good news is that if there were a serious problem, they likely would have picked up on it so it sounds like something hormonal to me.  Women's hormones can do weird things for sure.  Have you ever tried birth control pills to see if regulating these hormones helps at all?  I assume they have ruled out infections such as TB.    In the meantime I would keep a record of when these events occur and give as much detail as possible regarding your physical environment, food eaten and drunk, use of alcohol or drugs, emotional state, date and time.  This may help ultimately in finding the cause.  I might try an internal medicine doctor.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 21 weeks pregnant and have protein in urine
content: Hello, At this point the results are not significant but could be a warning of things to come.  I'm sure your doctor will want to continue to monitor you for other symptoms of gestational diabetes as you progress in your pregnancy.  This could be a risk factor for you but it typically shows up in the last trimester.  Your blood pressure will be monitored throughout your care.  It is important to stay well-hydrated as dehydration will also affect your urine testing, suggesting problems that may not be there in actuality.  Urine should be colorless or very pale yellow.  Anything darker indicates inadequate fluid intake.  There is no exact amount of water you should take in but monitoring urine color helps you to regulate it for yourself as an individual.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Mon Nov 17, 2008 2:12 pm

author: Echo4Friendly  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Nov 14, 2008 5:25 pm Gender: Female
title: Re: 21 weeks pregnant and have protein in urine
content: I am a mother of two with a Mirena IUC that was inserted in late 2006.  I have never had regular periods, but when I have had them they have normally been heavy and unpleasant, .  However, for the past few months I have had very light periods (if I have had them at all), and my grandmother continued to have periods during her pregnancies (weird but true; everyone's body is different).  I've been having a lot of the other symptoms that I had when I was pregnant before - the exhaustion, the moodiness, the bloating, the hard-to-pin-down feeling of pregnancy, and the migraines (which are the substitute for morning sickness in my family), not to mention increased heartburn (hiatal hernias also run in my family, so heartburn is run-of-the-mill, but not this bad).  I have back problems from a herniated and ruptured L5 disk in my back that was repaired surgically in 2005; however, what is normally a niggling pain has gotten nearly unbearable for abnormal amounts of time (I have occasional episodes, but they have grown more frequent recently).  For the past few weeks I've been feeling movement that has been growing stronger and stronger; and my belly has been growing slightly over the past few weeks (my clothes are starting to get tighter); however, I have taken several pregnancy tests over the past few months that have all come out negative.  It has been a few weeks since I took one.  The thing is that I have no idea how far along I would be, since I've never been regular with my periods.  I also know that Mirena slightly raises the possibility of ectopic pregnancy, which would explain false negatives on tests - however, I haven't experienced any of the other symptoms of ectopic pregnancy (such as pain in the shoulder).  I know it is a very effective method of birth control and that it is highly unlikely that I am pregnant; however, I am going with what I know.  I also have ovarian cysts that are likely a result of the IUC, and I know that a pulsating sensation in the abdomen can be a symptom of those getting out of hand, but I don't know that they would explain the other symptoms.  I have no medical insurance and cannot just go get an ultrasound (I am a working mother of two in the middle of a custody battle for one).  I have been ignoring this for a long time and have not yet mentioned it to my live-in boyfriend because I am worried that I'm just losing my mind and that he'll think that I've gotten paranoid; however, if I am pregnant and I have gotten far enough along to feel movement (I felt it around fifteen weeks with my second child) and to have started to show a little (I'm able to suck it in some, but it's getting hard) then I'm risking both my health (with my various problems) and my child's to sit around and wait.  (Not to mention that I have no idea what the IUC would do to a pregnancy that actually commenced despite its presence.)  I am really stumped, and I'm afraid to bring it up to anyone I know.  Please, someone say something, because I'm terrified.
posted_time: Post  by Echo4Friendly » Fri Nov 14, 2008 5:48 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Potentially pregnant with IUC
content: Hello, You are right that this is a very effective method of birth control, but no method is 100% except abstinence so of course there is always the possibility and whenever you have symptoms of pregnancy you should be tested.  A blood test can be more accurate, earlier, than the urine test so if you are doubtful, get that done.  Some clinics or hospitals may even offer free pregnancy testing.  You could inquire with your local health department about such services.  One thing about having borne a child in the past is that it makes you very conscious of subtle abdominal feelings and changes.  Even women who are post-menopausal sometimes feel sensations that feel exactly like the movement of the baby they felt when they were younger and pregnant.  This is also the reason women sometimes question if they are feeling movement early in pregnancy the first time - it isn't an obvious "kick" and they have felt such sensations previously.  The bowel and stomach with it's movements and gases that go with the digestive process can very much mimic fetal movement.  If a woman becomes pregnant with the Mirena still intact, it can sometimes be removed.  The process may result in a miscarriage, but if not, there is also the chance it will be delivered with the baby.    The fact that you still have some periods leads me to think probably not pregnancy.  Most women report lighter periods after the first six months or so of the IUD placement.  Again, take the test if in doubt because there is a failure rate of about 1%.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Ate swordfish for 4 times in the month of conception
content: Hello, I would not be overly concerned about this.  The amount of exposure over time is the more significant factor - as in throughout the pregnancy.  While swordfish is one of the larger fish with more likelihood than some others to contain mercury it is possible your wife did not consume contaminated fish.  What's more, recently it has been discovered that there appears to be a protective factor in the healthy omega 3 fatty acids found in fish that probably discounts the mercury concerns.  At least it appears that the benefits outweigh the risks, based on studies in countries where fish is a mainstay of the diet and women consume large amounts of the potentially contaminated fish.  More is sure to come from these studies in the future so, in the meantime, it is good for pregnant women  to avoid these types of fish and opt for less contaminated types just to be on the safe side.  The main thing here is, avoid the swordfish, tilefish, shark and king mackerel in the future but do take omega 3 rich fish that are lower in mercury contamination because of the health benefits.  Fish oil capsules can also be used.  I know of no test to determine this now but the main concern is cumulative so avoiding additional exposure to mercury is the best course of action now.    Not all possible effects of prenatal mercury exposure is even known.  It is believed that it would require substantially high levels to actually cause deficits in IQ - higher than what most women might consume.  Try to just enjoy the journey and your baby.  Best wishes.

content: Hello, Because of the wide fluctuation of hormones associated with pregnancy (before and after), these symptoms could be present in either case - miscarriage or pregnancy. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 27 Weeks Pregnant/Have Not Seen A Doctor!?
content: Hello, Perhaps your midwife was a direct entry or "lay" midwife as opposed to a certified nurse midwife.  The latter is always affiliated with a doctor to deliver when the pregnancy has complications or requires a c-section.  You didn't say why she won't be able to deliver your child.  Have you developed serious complications?  You should be able to get in to see a doctor even at this late date.  You may need to call a few but let them know your prenatal care provider is no longer willing/able to care for you in your pregnancy.    Often women move to a new location prior to delivering their babies and they are able to get in for care even in the last trimester.  Call your local hospital or if you have insurance you could find a provider listing and inquire about someone who would be available for your care.    If after explaining your situation the office refuses to schedule you for an appointment, call your local hospital labor and delivery unit and explain your dilemma to the nurses who can probably refer you to a provider.   If you happen to go into labor without a doctor caring for you, go to the hospital where your insurance covers (if you have insurance) or to any  facility.  They will find a doctor to care for you in the hospital.  It would be much better if you can arrange this in advance but in the worst case scenario of a surprise, early labor, this would be a possibility.  If you have a teaching hospital associated with a university, this can be a good place to start.    Best of luck to you.  Let us know if you have other questions.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Unicorn Uterus
content: Hello, Since you have conceived previously there is a good chance you can again though many women do experience infertility.  With this condition your risk of fetal loss is fairly high and your pregnancy would be classified as high risk.  You should see a specialist who would follow you closely and monitor any signs that your baby was in distress.  By knowing what you are dealing with there is a better chance of early detection of concerns.  There is a certain degree of risk involved but if you are wanting to bear a child it may be worth the effort and the potential problems.    I am not aware of any procedure to correct the condition.    Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Tubes tied almost 6yrs ago. Could I be pregnant?
content: Hello, I cannot say why you are having pain but it is unlikely you are pregnant.  Most women who get pregnant following tubal ligation do so within the first year or so of the procedure.  After a time, things have usually healed over to the point that it is not possible.    You should see your doctor if the pain continues as the abdomen contains many organs which can have problems - bowel, urinary, gall bladder, digestive systems just to name a few.  Ongoing pain of this type should be checked out but would be a very unusual early symptom of pregnancy.  Best wishes

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Pregnancy and Birth control
content: Hello, I assume you mean the birth control pill, or oral contraceptive.  With perfect use, it is estimated that your risk of pregnancy is less than 1% but there is no method that is 100% reliable except abstinence so it is possible, though unlikely.  You can take a home pregnancy test to be sure.  Use of the pill does not affect the results of the test.  Missed periods without pregnancy are not uncommon.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: After effects of Miscarriage
content: Hello, I would not be worried about this and suspect things will go back to normal soon.  Sometimes a light colored stool can be associated with gall bladder disease so if it continues, you should have it checked. Only rarely is stool color variations a serious concern in the absence of other symptoms.  Black, tarry stools can mean internal bleeding such ulcers and light stools can be associated with malabsorption.  This is not common and unrelated to the miscarriage.   Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Short Cervix, 1.6 cm at 7.5 weeks?
content: Hello, Cervical incompetency usually does not cause a problem for the pregnancy until the baby is larger - second to third trimester.  At that point the pressure of the baby can cause the cervix to fail.  Miscarriages that occur early as yours have are not usually caused by this problem.  The cerclage is placed somewhere around 12 - 14 weeks so waiting for your appointment is fine.  Even then it is likely too early to place it.  If a miscarriage occurs before then, a cerclage would not have helped anyway.    When the baby and placenta don't develop as they should, miscarriage is inevitable and nothing you can do will change what must happen.  In some cases early loss can be the result of a clotting disorder in the mother and may be helped in a future pregnancy but this is a rare situation.  Some women seem to not have enough progesterone in early pregnancy and doctors sometimes prescribe this.    Discuss all your concerns with your doctor at your visit.  Start writing notes so you won't forget your questions.  Good luck to you.

title: 36 weeks 4 days pregnant, small fundal height....
content: Hello, Fundal height alone can be deceiving.  Often this is watched for a few weeks and if still no change the doctor may order an extra ultrasound for evaluation of fluid volume, growth, etc.  It can show everything to be fine or it could be a sign of a small for gestational age baby and it's good to follow up to see if there is a problem.  Ask your doctor what she plans to do to follow up on this concern.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Cramps and bleeding in early preg
content: Hello, All you can do is wait and see.  If the baby is developing properly you could go on to have a normal pregnancy.  If it is not, nothing you can do will stop a miscarriage from happening.  So, take it easy, just to give your body every chance.  It could go either way.  Try not to stress about it because that alters hormones and we don't know how this will affect pregnancy.   Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: are partial birth abortions really done?
content: Hello, Yes it is done.  In the U.S. a law was passed and signed by President Bush outlawing this method, but it may still be performed illegally.  The purpose is to make sure the baby is not born alive, since these are done late enough in pregnancy it is possible the baby might survive.  It is gruesome for sure.  It is a highly controversial subject since abortions performed late in pregnancy are much more complicated.  I hope this helps.

author: Dr Omna Chawla  Medical Doctor Posts: 2 Joined: Tue Oct 28, 2008 7:03 am Gender: Female
title: oxycodone and a 4 week fetus?
content: Dear Sophia Oxycodone Tablets are indicated for the management of moderate to severe pain when a continuous, around-the-clock analgesic is needed for an extended period of time.Animal studies of the drug have shown fetal harm at a dosage much higher(almost 40 to 50 times) taken by you .So in my opinion this drug should be used during pregnancy only if clearly needed. But there is no need of unnecessary worry till you see your doctor; you can manage your pain with paracetamol 500mg tablet as and when required as this is considered to be the safest take care

author: Shelly Hoppe EMTP  Paramedic Posts: 11 Joined: Tue Oct 28, 2008 10:11 pm Gender: Female
title: sppoting 6 weeks pregnant
content: Greetings Silvia,  A small amount of spotting can be normal in some women during pregnancy or it can be a sign of pending miscarriage.  If the amount increases or you start passing clots, bright red blood or start to get menstral like cramps contact your OB/GYN doctor.  She can run a simple blood test to see if your Beta HCG levels are rising or falling.  They will continue to rise if you have a viable pregnancy and they will fall if you are having a miscarriage.  Good luck Silvia my thoughts and prayers will be with you.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: pregency sugar
content: Hello, Glucose is monitored in pregnancy and sometimes a woman develops gestational diabetes.  The levels are then checked regularly and managed with diet in most cases.  Sometimes insulin is necessary.  This usually comes on toward the end of the pregnancy.  You should be screened for this around 27 weeks and your doctor can advise you if intervention is needed.  If so, you may be referred to a dietician for help in planning your diet.  If insulin is required, the doctor will prescribe the type and amount.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Use of Silymarin during pregnancy
content: Hello, It is very difficult to advise you about herbal supplements  because we just don't know much about them.  They are not regulated or even tested under the same standards as other drugs and even if they were, testing is not done on pregnant women.  Because of this there are very few drugs we can really say are "safe" in pregnancy so the best advice is to avoid anything that is not essential for the mother's health (risks/benefits).  The chances of transmission of this infection to the baby is only about 5% and it appears to be somewhat controversial whether C-section would be preferable.  I don't think this will improve the odds and surgery itself carries additional risks so unneeded surgical intervention is not usually advised, (though across the board it is being done too often).   This is a decision that must be made in conjunction with your wife's health care provider who should explain all risks and benefits of each method of delivery so she can make an informed decision.  If he/she cannot give good reason that a cesarean is necessary, I would prefer the vaginal delivery.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Mon Oct 27, 2008 12:12 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Sex is Painful During Pregnancy?
content: Hello, Each person is individual in their response to sexual encounters, especially during pregnancy. Hormones can cause a decreased desire but there can also be emotional issues at play here.  Some people unconsciously worry that the baby could be harmed.  Especially after you have had a hemorrhage, you may be very sensitive to this possibility.    I would suggest you continue to work on your relationship, being kind and loving to one another in hopes you will recapture some of the passion you had before.  Many couples never experienced the kind of pleasure in sex they would like, and they feel others are having.  The most important thing is to not neglect one another.  After the baby arrives, this will be especially difficult with the demands on your time and the lack of rest you will get.  All the more reason you should take advantage of your time together now but don't focus on the pleasure you are receiving, but rather, on giving a gift of love to your husband with this form of expression.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Sat Oct 18, 2008 9:30 pm

title: infection around 20mth old c section wound
content: Hello, I do know of someone who had such a reaction and it turned out she was allergic to the suture material used and the response to it led to some ongoing problems.  I really don't know the details or what can be done in this case.  I can't say this is your situation of course but aside from something like that, I could only suggest possibly adhesions.  These are scar tissue bands that form in some people following surgery and they can be quite painful as they attach to organs.  I would continue with your doctor to find a cause for your discomfort.  Pain is not normal and your body is trying to tell you something.  Best wishes

title: itching and discharge after birth, occurs after period
content: Hello, Not everyone has every symptom of any condition or infection.  Don't worry about the lack of cheesy discharge. title: 15 weeks pregnant, bleeding gums, vomiting...
content: Hello, It is possible that hormones are causing the bleeding gums but also gingivitis can get worse and progress to a more serious infection so you should see your dentist when you are pregnant for cleaning and exam, fillings if you have cavities. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Stillbirth, Clomid, Hypertension, Progestrogene
content: Hello, I'm so sorry about your stillborn daughter.  I too experienced a full-term stillbirth and the cause was never determined.  In the majority of cases it is this way.  The medical community is still quite baffled about this particular tragedy in reproduction.  It is very important that you have a good and trusting relationship with your doctor so you should seek a new provider.  High blood pressure is nothing to ignore and if you need treatment it is important that you get this under control before pregnancy if possible.  If you have excess weight to lose, this would also be advised.    The home pregnancy tests are quite reliable by the time you miss a period.  First Response has an excellent reputation for accuracy but others are good as well.  Sometimes the hormone levels are not quite high enough to detect on any test so you should repeat it a week later if you still haven't had a period.  The blood test done in the doctor's office can detect pregnancy a little earlier because it is more sensitive to the hormones.  But, patience is a virtue and in time the pregnancy will be clear.  Good luck to you
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Mon Oct 06, 2008 6:15 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Pre marriage tests to avoid genetic problems
content: Hello, So this is a first cousin.  Some states have laws banning marriage to a first cousin for the reason you have expressed concern about.  You should consult with a geneticist.  There are usually some affiliated with University hospitals.  They will know what to look for but even then there are no guarantees.  We just don't know everything.  However, their advice would be very helpful for you in planning your future.  Keep in mind that marrying your cousin is not nearly the risk that marrying your sibling would be.  The genetic similarities are not that similar typically.  To pass on a genetic defect that would preclude such a marriage, you would both have to have the genetic defect gene so simply reproducing with a cousin does not mean you will have defective children but science and tradition has put social bans on this that make you worry.  So, for your peace of mind, seeing a genetic counselor might be helpful.    Good luck.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Sep 30, 2008 7:51 pm

title: Pregnancy and fiorinol
content: Hello, It is not known if there is a problem with this medication in pregnancy because there has not been enough testing to verify it one way or another. You should always discuss any medication use with your doctor.  Usually it is a balancing act between benefits to the mother and possible risks to the baby.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Spotting during pregnancy 4th pregnancy no kids
content: Hello, The risk of miscarriage drops off around the 13th week but loss can occur at any time in the pregnancy for various reasons.  Spotting alone is usually not a cause for concern since many pregnant women experience this while going on to deliver healthy babies.  If you develop cramping and real bleeding, that is another story.  The rate of miscarriage is greater than 20% so it is quite common.  All you can do is wait and watch.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Can I get pregnant with  3 cysts in my ovaries
content: Hello, Many women have polycystic ovary syndrome and sometimes have trouble conceiving.  Other women who have cysts become pregnant and my never even know they have the cysts.  They may interfere with ovulation but not necessarily.  If you have difficulty getting pregnant, your doctor may elect to give you medication to help this.  Plan a preconception visit to discuss your concerns.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: what are the chances to be pregnant after tube tide
content: Hello, I'd say the chances of pregnancy are quite slim but since I don't know what procedure was used when you had your surgery I can't say for sure.  Most of the time the ends are cut and closed off with a piece removed to further assure the ends will not grow back together.  If there is failure it is typically in the first year or so following the procedure but there are exceptions of course.    Chances are you are just experiencing some hormonal fluctuation, missed ovulation or other normal activity.  If the periods don't resume next month or you have symptoms you could get a pregnancy test and/or see your doctor.  Best wishes

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Tubes tied/Pregnant?
content: Hello, After five years it is unlikely you are pregnant after having your tubes tied.  Most often failures become evident in the year or so following the procedure.  Not knowing what technique your doctor used I can't say for sure but in most cases they remove a bit of tube and seal the ends making it highly unlikely the ends can grow back together.    The abdomen contains so many organs that symptoms can sometimes be similar to pregnancy.  The bowel and bladder are two organs that can be suspect for infections.  Of course you still have functioning ovaries which can also have problems and some women develop endometriosis which can cause abdominal pain.  These are just a few possibilities.  I'm glad you are having this checked out with your doctor for your own peace of mind.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Sep 30, 2008 6:04 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Could I be pregnant or had a miscarriage?
content: Hello Jessica76976,  This soon after your last period it would be unusual to see any signs of a miscarriage.  However, you may be experiencing some bleeding that can occur with pregnancy called implantation bleeding.  Typically, ovulation will occur around 14 days after the start of the last period.  Sperm cells can live around a week in the vaginal tract.  Given your exposure time course, you would most likely have been in the fertile time of your cycle.  This is not a 100% guarantee that your symptoms are due to pregnancy.  Many things can affect bleeding, including various stresses.  Many home pregancy tests are accurate a day or two before the expected day of your next period.  They are most accurate in the 5th week after the start of the last period.  If you take one before then that is negative and your period does not start as expected I would suggest that you repeat the pregnancy test a week later.    Regarding the diet pill, it is hard to say for sure but in general I would recommend against taking any more until you know whether or not you are pregnant.  Many drugs can have some effects on the growing baby, especially early on in the pregnancy.  Diet supplements often contain herbal supplements that have not been tested for safety during pregnancy.  Many supplements claim to be 100% safe and without side-effects since they are "natural".  Unfortunately, this is far from the truth.  If your symptoms continue and you're concerned I would recommend you see your gynecologist.    Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Tue Sep 30, 2008 3:01 pm

title: Genes & Gender!!
content: Hello, Of course genes are involved in everything about the human body.  In addition there are issues such as body pH which can affect the survival of a specific gender at the time of fertilization and conception.  Girls also tend to be a bit stronger than boys when it comes to survival.  There definitely could be genetic factors at play here but these kinds of tendencies tend to have occasional exceptions so anything is possible.    I hope this helps a little.  Life still holds lots of mysteries.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: i'm i pregnant or it it menopause
content: Hello, Of course there is the chance of pregnancy if you are sexually active, but you could also be in the years of perimenopause when your periods begin to vary in length, spacing, characteristics, etc.  You could be ovulating inconsistently so pregnancy is still a possibility even when periods have slowed and even disappeared for a while.  Not everyone experiencing menopause has unpleasant side effects such as hot flashes so this is not a good indicator.  Even hormone tests are not very reliable here, though they can sometimes give clues that support the onset of menopause.  You should continue to use birth control until you are well into menopause, defined as a full year of absent periods, with or without other symptoms.    The perimenopause period can last for several years.  It's very inconvenient because you never know when you might expect a period so be prepared at all times.  Meanwhile, repeat pregnancy tests weekly until you are quite sure you are not pregnant.  The two conditions can definitely mimic each other.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Sep 30, 2008 11:51 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Unexpected Pregnancy - Problems
content: Hello, This is an extensive list of exposures during early pregnancy.  In most cases we do not know what causes birth defects and only when we see a higher than usual rate of defects in patients who have been exposed to a particular drug do we know if it will have an effect or not.  Some factors to consider include the amount of exposure.  A one time use, or limited use is less likely to be a problem.    We do not know what effect binge drinking of alcohol will have on a baby.  Recommendation is to avoid it altogether to be on the safe side but at this point it's best just to avoid any future binges since there's nothing you can do to change the past but hope for the best.  Supplements are not tested at all so we know very little about the effects of these; other drugs approved by the FDA are not tested on pregnant women so our only information is anecdotal (gathering data after a number of women have had exposure either because they did not know they were pregnant when taking it or because the benefit outweighed the risks).  Topical medications are rarely a problem and would most likely require massive amounts of exposure to get into the baby's blood stream so they are probably not a concern.   Eye drops are not a problem.    There is no way to guarantee a perfect baby.  The best thing you can do is take care of yourself now and avoid such exposures in the future. Eat a balanced, healthy diet, get regular exercise, avoid secondhand smoke and see your doctor for prenatal care.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Sep 16, 2008 4:42 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Missed 4 days of birth control, what is chance of pregnancy?
content: Hello I apologize for not seeing your continued posting  For the sake of other readers, you are correct that continuing to take birth control pills when waiting to find out if you are pregnant has not been associated with any birth defects or other problems in pregnancy, though they should be discontinued once it is confirmed.  You can also have a serum (blood) pregnancy test earlier than the urine test since it is more sensitive.  Generally the first clue about pregnancy occurs with the missed period.    If I understand you correctly, you had a longer period of time between packets of pills.  The delay in starting the new pack should not have been significant in the effectiveness.     Best wishes.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Pregnant - ate salad with blue cheese
content: Hello -  I don't think you need to be actively worried about listeria unless you actually develop symptoms, which probably would have happened by now anyway. The immune system tends to attack the responsible microbe very aggressively as a rule, and you only ingested a tiny amount of potentially contaminated bleu cheese crumbs. While it is definitely wise to avoid the  soft cheeses (as well as hotdogs, undercooked meats, etc.), especially when pregnant, I think it would be an extremely big coincidence if you did contract listeria from this very limited contact with the food in question.  Hope this helps, and I hope you have a safe and uneventful pregnancy. Congratulations!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Thick Period
content: Hello, You may be experiencing peri-menopause - a condition sometimes lasting several years prior to actual cessation of menstruation.  Hormones change during this time and this can cause a change in your periods.  It is not alarming but discuss the situation with your doctor when you go in for your annual exam and pap smear.    Best wishes

title: Possible Pregnancy or other problems?
content: Hello, It is possible you could be pregnant even with a negative test so if your symptoms continue you should repeat the test weekly until your period starts or you are satisfied you are not pregnant.  It can also be normal hormonal fluctuation.  While infection is always possible, bleeding alone would not make me think that direction.  You may want to be tested for sexually transmitted infections for your own peace of mind, however.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Period/ pregnancy
content: Hello, The morning after pill or plan B is a powerful hormone and it will disrupt your cycle.  It can take a few months to get back to normal following this treatment so it is difficult to tell what is going on now.  Even the mood swings can be related.  You should do pregnancy tests weekly as long as you are worried about pregnancy or see a doctor for a serum pregnancy test which can detect pregnancy at an earlier stage than the urine tests.  If negative, you may just have to wait a while for your body to adjust.  Meanwhile, I would suggest a different brand of condom or a second method of birth control - perhaps an IUD, the patch or pills.  Best wishes, Debbie

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: bcp bleeding
content: Hello Lily girl,  Pregnancy, while not 100% out of the question, is very unlikely.  Oral contraceptives (OCP's) by themselves are in the range of 97-99% effective when taken as directed.  Add to this the effectiveness of condoms and the chances of pregnancy are very, very slim.    Even with OCP's it is possible to get some break through bleeding/spotting (especially in the middle/last part of the cycle).  Stress can very much affect this so it is quite possible that the start up of classes is affecting your cycle.  If, however, your period does not occur as expected when taking the sugar pill week of your OCP's, I would recommend a pregnancy test just to be sure.  (Again, its very unlikely.)  Best wishes and study hard!
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Wed Aug 27, 2008 11:13 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: bcp bleeding
content: This depends on how much bleeding you're having and where in your cycle you are.  Often, if there is just some spotting, the woman will still have a regular period.  If the bleeding is heavier and near when the next period is expected, that period may be delayed or skipped.  All of this would still be considered a normal occasional variation of oral contraceptives.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: missed period 5 days late
content: Hi Kze100,  There are a few medicines that can induce menses.  Typically, these are progesterone based.  The normal menstrual cycle involves three phases.  1st, estrogen induces a thickening of the endometrial lining during the first part of the cycle (immediately after the last bleeding stops).  2nd, progesterone induces a maturing of the lining (to be able to support pregnancy).  Then, if a pregnancy has not occurred, the 3rd stage occurs when the progesterone levels fall.  This withdrawal of progesterone induces shedding of the lining of the uterus and, as a result, menstrual bleeding.  There are several reasons for a woman to have a delayed period.  1st, if pregnancy is a possibility this should be evaluated.  It is also very normal for women to occasionally have an irregular period.  This can be contributed to by stress, exercise, or any number of things.  I would recommend waiting a bit longer before considering trying a medication to induce bleeding.  I would recommend you avoid herbal remedies such as Humphries #11.  The reason for this is because there is often not very good information about herbal medications and their effects.  They can have effects that we are not expecting.  In addition, herbal supplements are not regulated like medications are so there is no guarantee that what is supposed to be in the supplement actually is.  There are many reports of harmful substances being found in supposedly safe supplements.  (OK, I'll get off my soap box now.)  If your period does not start soon and you are concerned about it, it is very reasonable to see your gynecologist for an evaluation and possibly a medication to induce menses.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Worried about strange Braxton Hicks contractions..
content: Hello Sweetheart5015,  This is a bit outside my expertise but I wanted to reply to your question.  Your obstetrician's theory is very plausible.  The uterus receives a dramatic percentage of the body's blood flow that can suddenly be diverted to other places when the uterus contracts.  It may help to be sure you are very well hydrated to help minimize effects of blood flow changes.    If these get worse, it may also be reasonable to discuss with your OB about the possibility of a heart rhythm problem although this seems to be pretty unlikely overall.  I wish I could give you more information but I'm not familiar enough with this type of an issue to confidently answer. Follow up with your OB is important.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: irregualr periods..hard to get pregnant?!
content: Hello, In a woman of child-bearing years who is having regular sexual intercourse with a fertile male, it is considered normal for it to take a year to get pregnant.  So, at six months, while you may be anxious, it is not cause for alarm or intervention.    The best thing you can do is make sure you are both eating a healthy diet and taking care of your health in all ways.  Have sex every other day during the two weeks or so during which you are likely to ovulate.  Your partner should avoid tight shorts, hot tubs and anything that might damage his testicles.  The rest is up to the stars being in alignment, the higher power, God, or whatever you believe makes the world go around.  Good luck with this and try to be patient, decrease your stress worrying about it and it will most likely occur when you least expect it.  If not, after a year, you may want to consult with your doctor to see if a cause can be found.  In some cases however, a cause is just never known and it just takes a while.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Caesarian Section v.s. Vaginal Birth
content: Hello, You might enjoy seeing "The Business of Being Born" where Ricki Lake documents her second pregnancy which she determined should be more natural.  She opted for a home birth with a nurse midwife.  While I like the safety net of a hospital for delivery, there is a certain amount of risk that goes into this.  Technology sometimes gets out of hand and interferes with a natural process, such as delivering a baby.  A hospital is great when you are sick or in trouble but for normal life events such as giving birth, we sometimes treat normal mothers and babies as though they are ill.  There is a lot of liability-driven medicine being practiced.  There is a reason this is the case.  Many doctors encourage unnecessary cesarean births because they believe they will be better able to control the outcome, though major surgery such as this has many complications.  It is also more convenient - the doctor can schedule it, people love feeling like they are in charge, rather than at the mercy of their baby.  This is not the way to go, however.  It also brings in more money for the doctor and the hospital.  So, there may be a conflict of interest going on.    I would never advise a first time mother to choose a cesarean electively without some pretty compelling medical reason.  In most cases I would not advise a mother who had one c/section before to repeat it unless it was done under just certain circumstances; not just because the first was a cesarean.    The most important reasons to allow birth to be as natural as possible are fewer complications, infections, faster recovery, better success at breastfeeding, and future childbearing plans will not be adversely affected.  The more cesareans you have, the greater the risk so if you want to have several children, please don't choose a c/section for "convenience."  I have seen cases of post surgery infections, blood clots, and wounds dehissance (opening up).  This is not a pretty picture.  The surgical delivery is an important option for a mother who truly needs it, but too often this is not the case so each birth needs to be carefully evaluated individually and I would choose a midwife or doctor who does everything possible to ensure a vaginal delivery whenever it is safe.  You can get information from labor and delivery nurses who work with these doctors and midwives daily to help you find a provider that meets your expectations.  Of course you need to work within the framework of your insurance but you should be able to find a provider that will advocate for non-surgical birth whenever feasable.    There are various methods of prepared, non-medicated childbirth such as Lamaze, Bradley, hypnobirthing, etc. and they all work on the principle that knowledge is power and they teach relaxation, visual imagery and other skills to help.  You are wise to plan ahead.  Best wishes to you.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Thu Jul 10, 2008 5:31 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Alternatives to epidural?
content: Hello, Any drug used in your delivery has the potential for problems to either you or the baby.  The epidural is actually one of the safest forms of anesthesia for childbirth.  If you want to be completely safe from drug complications, consider an unmedicated birth.  Prepared childbirth can be very effective and rewarding but the key is "prepared."  You won't be successful if you just tell yourself you are going to do it.  But, if you take classes in a method such as Lamaze, Bradley or hypnobirthing, and practice faithfully, you can control your pain by understanding the process and working with your body to push the baby out - to allow nature to do its work.  You could benefit from a certified nurse midwife who is proficient in this type of delivery.  Choosing your health care provider is vital here.  A doctor who does not support this will not be a good choice.  It is work with your mind and the mind is capable of much more than we realize.  At least get hold of some books and read up on the subject.  There is also an interesting video called The Business of Being Born, created by Ricki Lake which shows what is possible.  She did a home birth and I am not advocating that - but the points it makes about getting back to the basics of giving birth naturally are quite remarkable.  In a hospital you have safety backups for problems, but most births are uncomplicated and the hospital environment itself can contribute to the problems.  Being educated on this and preparing yourself can allow you to be assertive to get the birth you want.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: medications while I was in 1st trimester.
content: Hello, Of course you are concerned but the ultrasound findings are definitely encouraging so try not to stress over this.  Even drugs which are known to increase the risk of birth defects do not do so in every case - just raises the odds a bit.  Many babies with exposure to known dangerous drugs are born healthy and normal.  Others are born with problems that have had no exposure to anything.  There is no guarantee and absolutely no way to definitely predict before the birth itself if there might be a problem.  When we have children there are a few risks we take and then we do the best with what we are given.  In the early weeks, typically you would see serious damage or even miscarriage as this is in the cell division stage - before the facial features.  So, if your baby had been seriously affected at this stage, most likely you would have lost the baby or it would be a significant problem that would be seen on ultrasound.  Best wishes for a healthy baby.

title: positive pregnancy test negative blood test why?
content: Hello, It is possible you were in the middle of a miscarriage.  By now I'm sure you have the outcome and I apologize we were not available to answer in a timely fashion.  We are volunteers here and sometimes it is difficult to get everyone's questions handled.  Other than that, I am not sure what blood test was actually performed so it is hard to explain what might have been happening.  Typically a serum (blood) pregnancy test is more reliable earlier than a urine test is so if that is the test you refer to, most likely it meant early miscarriage had occurred.    Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Fetal weight low.
content: Hello, I'm sorry I did not get to your question in a timely manner.  By now you have delivered and I hope you were able to do so vaginally.  Induction is a very popular option these days - it seems rare to actually go into labor spontaneously, even though the odds are better if you do.  There are complications with induction, most commonly that it ends in a Cesarean  delivery or the baby truly was not ready.  Labor also tends to be especially difficult with pitocin assistance.  Ultrasound exams for weight are not that accurate and there is a two pound variable to be considered.    If induction is done for a cause, it is ideal if it does not happen before week 39 and if the cervix is ready.  The fact that your gestational diabetes has been controlled with medication and diet improves your chances of having a baby of normal size.  Also, your body can accommodate varying sizes of babies and there is no magic number that can be determined in advance that would suggest you could not successfully deliver.  Staying with your prescribed glucose management program is your best assurance for a safe and healthy delivery.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Wed Jul 09, 2008 5:58 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 10wks pregant and had some discharge
content: Hello, I'm sorry we did not get to your question sooner. I'm sure you now know the outcome and I hope it was positive for you.    Discharge alone is really not a sure indicator of impending miscarriage.  I am confident it had nothing to do with the medications that you were prescribed either.  Most of the time it is a "wait and see" type thing.  There is little to be done if a miscarriage is about to occur.    If you did miscarry, you may wish to see a specialist for testing to see if you have a clotting disorder or to determine if you might be a candidate for some special intervention on your next attempt.  There are no guarantees, but repeated losses sometimes suggest a pattern that could benefit this way.  Good luck to you.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 35 weeks preg & low lying placenta.  Do I need C-section?
content: Hello, I'm sorry it took so long to get to your question.  A low-lying placenta may or may not result in a C section.  As your uterus continues to grow it can pull away from the cervix and cause no problem during delivery.  But if not and if you have bleeding, your doctor may recommend a c section.  If this happened to you, it does not necessarily mean you would need a C/S for future pregnancies so you should consider the possibility of a vaginal birth next time in any case.    I'm sure by now you have your result but in case others have similar questions I have answered here.  Best wishes.

title: Positive Pregnancy Test - Not Implantation Bleeding?
content: Hello, It's good you have a sense of humor.  I'm sorry it took us so long to answer your question.  But, there is no set number of days for implantation bleeding and some women feel that they have a nearly normal period with implantation so this alone would not make me decide where to put my money if I were betting on this.  By now I'm sure you have a result but barring additional testing and/or ultrasound determination, it would be impossible to say if you are pregnant or not.  Each woman responds to pregnancy differently and each pregnancy can be very different in the same woman.  Best wishes.

content: Thank you so much for your response.   I wanted to post a follow-up in case anyone is going through what we are going through. As it turned out, I experienced something called "chemical pregnancy." I am indeed pregnant, but due to lack of proper implantation of the fetus in the womb, the pregnancy goes away. Apparently, this is a very common phenomenon; most  people, except those who are actively trying to conceive, never notice they are pregnant, as it comes and goes so quickly. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: drying up milk
content: Hello, I totally understand why you would like to eliminate this problem which is related to prolactin levels in your body.  It is nothing to be alarmed about however, and you might try to relax and know that it is a good sign that your body will do well in breastfeeding when the time comes with another baby.  Many women leak from their breasts for several months in pregnancy too and it is harmless.  I would not encourage medication to treat this minor problem unless it is related to some other issue such as a pituitary tumor.  If it seems to become worse you may want to ask your doctor to evaluate your endocrine system.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: why Hcg is not showing up?
content: I have known of a number of women who have this same situation where they are pregnant, yet none of the tests are able to determine it for several weeks or months.  This is why no test is 100% accurate. There are always exceptions.  In the same way, some people cannot develop immunity to certain diseases such as rubella that most people do through vaccines.  I can't say exactly why this is the case; it is just one of life's variables.  You will probably have to rely on other ways to determine pregnancy.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Irregular spotting 3 months after miscarriage
content: Hello, It sounds like you are experiencing some hormonal fluctuation.  I would not be too alarmed by this.  With a negative pregnancy test it is unlikely you are experiencing implantation bleeding but you can always repeat the test a week or two later in case the hormone levels are not yet up to the level that would show up on the test.  Some spotting between periods is normal in almost all women and especially following hormonal changes such as you have had.  It is impossible to say if you are ovulating without monitoring your basal temperatures.  However, you may notice secretions that become heavier around the time of ovulation.  This can be a clue.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Why no pregnancy after miscarriage?
content: I can certainly understand your frustration.  It would seem likely that you would have conceived by now but there are many women who do not conceive in spite of the fact they have regular periods, regular sexual intercourse and use no birth control.  Sometimes it just takes a little while for everything to line up.  To improve your chances, I would suggest you have sex from day 8 through day 19 (start counting days on the first day of your period).  Daily is fine or every other day, but not less frequently than that.  You can also use ovulation indicators that use your body temperature as a guide.  Also, if you notice extra secretions, that is also a sign you may be fertile.  The trick is to present frequent opportunities for sperm to meet egg.  Good luck

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Why no pregnancy after miscarriage?
content: First please let me apologize for not answering your question before now.    It is possible you had an early miscarriage but it is also possible to have a period that consists of tissue as well as blood.  Once it happens it is nearly impossible to say for sure.  If there was a pregnancy but the baby just didn't develop, your body will take care of the remaining tissue which may have begun to prepare your body for a baby to grow.    You may become pregnant yet as most people who suffer a miscarriage do go on to conceive a baby that is healthy and strong.  But, if it doesn't happen soon and artificial reproductive technology (such as in vitro or artificial insemination) is a possibility for you, it might be time to consult with a fertility specialist about it.  At your age, there is still a good chance you could become pregnant spontaneously, assuming you don't have some underlying problem that is preventing ovulation.  Polycystic ovary syndrome sometimes does this and is often associated with adult acne.    Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: What are the chances of extended bedrest during pregnancy?
content: Hello, This is an interesting question because it is impossible to know if you could be one of the few women who might require bedrest in pregnancy. Fortunately the vast majority of women are able to work right up until they go into labor at the appropriate time.  You are wise to think about these things.  Some employers offer short-term disability that can help a woman in this situation.  There is also much controversy surrounding the order of bedrest.  In many situations where it has previously been prescribed it has mostly been discredited as something with little or no effect on the outcome of the pregnancy.  There are exceptions.  Times where bedrest is helpful is in the case of a uterine tear or placenta previa with bleeding, when the mother develops serious high blood pressure and sometimes when there is an incompetent cervix.  Other times (threatened miscarriage,  There is no data that bedrest can help in threatened miscarriage, and yet patients are told to go to bed rest with bathroom privileges when they have bleeding and cramping in the first trimester. It likely will not help but if the woman miscarries she feels that she did all she could to prevent it from happening so some providers feel there is psychological benefit.    This should be balanced with the harm that can be done with bedrest.  Women on bedrest face a host of physical problems caused by lack of activity, including muscle atrophy and blood clot risk as well as emotional issues related to boredom and isolation.  Then of course there is the financial disaster it sometimes causes - leading to further stress.  There is even some thought that the stress means increased cortisol levels which may adversely affect the baby or induce preterm labor.  If your job is not physically demanding, you are likely to do just as well going to work, except in those cases listed above.  Nobody can predict if you will develop high blood pressure, placenta previa or premature cervical changes that threaten a too-early birth.  There are risk factors that might mean you are at increased risk, but even then, there is no way to predict such a thing.  Mothers who are obese or who smoke carry a greater risk for hypertenstion.  If you were born prematurely, you have a greater risk of delivering a preterm infant.    In most cases bedrest involves a few weeks at most.  If it is in early pregnancy, you are likely to miscarry or find that everything is fine within a few days so even if you went to bed it would not be for a prolonged time.  If it is for hypertension, this would likely not occur until the last trimester and if it is severe it can be a few weeks.  If it gets dangerously high, the baby is delivered even if it is premature.  Placental bleeding can occur at any time.  If it is early, it will likely heal over and you can go back to normal activities.  If it is late, it could involve a few weeks until delivery.  Most women are probably on bedrest no more than two months.  A mother pregnant with multiples will also be at greater risk for bedrest to avoid preterm labor but many mothers deliver at term, working right up until their 36th or 37th week (or even beyond).  I know of women who had bedrest prescribed who explained their work situation to the doctor who then agreed they were probably at no greater risk by going to work.  There is nothing that can be done to prevent an early, first-trimester miscarriage so the negative effects of being on bedrest would likely outweigh any psychological benefit that may theoretically exist by going to bed.  If you understand that nothing you could have done differently would have changed the outcome, you emotional health should be fine.    Now, I'm not suggesting you throw caution to the wind and ride rollercoasters, go scuba diving or wakeboarding.  There are risky behaviors that can negatively affect your pregnancy.  Remember the vast majority of pregnant women never need to be on bedrest, but I can't quote you the odds.  It's really senseless anyway since if it happens to you it really doesn't matter if you're one in a thousand.  Good luck with your plans.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Apr 01, 2008 5:59 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Having trouble determining pregnancy
content: Hello, I am doubtful this is pregnancy.  Implantation bleeding typically occurs about the time of your expected period, not before, which is why many women feel they had a period and are not pregnant, when in fact they are.  If your period does not come as expected, take a home test about a week after the expected period date.  Usually these are quite accurate at that point - not 100% but good still.  Best wishes.

title: Re: Having trouble determining pregnancy
content: Of course there is the slight possibility of pregnancy.  One to two in 100 users of the pill will become pregnant.  So, do the pregnancy test at the five week mark.  If negative but still symptomatic, repeat one week later or see a doctor for a blood test which is more sensitive.    Symptoms could be related to hormonal fluctuation and being on the pill does affect your hormones.  Good luck

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 2 periods in a month plus classic preggy signs
content: Hello, While I wouldn't think pregnancy is likely, it is always a possibility when you are sexually active, fertile and particularly without use of birth control.  When you have a "period" after becoming pregnant, it is actually implantation bleeding rather than a true period and most people do describe it as not being their normal type of period, as you have.  This, coupled with your symptoms would suggest doing a pregnancy test.  Assuming the second period was not actually a period, the test should be quite reliable now.  Best wishes.
