author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Water on baby brain (6 month-pregnant period)
content: Hello, Most likely your ultrasound will be followed up with another one (or possibly MRI) that might give more information specific to the concerns raised with what was seen on the first report.  Early ultrasounds are helpful for screening but often they alarm people needlessly. Some abnormalities resolve on their own and others respond well to medical treatments after birth, helping the baby to recover and have as normal a life as possible.  Perhaps you will be referred to a neonatologist or pediatric neurologist for an evaluation to see if there are other problems associated and to help you understand what you are up against.  If so, this will likely be done soon since you have considered a termination and there are legal guidelines that create an urgency.   A decision to terminate is certainly a personal one but I would recommend you meet with the specialist first before deciding.    It sounds like the concern is hydrocephalus, possibly with kidney involvement.  If this is the case, sometimes a cesarean section delivery is recommended to reduce trauma at delivery, then a shunt is placed to help the baby to drain the water into the abdomen from the brain.  Surgery is sometimes even performed on the baby prior to birth in some places.  I wish you the best of luck in the coming weeks as you face this situation.  May you be blessed as you progress in this pregnancy and make your decisions.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Fetal demise
content: Hello, This is such a sad situation.  I am so sorry for your loss.  I can relate since I also had a fetal demise at term.  In my case, my doctor gave me the option for induction which I took gratefully!  I have not regretted doing that.  There may be advantages to letting nature take it's course but there are emotional factors that the doctor might overlook.  I don't know enough about your history to guess why your doctor recommends this option.  You may want to ask for more information.   The problem with induction comes if your cervix is not ready.   In a demise you can usually be given something to soften the cervix and prepare you for induction if your doctor is amenable to it.  If you have had a previous C-section, this may make the doctor reluctant to induce.  This must be a decision between you and your doctor, who will hopefully take into consideration all factors including your health and safety as well as your emotional well-being.    Continuing to carry babies who have died in the womb can be very disturbing.  Well-meaning friends and even strangers comment to the pregnant woman in ways that can be very disturbing if the babies will not be born alive.  These are reasons I favor induction if you are able to get this.    I would like to recommend some websites for support in your grief.  http://www.missingangel.org, http://www.stillbirthsupport.org and http://dailystrength.org/c/Stillbirth/support-group.  I would encourage you to take pictures of your babies at delivery - even if they don't look as good as you would hope.  One day little mementos will be all you have to validate your memory and experience.  Many hospitals have volunteers who put together little packets for grieving moms and include a little blanket, hat, etc. you can put on the babies, then keep these as something that contacted the baby.  They can give you footprints to keep.  This can provide something you can see and touch.  The whole experience tends to take on an unreal feel and it is necessary to have something tangible to help you in your grief.  You will always know that these babies were part of you, they lived inside you and the kicking you felt proved their existence.  May you be blessed in your time of sorrow.  Good luck in the coming very challenging weeks.  Take care

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 5 weeks along, severe cramps and sharp pain for 2 weeks+
content: Hello, Of course you do need to rule out tubal (ectopic) pregnancy and I assume that is what your doctor is doing, knowing that pain can be a symptom.  You did not indicate how far along you are.  Ectopic pregnancies are usually noticed around six or seven weeks.    You also did not indicate how long the pain lasts.  If it is a brief and passing thing, even though it is sharp, it may be round ligament pain.  These ligaments stretch as your uterus grows and often cause sharp, stabbing pain in the lower pelvis, especially when changing positions.    Don't worry about taking the narcotic.  It is safe in pregnancy when taken occasionally for acute pain such as this but you should discuss it with your doctor to get his OK.  Tylenol is always considered safe in pregnancy unless you have liver problems.  Motrin and ibuprofen are the same thing and it is best to avoid these.  They do not cause birth defects but can affect your blood clotting so it is not recommended.    Of course there is also the possibility that you have something else going on that is unrelated to the pregnancy such as appendicitis, bowel or kidney problems.  Since they did labwork and ultrasound, I believe they are monitoring you for anything serious.  If you have some type of infection, this will likely show up.  Hopefully the pain will pass soon on its own even if they never discover the cause.  Keep your doctor posted about any unusual additional symptoms such as bleeding, fever, etc. and whether or not it improves or worsens in the coming days.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Adderall during pregnancy
content: Hello, The easy answer is if you don't really need it, don't take it in pregnancy.  That is the safe course for almost all drugs.  But, that said, often medications are needed in pregnancy and many have been found to be safe.  Label warnings are there because drugs are not tested on pregnant or breastfeeding mothers - thus the manufacturer cannot claim safety.    Teratology services have tracked medications for many years in mothers who were on these either not knowing they were pregnant, or because they really were needed and the risk outweighed potential, though unproven, risks.  Adderall is basically an amphetamine, and these have been studied extensively beginning in the 50s and 60s when they were often prescribed for depression.  Babies of mothers who were on the medications were tracked for 30 years and no increased rate of birth defect, learning disability or other problem was noted in the children of these mothers.  What they did observe was some increase in hypertension (high blood pressure) in the moms which can lead to preterm birth and those babies are at risk for serious complications.  So, if you do take the medication, blood pressure should be monitored closely.  If you already have high blood pressure or a history of preterm birth, it would probably be advised to avoid the Adderall.    The other potential problem for the drug is that it suppresses appetite and this can result in inadequate weight gain for the mother, low birth weight for the baby - again putting the baby at risk.  So, the second caution would be (if you choose to continue the drug) to make sure you are eating a healthy diet and gaining the recommended weight for your body type based on body mass index going into the pregnancy.    As with all medications in pregnancy, risk and benefit must be weighed and you should consult with your health care provider who knows your history so you can make a decision that is in your best interest.    Congratulations on your pregnancy and I wish you the best.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Thu Mar 20, 2008 2:13 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: umbilical cord entanglement
content: Hello, It is difficult to accurately estimate weight in a fetus and they often miss the mark by a bit but this is pretty good for this stage, assuming they are correct.    The baby moves around throughout the pregnancy and often the cord is around various parts of the baby.  Many healthy babies are born with cords around the neck even three times.  It depends on how tightly it is wrapped and whether or not it interferes with the baby's descent into the birth canal.  For this reason the monitoring will focus on any disruption in the baby's heartbeat that might indicate distress and they will be aware that if the baby is not descending, it might be due to the cord.  If that is the case, intervention with a cesarean section might be indicated.  Babies do sometimes have "cord accidents" prior to birth or at the time of delivery so it is important to monitor the baby's movements and if a marked decrease is noted, the mother should be seen right away to assess the status of the baby.  I suspect this information is mostly to alert you and the provider in case anything else develops as the mother nears her anticipated delivery date.  This is all that really can be done at this point.  As I said, it is quite common and usually things work out fine.  Be sure to keep all prenatal care appointments at this time and call or see the doctor if you don't feel right about how things are going, baby's movements, etc.  Best wishes to all of you.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: I am 27 and never had a natural period - can I get pregnant?
content: Hello, It looks like you made a mistake in recording your weight here.  Did you mean 70 lbs?  At any rate anorexia can cause ovulation to cease so I would concentrate on your eating disorder.  Getting to a normal, stable weight can only help your chances.  The body knows it cannot support a pregnancy in such a malnourished state so ovulation is suppressed as part of self-preservation.    See a counselor who specializes in eating disorders.  It is important that you be recovered and with a normal BMI.  Recovering is good but not yet safe enough to grow a baby, especially since your changing (and growing) body image is likely to trigger more anorexia if you have been premature in your assessment of your health.  As I'm sure you know, this is not a quick fix problem.  It will take a while to achieve lasting success in overcoming this disease.  Once the weight stabilizes, your doctor can evaluate your hormone function and help with ovulation stimulation hormones in addition to the treatment for PCOS if needed.    Under these conditions, I can see you having a child in the future.  In the meantime, take a daily multiple vitamin if you don't already do so. Good luck.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Mar 18, 2008 3:15 pm

author: Alexandra C, RN  Nurse Posts: 26 Joined: Fri Mar 14, 2008 3:46 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Spray Tan While Pregnant?
content: Hello Mo Mo37,  The only real concern about the spray tanning is whether the active ingredient can penetrate the skin.  It seems no studies have confirmed that it does, but  if you must use the spray tan, I recommend you wait until your first trimester is over.  Check with your doctor if you are still unsure.  As for the hydration bed, anything that raises the body temperature over 101 degrees F has the potential to cause harm to a developing fetus.  Saunas and hot tubs are not recommended during pregnancy.  I would recommend you avoid the hydration bed during your pregnancy for this reason.  I hope you have a joyful and healthy pregnancy.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Seredyn safe at 30 wks pregnant?
content: Hello, I must first caution you not to assume that because something is "natural' it is safe.  Many unsafe products are completely natural.  In addition to this caution, supplements are not tested or regulated by the FDA and so we do not have adequate data to declare safety.  In fact no medication is tested on pregnant women - but teratology organizations track women who have taken various drugs so they have anecdotal evidence and can sometimes give you reassurance on other medications.  Supplements remain a mystery and even the purity of the product is sometimes in question.  There has on occasion been found other ingredients contained beyond what is disclosed on the label.  Without greater regulation, this is hard to evaluate.    The best advice is to consult with your doctor.  Often a prescription medication for anxiety will be the safest course in both pregnancy and lactation.  Do not assume that just because the label says not to take in pregnancy or breastfeeding without consulting your doctor because they all say this.  It is because of the limited testing and the individual nature of the patient.  Many medications are very safe in breastfeeding and because of the important benefits to mother and baby it is important not to automatically stop breastfeeding because medication is needed.  Check it out first with an organization like OTIS (otispregnancy.org).  Many communities have access to this type of service locally.  Best wishes.

author: Alexandra C, RN  Nurse Posts: 26 Joined: Fri Mar 14, 2008 3:46 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Do I need to have a prenatal checkup yet
content: I would definitely suggest that you find a provider in you area and schedule an appointment in the very near future. Generally you should be seen for your first prenatal visit at about 6-8 weeks, and every 4 weeks after that throughout your first trimester.  During your first appointment your provider will determine you due date, obtain a thorough medical and family history, perform a thorough physical and pelvic exam, and obtain blood and urine for a number of laboratory tests.  Some providers also use early ultrasound to confirm a viable, intrauterine pregnancy and to help determine an accurate EDD (due date).  The provider will also make recommendations to help you maintain a healthy lifestyle during pregnancy and answer your questions.  The first trimester is a crucial period for your baby's development, and it is really important to take a prenatal multivitamin with 600-1000mcg of folic acid daily.
posted_time: Post  by Alexandra C, RN » Sat Mar 15, 2008 12:59 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Do I need to have a prenatal checkup yet
content: Hello, I would add that many OBs will not see their patients before 10-13 weeks unless they have problems arise before then.  We consider 13 weeks to be the latest recommended onset of prenatal care.  Some will have you come earlier or have a nurse visit to be sure you are on vitamins, sometimes draw blood, etc.  Some will see you earlier and of course this would be great, but as I said, some feel there is so little to be done then it is better to wait until a heart beat can be detected.  This is highly individualized with each provider, but you definitely should be on a vitamin in the meantime.    Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Which day is closer to the day i conceived?
content: Hello, There is a range of possible fertile days based on average but any woman may conceive on any day.  If I were to guess, I would say the 15th is closer but it would be impossible for anyone to tell you exactly when at this point.  The typical range is between day 8 and 19 when you start countin on the first day of your period.  Therefore your most likely fertile days would have been between Dec. 13 and 24.  This is how I came up with my educated guess.  But something like 20 percent of women ovulate outside those expected days.  Good luck.

title: Vibrators in pregnancy
content: Hello, There are many unknowns about exposures in pregnancy, but there has not been any evidence so far that this is dangerous to the baby.  Usually exposures are monitored to see if there is any increased risk for birth defects, beyond the usual amount, inherent in all pregnancies.  So, while nobody can make any guarantees, it does not appear to be risky.    Best wishes to you and your baby.

author: Alexandra C, RN  Nurse Posts: 26 Joined: Fri Mar 14, 2008 3:46 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: problems with rh- pregnancy
content: Since your daughter is Rh-negative, there is no chance you were sensitized during that pregnancy and therefore would not have developed any antibodies.  Sensitization could occur during a miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy, some obstetric procedures (like amniocentesis) and a few other scenarios, so without knowing your history it is not possible to know if there is any possibility that you've ever been sensitized, but if you have had any of the above, you should have received an injection of Rh immune globulin, which will prevent your body from making the antibodies.  A blood test for type and antibodies is routinely done at your first prenatal visit, so your doctor would know if you've been sensitized. You should have another test for type and antibodies and receive an injection of the Rh immune globulin at 28 weeks with this pregnancy, to prevent sensitization, and after your delivery both your blood and your babies' blood will be tested to determine if you need another injection of Rh immune globulin. (If either baby is Rh-positive, you will.) To summarize, if you are not sensitized and thus have no antibodies to Rh-positive blood cells, your babies are not at any risk of harm related to Rh incompatibility. Good luck with your pregnancy!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 2nd preg, same symptoms, 4 neg HPTs
content: It is possible you could be pregnant.  Some bleeding in early pregnancy is actually quite common.  I would repeat the pregnancy test a week after the first negative one.  These are usually quite accurate the week after you would expect your normal period.  You can also get a serum (blood) pregnancy test at a clinic.  These are more sensitive than the urine tests for those whose hormone levels may not yet be evident but who are still pregnant.  Women vary on this so it's possible to have a negative test while still being pregnant.    Be patient and good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Waiting to conceive after miscarriage
content: Hello, I have very reliable sources who indicate there is no need to wait as long as you are recovered, have not lost too much blood so as to be anemic and feel up to it emotionally.  The primary reason cited is to have at least one period to help establish the due date of the next baby but with sophisticated ultrasound gestational age dating, this is really irrelevant.  If there were physical reasons such as nutritional deficiency (very underweight, bulimic, etc.) this might be a reason to wait as you build up your body's mass or perhaps stop a bad habit such as smoking.    As for just a general rule, this has been disproven as making a difference to the outcome of the next pregnancy.  If you are healthy you should be fine to try for pregnancy as soon as you feel ready to do so.  Good luck.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Mar 11, 2008 11:07 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: birth control interactions
content: There is the potential for Topamax to reduce the effectiveness of Yasmin or other hormonal birth control methods.  They are sometimes used together but there is some risk for results not quite up to normal for oral contraceptives without drug interactions.  Potential means it COULD; not that it definitely WILL.  So, you are taking a little bit of a chance when not using backup but probably not a huge risk.  And, the pre-ejactulate is also not a huge risk for pregnancy - only slight.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Weight loss at 34 weeks
content: Hello, I assume you mean she is 34 weeks' pregnant.    Overall weight gain can vary considerably and if the woman is overweight going into the pregnancy it is not necessary for her to gain as much as a lean woman, while still giving birth to a healthy baby.  Your sister's weight at this point doesn't indicate to me if she is of normal weight or not.  It is typical to gain weight during the third trimester as this is when the baby is growing in weight.  The beginning stages are cell division and organ development but at this point, adding fat, muscle, contributing to overall well-being like brain development is important so weight loss should be investigated.  It could also be related to the amount of amniotic fluid.  I would recommend she talk to her doctor about this in case they need to do ultrasounds or non-stress testing to be sure the baby is not compromised.  It is important for her to monitor fetal movement.  She should haver regular movement at this point, feeling about 10 kicks per two hour period.   If it is significantly less than usual or if she notices "frantic" movement, these can be warning signs of trouble.  She should also be sure she gets plenty of water to drink.  Dehydration is not good in pregnancy particularly.  Abdominal pain should always be investigated especially if there is blood or high blood pressure as well.  Best wishes and good luck to your sister.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Decrease in Braxton Hicks, strange pains
content: Hello, There is some controversy about Braxton-Hicks contractions.  Some say there is no such thing.  Contractions are contractions, but it is important to determine if it might be true preterm labor as opposed to false labor.  Many women chalk the contractions up to Braxton-Hicks when in fact they are having labor, then only get medical attention when it is too late for anything to be done.  The only way to do this is to see if there are any cervical changes taking place along with the contractions.  Throughout pregnancy your body often has contractions, almost as a preparatory exercise but a decrease in these has not been identified with anything alarming.    It is important to monitor fetal movement and a significant decrease in these can be cause for concern - as can a sudden increase in "frantic" movement.  You should monitor your baby's movements and at this stage in pregnancy you should feel 10 kicks in a two hour block of time.  Monitor this daily at approximately the same time.  Be sure you are well-hydrated as dehydration is a concern in pregnancy especially.    The other sharp pain you described should be evaluated, especially if you notice any bleeding or have high blood pressure.  This can be a warning sign of problems so your doctor should be informed.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 2 questions - staples vs. stiches and 'pain ball'
content: Hello, Good luck on your c section.  I'm sorry you aren't able to have a VBAC.    Stapes and stitches are usually a doctor's preference and they are equally effective.  In both cases they remove them as soon as possible to reduce scarring.  It is important to remember though that the wound can dehiss (open up) and this is a serious complication so even after the closures are removed you must continue to take it easy and not strain your abdominal muscles.  The pain ball may refer to a dosing mechanism where there is a pump with painkillers for your IV that is controlled by the patient who can order a delivery of medication by pushing a button or squeezing a ball.  This way you get more continuous pain relief and the pump prevents overdosage.  It is a good way to deliver analgesia but it is only for the short term.  Once your IV is removed you will rely on other pain relief measures.  Best of luck to you.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Sun Feb 03, 2008 5:09 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 31 weeks pregnant cramping
content: Hello, You must consider the possibility of preterm labor so when you have such cramping, you should see your doctor or midwife.  It can be impossible to tell "Braxton-Hicks" or false labor from true labor unless you have an examination.  There are also tests that can screen for the likelihood of an imminent delivery so see your provider about this.  Preterm labor can sometimes be stopped if treated early but if you wait and go into labor you could reach the point where it could not be helped and your baby would be at risk for many problems related to prematurity.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Percocet and Pregnancy
content: Her doctor will advise her I'm sure, but usually it is reommended that the mother not take it the last month.  Since it might take weaning, it would be good to start right away.  Also, there is the risk the baby could come ahead of schedule and would be at risk for breathing problems if she is still taking the narcotics, so sooner would be best if possible.  She may be able to work on relaxation techniques to control the pain - similar to the kinds of methods which are often employed with labor and delivery such as self-hypnosis, visualization, breathing exercises, etc.  Best of luck to you both.  Thank you for your concern.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 2 1/2 months late and negative hpt.........
content: Hello, It is possible you are pregnant even with negative tests.  People have varying levels of the hormones in pregnancy and while the tests pick up the majority at a fairly early point, some people show negative for several months even though they are pregnant.  Your doctor can do a blood test which is more sensitive.  Your symptoms certainly suggest pregnancy but other hormonal fluctuation can mimic pregnancy.  Recently stopping the pill is one of those times when your hormones may be a bit erratic.  So, I guess the bottom line is, I can't say which it is but either is possible.  Good luck to you.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Pregnancy risks after Gestational Diabetes?
content: Hello, I would not expect any worsening of symptoms in subsequent pregnancies - it does not seem to progress this way.  Gestational diabetes is very common and it's so good that the doctors now screen for it routinely as the greatest concern is with the out-of-control diabetic.  Well-controlled GDM generally results in a healthy mom and baby.    Having had this in pregnancy does predispose you to the possibility of developing type 2 diabetes in the future but it doesn't cause this; just suggests that you might be more prone to it than some other people.  Whatever causes it in pregnancy could also cause it in later life.  You could do some things to help prevent this however.  Regular exercise, a diet low in refined sugars, and maintaining a healthy weight can all help prevent diabetes.    Best wishes and good luck with your plans.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Mon Jan 07, 2008 6:31 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: Inconclusive blood pregnancy test
content: Hi summerday, An inconclusive test essentially means that the test result is not clear. Testing in 48 hours is a standard and measures hCG levels (human chorionic gonadotropin) in the blood to detect pregnancy. Best wishes. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

title: hcg levels going up after a miscarriage
content: Hello, I understand your frustration but it is unlikely you are still pregnant since that would result in much higher levels.  It can take 4 or 5 weeks for levels to return to normal.  An increase could be an indication that your body hasn't yet gotten rid of all the tissue and it may suggest a need for a D and C.  Wait for your doctor's reply or call the office again when he/she is in so they can evaluate whether or not your miscarriage was complete.  Best wishes

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Testing after multiple miscarriages
content: Hi KortCam,  The decision about whether or not to be tested is a decision you'll what to decide for yourself with the advice/input of your husband and doctor.  2 miscarriages can still be an unfortunate coincidence.    If you were to be tested, the main tests that are done are tests to look for hypercoagulable states (conditions that increase the risk of forming blood clots).  With these conditions, small blood clots can form in the vessels that feed the growing baby, compromising its nutrition and ultimately sometimes resulting in a miscarriage.    These conditions include Factor 5 Leiden, Prothrombin 20210 mutation, Antithrombin III, and Lupus anticoagulant (which is actually a procoagulant) among others.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: cramps and growing tummy at 5wks??
content: Hello, I would suspect you are experiencing some bloating, unrelated to the growing uterus if you are sure that you are just five weeks along.  Sometimes your bowels give you trouble when pregnant and perhaps this is the reason.  It would also explain some cramps.  But, cramping in early pregnancy can also be normal.  If there is no blood it is probably nothing to worry about.  If  you were threatening miscarriage, chances are you would begin bleeding as well as cramping.   Give it time to even things out and if you need to take something for your tummy like anti-gas medication, simethicone is safe in pregnancy.    Best wishes for a safe and healthy pregnancy.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: ovulation, birth control and periods?
content: Hello, It is often very normal to have irregular periods.  The majority of women have some fluctuation because hormones are not released at exactly the same rate naturally, the way they are with artificial manipulation from oral contraceptives.  Widespread use of the pill has made us think that a predictable, regular cycle is normal and anything else is problematic.  In an ideal world we might all have regular cycles we can calendar around but in the real world this is not the case.  The irregularity may be somewhat influenced by the pill use but it is just as likely that it is just your individual body's hormone regulation.  Mother Nature tends to surprise us.  It is also nearly impossible to accurately predict your ovulation date or conception time, though you could get it within a few days if you limited sexual activity to one day in particular.  For this reason I wonder why you believe the bleeding was the day after conception.  If it was the day after you had intercourse, it is still possible you ovulated at a different date - earlier or later.  The frequent periods should in no way interfere with your ability to become pregnant.  It just might make it a little harder to predict your approximate time of ovulation.  Most pregnancies occur spontaneously with regular unprotected sexual intercourse in a matter of months without need for diligent calendar watching.  Relaxing can actually assist in the process since you will not be dealing with stress hormones and their possible negative effects.    So, enjoy the experience and let nature take its course.  You are not having any symptoms of concern.  It is possible for an increase in hormonal fluctuation after stopping the birth control pills so irregularity is nothing to be alarmed about.    Good luck in your efforts.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Wed Jan 02, 2008 3:40 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Signs of Pregnancy, but negative results
content: Hello, It could be that your hormones were not high enough yet to be detected on the home test.  Maybe a week later you would get a different result.  Going off birth control pills often results in some cycle disruption so you could be experiencing this.  Try to relax because stress can also delay your period.    It is not always possible to say when you will ovulate.  We give a range only of days 8 though 14 (start counting the first day of period).  Most, but not all, women ovulate during that period of time if they have regular cycles of 26 to 32 days.  When people try to conceive, they concentrate efforts on those days and luck comes into play here.  Do not limit yourself to having sex on those days, but you would want to be sure you are doing it about every other day during the potentially fertile period.  It would be considered normal if it takes up to a year to become pregnant.    Good luck in your efforts.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Mon Dec 31, 2007 1:38 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Getting pregnet before my wedding...
content: Hello, There is a certain amount of luck involved in conceiving a child.  It is a process where hormones, release of egg, intercourse timing all come together and it (sometimes) works.  It does not happen every time you try, even for the most well-planned according to the calendar, and it is considered normal for it to take a year even with regular sexual relations and no birth control.  It is possible you could have some delay in ovulation due to the depo shot but chances are you are ovulating - things just haven't yet worked out that fertilization and implantation has occurred.  I would not be concerned yet about any problem - you probably just need to give it time, have patience and if you want to get married, plan accordingly, allowing pregnancy to happen when it will.  Sometimes we have less to say about this than we would like to think and it just takes persistence, faith and trust that it will happen eventually - when it does, what a happy surprise that can be!    In the past, before birth control pills, most pregnancies occurred this way.   Good luck with your future plans - all of them.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Getting pregnet before my wedding...
content: Hormones vary considerably between women and I can't say how long you might be affected.  Many women do become pregnant right away so clearly it is not a consistent problem; just a possibility and I a only speculating that is COULD be a factor, though I suspect it is just the normal luck of the draw for when conception may actually occur for you.    You have done nothing wrong in the use of the depo and I suspect you will become pregnant if you have regular intercourse without birth control.  You may not know exactly when you ovulate, though many women become very good at recognizing the subtle changes in their vaginal secretions.  This whitish discharge tends to get more plentiful near the time of ovulation.  This is perhaps the easiest way to know on your own.  We predict that most women ovulate somewhere around 14 days after their period begins but again, much variation is the norm.    For most couples, daily or every other day sexual activity will result in pregnancy within a few months.

title: Re: Getting pregnet before my wedding..
content: My daughter recently found out that she would be too high risk for pregnancy due to clotting characteristics in her blood.  An option she is considering is having an embryo created from her egg and her husband's sperm implanted in a surrogate.  Her misgivings about surrogacy:  How much does the blood from the surrogate circulating through the placenta effect the fetus and the genetic influence on the baby?  Assuming that the surrogate eats well, takes care of herself, and has no problems or illnesses during the pregnancy, can any of her genes or family genetic history have an effect on the baby?
posted_time: Post  by judyt » Fri Dec 28, 2007 8:50 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: effects of a surrogate's blood on genetics of baby
content: This is not a problem.  The actual blood is not shared.  Nutrients cross through the placenta but the baby can have an entirely different blood type than the mother.  If blood sharing occurred this obviously would not be the case and the baby would always have the same type.  The only time there is some crossover is at delivery when there is a chance the mother could be exposed to the baby's blood and if she is a negative blood type and the baby is positive, it would be necessary for the mother to receive RhoGam to prevent problems with antibodies she might make that could affect her future pregnancies.  This is a condition that is well controlled and the doctor would be aware of any risk that way with the preventive measures taken, assuming she gets good prenatal and delivery care.    Good luck to your daughter and all concerned in this endeavor.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Irregular period, cramps, sore breasts, bloated stomach
content: Hormonal fluctuation can cause occasional bleeding between periods and this can still be within normal limits. Even though you have a history of regular periods, it is entirely normal to sometimes get it at a different time.  Your other symptoms can certainly be due to a number of problems; not just pregnancy.  PMS, bowel problems, etc.  It is unlikely that the unprotected sex with bleeding right after resulted in pregnancy and that would have been very early to experience anything pregnancy-related.  Implantation bleeding that sometimes occurs when you are pregnancy happens at about the time your next period would occur - a couple of weeks after conception.  Repeating the pregnancy test is your best option but your doctor could perform a blood test which would be even more accurate early on.  Try to be patient and things may resolve on their own. Stress can affect your periods too.  I hope this answers your question.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Pregnancy??
content: It is unlikely you are pregnant with your faithful use of the pill, but there is always that possibility.  Such common symptoms as you describe are often associated with a variety of conditions so you would need to rule them out one at a time, most likely.    You said your last time to have intercourse was Dec. 9 but I assume there were other times since your last bleed as well.  Based on this information, if pregnancy occurred I would suspect it was just that recently.  If you must know this early, I would recommend a blood pregnancy test for accuracy.  By the first week of the new year you will likely either have another period or, if not, you could take a home pregnancy test.    You should check for urinary infection if you continue to have cramping, pain and urinary frequency as this could be the problem.  Another potential concern might include bowel irritability.  As you suggested, there are also sometimes side effects with the pill that can mimic pregnancy so this is also a possibility.  I'm sorry I can't confirm what is actually happening in your case.  You can wait it out a little while and see if it subsides but if symptoms get worse you should have it checked out.  Best wishes.

title: [no title]
content: Is this too low of a heartbeat - should I be concered?  Also just got put on thyroid medication for hypothyroid - what are the chances of normal pregnancy with thyroid disorders?
posted_time: Post  by ambrew07 » Wed Dec 12, 2007 12:16 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Baby's heartrate 122 BPM at 8 weeks, 2 days pregnant
content: Hello, You should be aware that the dose of medication may have to be increased during pregnancy in the case of hypothyroidism. Your blood level of TSH will be periodically checked throughout pregnancy to see if any adjustment is needed. Thyroid function tests should continue to be reviewed every 2-3 months throughout the pregnancy. After delivery, the dose should be close to the pre-pregnancy dose and thyroid function tests reviewed two months later.  Controlled thyroid levels will ensure your healthy pregnancy.  Thyroid medication does not hurt the baby but not taking it as needed could.  Do plan to breastfeed your baby for additional health benefits.  The medication will not do any harm at that time either and will help to ensure a good milk supply.  Fetal heart rate is typically between 120 and 160/minute.  It doesn't matter if you are on the low end or the high end, it is still in the normal range.    Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Wed Dec 12, 2007 4:14 pm

author: Sandy Tracy RN  Nurse Posts: 60 Joined: Wed Nov 07, 2007 6:57 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi, Ambre07,    A normal fetal heartbeat at 6-7 weeks of age is 90-110 beats per minute.  At 9 weeks the normal heartbeat is 140-170.  Since you are just over the 7 weeks and too early for the 9th week.  I would say your baby is fine.  At 7 weeks the prescence of a heartbeat is a sign of a healthy pregnancy.  As far as your thyroid condition it is perfectly safe to take thyroid medication during pregnancy.  This will not affect the thyroid development of the baby.  A TSH level should be monitored frequently during pregnancy to make sure you do not need a medication adjustment.  As for having a normal pregnancy, most babies that develop problems are due to mom not being treated for a thyroid disorder.  Since you are currently being treated for this disorder your chances of having a normal pregnancy is good.I encourage you to talk to your doctor about the continued need for monitoring your TSH, and free T4.    Good luck and congratulations. Sandy RN

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: about 34 weeks pregnant and have a nonproductive cough
content: Since you are under a doctor's care, I would suggest you talk to your provider.  There is always the possibility your cold could have progressed to pneumonia or bronchitis.  If it is viral antibiotics will not help (probably the reason the Zpack did not take care of it) but secondary bacterial infections can arise after you have been fighting a virus and your resistance is down.  So, this does not mean you may not need antibiotics yet.    It sounds like you have done much for your condition already and it may just require more time, rest, fluids and patience.  It can take a while for your immune system to fully eliminate the infection, especially during pregnancy.   You might try resting in a recliner instead of a bed for better oxygen exchange and increased comfort.  As long as you are able to get adequate oxygen and your doctor feels your lungs are clear, you may just have to wait it out.    Good luck in your recovery and with the birth of your child.

posted_time: Post  by llm8221 » Mon Dec 10, 2007 12:29 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Tea tree oil and lavendar???
content: You should be commended for your diligent concern in pregnancy for the safety of your unborn child.  The problem with these things is that they are not regulated by the FDA and we wouldn't test on pregnant women even if they were.  There have been reports lately that we are regularly breathing and consuming millions of toxins and they are only scratching the surface of finding out what possible responses we may be seeing.  We know there are unexplained increases in certain diseases and syndromes which may be related to environmental factors.    Lavendar has been implicated to a degree in affecting boys sexual organs by increasing estrogen.  There are not a lot of studies about this to confirm but if you want to be safe on it, avoid the lavender for baby boys.  How it might affect pregnancy is anyone's guess at this point.  We have lots of toxins in our world and we need to learn more, do more and live differently than we have in the past.  Many people are switching to more organics, fewer additives and chemicals, etc. to be on the safe side.    I have heard some lectures recently that have suggested we stay away from aromatherapy.  The fact that it does help for certain conditions is a clue that it could also have adverse effects.       Along these lines, it is recommended that we all avoid microwaving in plastic.  Bits of plastic get into our food and it's just not good for us. This is a hard habit to break.  There are many more safety concerns about the environment but these are a couple of things that can be done to help.    Best wishes for you and your children.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 41 Days past period-negative tests
content: If I were you I would feel quite confident that I was not pregnant but if you continue to not get your period you may want to go in.  Irregularity is more normal than you may think.  In this day of the pill, women have come to expect very regular menses.  So, you may not be conceiving or some other problem causing the cessation of your periods, but after all the testing that has been done, I don't think it is due to pregnancy.    Are you by chance underweight or a heavy exerciser?  Stress such as this or mental stress can result in missed periods.  Having amenorrhea (absence of periods) is rarely caused by anything serious.    It can take several months following birth control pill use for periods to get back to "normal."  There are other hormonal imbalances that can cause this symptom and this could generate from one of several glands, involving different hormones.  If you go a few months without a period, you should be evaluated as to what might be causing this.  Missing three or more in a row would probably be a good indicator that it is time to have it checked.  Remember, though, this is a symptom; not a disease.    Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Missed Period but Negative Pregnancy Test
content: Hello, Your symptoms do suggest pregnancy and some people do not respond to the tests at first due to variable hCG levels.  If your symptoms continue and you do not get your period you should have a serum (blood) pregnancy test which is more sensitive than urine.    Other hormones can cause symptoms that mimic pregnancy - some people experience these regularly in association with their pregnancy.  Since you are noticing a difference it seems unlikely.  But, if they continue with negative pregnancy tests, you should see a doctor.    Good luck.

title: [no title]
content: I am 7 weeks and already heard the heartbeat a few days ago through a vaginal ultrasound.  Since everything looked good and i heard the heartbeat does that lessen my chance of miscarriage the 1st trimester?
posted_time: Post  by llm8221 » Fri Dec 07, 2007 9:06 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 7 weeks and already heard the heartbeat...so???
content: Hello, Congratulations on your pregnancy.    I would say that at least in one way your chances are now somewhat decreased for miscarriage.  There is a condition called a blighted ovum where the baby never develops.  Your ultrasound has revealed that this type of miscarriage won't happen.  However, there are other things that can go wrong so you can't totally breathe a sigh of relief yet.  It is estimated that up to 30% of all pregnancies result in miscarriage, usually this occurs by the 10th to 12th week so time is on your side if you make it to that point.  These are the miscarriages that are believed to be caused by chromosomal defects or implantation/placenta problems.  Later miscarriages are usually due to different factors.  They still happen, but not nearly as often.  Take good care of yourself, eat healthy food, exercise, take a daily multivitamin, wear your seatbelt, get adequate rest and try not to stress too much.  All these will help you assure a healthy pregnancy.  Beyond that there is little we can do.  Best wishes.

I haven't been taking any medications (besides pre-natal vitamins) except the occassional paracetamol. This is my first pregnancy.  Because of my age I may already have some problems but I don't want to hurt the baby by taking ventolin.  Is it safe to use this during pregnancy?
posted_time: Post  by Ree » Sat Dec 08, 2007 3:40 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Ventolin and pregnancy
content: Hello,  I am so glad to see you are taking your prenatal vitamins.  I can understand your concern about your medications. Most women with asthma have perfectly normal, healthy babies, but we know that uncontrolled asthma can result in too little oxygen getting to the baby, increasing the risk for low birthweight and other problems. Uncontrolled asthma can also increase your risk for pregnancy complications such as pre-eclampsia and hyperemesis (too much vomiting).    These are much greater threats than the unknown potential risk to the baby by using your medication to remain in control.  We have not seen documented association of increased birth defects in babies whose mothers have used their asthma medications but since we don't do studies on pregnant women we do not have the kind of controlled studies that can show definite safety.  For this reason the manufacturers do not make claims to that effect.  Talk to your doctor about this but the evidence does suggest it is important to be well-ventilated and if that means using your medication, this is the risk/benefit ratio we are looking for.    Your age does not increase your risk greatly.  There is nothing magical that happens to a woman's body at precisely age 35 so don't worry too much.  It is true that having your first baby now slightly increases some risks but most women your age deliver perfectly healthy babies and it is becoming much more common than it was in the past besides.  Taking care of yourself is your best assurance for a healthy pregnancy.  Good luck with the virus and let us know if you have other concerns.    Best wishes.

title: Brown/redish discharge
content: Hi Sofia, I think you can be confident that you did not contract a sexually transmitted infection at the dental office.  The cause of your gums bleeding should be investigated but it is not related to your periods unless you have some kind of systemic condition that has affected hormones throughout the body.    Stress can result in absence of periods, even if it doesn't seem worse than usual.  Many women have times of period irregularity and it is considered normal. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Ruebella vaccine???
content: Not likely.  You probably were not showing adequate levels of immunity so they gave you the vaccine after delivery when they could be certain you were not pregnant.  This is a shot that should not be given during pregnancy.  They test at your prenatal appointment to see if you are immune.  If not, they give the vaccine after you give birth.  Most people develop immunity after the vaccine so I expect the next time you are pregnant and your doctor tests you will show the antibodies and won't need it again.  It is a rare person who would need to repeat it.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Flu shot during pregnancy
content: Yes, it is possible to get the influenza vaccine without preservatives or with only trace amounts but the supply is limited so you would have to check with the supplier to find out if theirs is that particular type.    The dangers of flu are greater for pregnant women so it is important for you to get the vaccine.  You can read the US Government Center for Disease Control information about influenza vaccine and preservatives here: http://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/qa/thimerosal.htm  Sometimes web addresses change but you can get information about vaccine safety from the CDC through a search if this one does not work for you.  There are many toxins in our environment that are known dangers and much more serious than the preservatives in adult vaccines.  I'm glad to see you are concerned with the health of your baby.  Hopefully we can all do more to clean up the air, water, and soils to make the world safer for the next generations.  Most likely, birth defects are caused by a combination of many different environmental toxins and genetic predisposition.  You are wise to be cautious and people like you who are concerned with safety issues can be active in world health concerns.       Meanwhile, use your seatbelt, don't smoke, drink alcohol, take your vitamins, eat a healthy diet and exercise.  These are the things that will do the most to ensure a healthy baby.  Good luck!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Bleeding vs. spotting
content: Hello, I certainly understand your concern.  The good news is that your doctor is right.  What you describe is perfectly normal in early pregnancy.  There is no way to be sure everything will continue as you hope but what you have seen is not a cause for grave concern either.    In most early miscarriages, there is really not much that can be done to prevent.  Some doctors are prescribing progesterone if they suspect you may not have adequate levels of that hormone but it will only help if that was the cause of your previous miscarriages.  Some women have clotting disorders and a blood thinner is sometimes prescribed but these cases are not the most common; just two of the identified factors involved in miscarriage.  If it was a chromosomal abnormality, as is most often assumed, there is nothing that can be done to prevent it.  I do wish you luck this time around.  Talk to your doctor about your concerns.  Especially since you have had repeated miscarriages, it is worth investigating.  Best wishes.

title: can pregnant women take emergen-c?
content: Hello, Herbal supplements and megadoses of vitamins such as vitamin C or others you may have in this, have not been studied in pregnancy so we really don't know about potential problems with it.  It definitely is not something that has been found to have negative effects as we see women who have taken it so I would not be overly concerned, but at the same time I cannot recommend it routinely.  Having taken it a couple times is very unlikely to be a problem for your baby.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: heavy period or miscarriage?
content: It is possible it could be either a heavy period or an early miscarriage.  If the latter is the case, it is very likely her body will just take care of it anyway.  If she has other symptoms she should definitely see a doctor but if it is just bleeding with clots (normal) and cramping, the chances are she never will know if it was a very early miscarriage.  If she continues for more than a week to have heavy bleeding it would be good to have it checked out.  There would be no point in doing a pregnancy test now because she is either on her period or having a miscarriage and in either case the test would be negative.  If a woman who is sexually active misses a period, a home pregnancy test is usually quite reliable within a week after the missed period date.  Thank you for your concern for your friend.  I do not believe her future reproduction will be affected unless she contracts a sexually transmitted infection such as HIV, syphilis or gonorrhea.    Best wishes to you both.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: How far in pregnancy do you think i am??
content: It is impossible for me to guess what she meant and the period date is really all we can go by until later when ultrasounds can verify the most likely due date.  Only about 30% of women ovulate during the 5 or 6 days considered most likely.  That means 70% of women ovulate earlier or later so there will be much variability.  A period date just gets us in the ballpark.    Even blood work has limited accuracy here as hCG levels, which double anywhere from 48 to 72 hours (and up to 96 hours later on) are not consistent enough to say for sure when conception occurred.  We give our best guess to get us in the ball park then watch how the baby grows. The routine mid-pregnancy ultrasound is quite accurate at determining gestational age.  Earlier ultrasound exams can also give a pretty good idea but likely within a week or two either way.    This may be helpful: Typical test results for hCG #  3 weeks LMP: 5 - 50 mIU/ml # 4 weeks LMP: 5 - 426 mIU/ml # 5 weeks LMP: 18 - 7,340 mIU/ml  Many OBs don't actually see their patients until around 10-12 weeks' gestation so this is quite typical.   At this point it should not be that significant to know exactly how many weeks along you are.  Take your vitamins, exercise and eat right, avoid unhealthy habits so you can have a healthy pregnancy.  This is where I would put my efforts if I were you.  Good luck and congratulations on your pregnancy!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Restoril and pregnancy
content: Hi, I can certainly understand your concern.  I would check with a teratology service if you have one in your area.  You can go to this link:  http://www.otispregnancy.org/ for locating local agencies.  These people are the experts at medication interaction in pregnancy or lactation.  They should be able to give you some information more specific to your situation.  They probably can say if it is likely to be a problem with just such limited use and, if so, what might be expected.  Let me know if you can't get information and I will call our local teratology service.    They have some medication fact sheets on their website, but I didn't see one for Restoril.  In general, discontinuing such medications once pregnancy is suspected or confirmed is often enough to reduce risks considerably.  It is often the cumulative effect of exposure that causes problems.    Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: normal or miscarrage
content: At this point it could go either way.  There is a high risk of miscarriage in general - possibly as high as 30% of all pregnancies when you consider those who don't even know they are pregnant when they miscarry.  But it is very common to have these symptoms in a normal pregnancy as well.  So, it's just a waiting game at this point.  If it is a miscarriage you will likely continue to have symptoms which will likely be more pronounced.    There is really nothing you can do to intervene.  Early miscarriages are thought to be related to chromosomal abnormalities and things just aren't developing properly.  Nothing you can do will stop this type of miscarriage.  It never hurts to take it easy a bit to give your body every chance in case the pregnancy is to be OK.    Good luck.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Pregnancy and Nexium
content: Hi Llm8221,  Nexium is considered by most to be a class B medicine.  Many physicians will continue patients on nexium during pregnancy.  That being said, there is always a small risk.  One should consider if the medicines are necessary.  If they are and there is little danger to the baby with them then they can be continued.   Best wishes.

author: llm8221  Guest Posts: 21 Joined: Thu Nov 17, 2005 9:43 am Location: Omaha, NE
title: [no title]

posted_time: Post  by llm8221 » Thu Nov 15, 2007 11:47 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Of the proton pump inhibitor class medicines (of which nexium is a part), nexium is probably among the safest.  There are a few others (prevacid and protonix) that are also class B.  Nexium's "brother" medicine, omeprazole (brand name prilosec) is rated class C.    The lesser strength antacids, such as famotidine (Pepcid) or ranitidine (zantac) are both class B as well.  You can discuss with your obstetrician whether or not she thinks any of these would be safer but I suspect that the Nexium is just as safe or more safe than some of the other options.  The one antacid that is very safe and can give some extra needed calcium is Tums.  While it is good at controlling heart burn it is no where near as strong as the other medications above.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Will taking clomid be OK !!
content: Hello, I can understand that you are anxious to conceive and worried about your circumstances.  PCOS can definitely make it difficult, though many people conceive naturally in spite of this condition.   I would hope you are getting the PCOS in control prior to attempting fertility treatments because you might conceive without the fertility drugs.  Because so many women with PCOS have high insulin levels or their body does not use insulin efficiently, insulin medications such as Metformin can help normalize insulin levels.  This alone has been found helpful in regulating periods and promoting ovulation.  If you are overweight, losing a few pounds can also improve your chances for ovulation.    Your doctor will need to evaluate and determine how to handle your nonstop bleeding.  Clomid is not known to fix that problem.  It is a serious medication and should only be taken under a doctor's care after careful evaluation to determine if you are a candidate for this treatment.  It also greatly increases your odds for multiples which carry many other problems such as preterm birth and lifelong problems that often go along with that.  You should be made well aware of the risks.  Often when people are feeling desperate to conceive, they brush off these risks, then when they conceive multiples they may risk losing the babies or having serious problems they really haven't considered but which may compound their sorrow.    Clomid itself often causes other side effects as well and your doctor should discuss these with you prior to prescribing the medication.  I repeat, DO NOT TAKE THIS MEDICATION ON YOUR OWN, even if you are able to get your hands on it without a prescription.   Good luck in your efforts to have a child.

author: ThreePrinces  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Fri May 04, 2007 5:49 pm
title: [no title]
content: I think I can help you feel better.  I'm not sure how much you know about the menstrual cycle.  If you know a lot, then go ahead and don't pay attention to this entire paragraph.  =)  okay.   The first day of bleeding is cycle day 1.  Typically bleeding will last about 5 days.  Ovulation occurs anywhere between cycle day 11 or so up until very late in the cycle-the average day is day 14.  Sperm can live inside the female tract for up to 5 days.  There is typically a 7 day window around ovulation where it is POSSIBLE (but not likely, since it is not likely for sperm to live those 5 days or to conceive after ovulation) to conceive.  The egg will only live about 12-24 hours.  So it's safe to say there are 7 days where you should either avoid intercourse or use birth control.  After ovulation, there is a phase called the Luteal Phase that will last anywhere from 10 to 18 days.  A home pregnancy test will be positive anywhere after around 12 days past ovulation or so.  What I'm trying to say is, if these encounters were a month ago, if you were to take a test now it would be positive if you were pregnant.  The bleeding may be annovulatory bleeding.  A woman does not always ovulate during her cycle.  This causes stress for her because she worries about pregnancy when her period doesn't come "on time."  A period that is "late" is really kind of a myth....ovulation days can vary in the same woman from cycle to cycle.  I know that I have had ovulations anywhere from cycle day 12 to cycle day 100+.  Sometimes it just happens.  And when you're under stress, as you are right now, it is even more likely to occur.  "Breakthrough bleeding" like you just had is very common during annovulatory cycles.  I'm sure that was long winded.  I'm not a doctor, I've just spent many years in the throws of infertility and I know menstrual cycles very very well.  =)  My advice is to take a pregnancy test.  If these encounters were a month ago, IF you were pregnant it would be positive by now.  No matter what, it will put your mind at ease.

author: ThreePrinces  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Fri May 04, 2007 5:49 pm
title: [no title]
content: A blood test at your doctor's office will be billed to your insurance and if you're on the parents' insurance, they may very well find out.  And since it is called a "quantitative HCG" or "qualitative HCG", if your parents know that HCG is the pregnancy hormone, then they would know what it was.  You can always get a test at Planned Parenthood, however I don't know if they do blood tests or not.  But really, the home pregnancy tests that you buy at the store are very sensitive and accurate.  Especially given the fact that your incidents were a month ago and if you conceived then, you would be about 6 weeks along by now.  There are certain brands that are more sensitive than others.  I have certain brands that I like better than others.  This website has a great table showing the sensitivity of home pregnancy tests:  http://www.fertilityplus.org/faq/hpt.html  Tests measuring the lowest mIU are going to be the most sensitive.  I advise you to steer clear of the ones from the Dollar Store though, despite the fact that they are listed on that website.  Those tests are notorious for "evaporation lines", or false positives.  When performing a home pregnancy test, be certain to follow the directions and read the test after the time frame and not any later.  Many tests will get an evaporation line after they have sat for an hour or two and make it look positive when it really is not.  Good luck and be sure to update

content: Hi,  My wife is Rh -ve and I am Rh +ve. During the 5th month of my wife's first pregnancy, ICT was done on her and the results were -ve, i.e. there were no anitbodies for Rh +ve blood created in her red blood cells.   Then upon doctor's advice she took an antiD injection (Rhogam). When the ICT was repeated after the completion of 8th month, the results were positive with the titre ratio as 1:8. Upon doctors advise we went for a successful casearan operation.   But after the delivery the tests that were conducted on the baby's blood, she is also Rh -ve and the DCT also resulted negative.   I would like to know, why the Indirect coombs test, gave a positive result the second time, when the baby was also Rh -ve and the DCT done on the baby is also -ve.  Also is there any problems for my wife because of this Rh sensitisation?   Thanks,  Vinod
posted_time: Post  by VinodDobhal » Sun Nov 11, 2007 10:30 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Positive Indirect Coomb's Test
content: Hi Vinod,  There is a very logical explanation for the lab testing.  Hopefully I can explain it clearly.  As you have described, blood types are either Rh postive or Rh negative.  The Rh factor is also known as the D antigen.  The baby will receive one gene from each mom and dad.  If either of those genes is the Rh + gene the baby will be Rh +.  In your families' case, your wife is Rh neg. so she has two copies of the Rh negative gene.  With you being Rh + and having a baby that is Rh neg. you must have one copy of the + gene and one of the neg. gene (causing you to be Rh + but able to pass the Rh neg. gene to your child).  When mom's are Rh negative there is a chance that the baby could be Rh +.  In this case, if some of the baby's blood gets into mom's blood stream she may develop antibodies to the Rh+ blood cells.  These antibodies subsequently can cross the placenta and destroy the baby's blood cells causing severe problems.    To prevent this, Rh negative moms are given an injection of Rhogam.  This is Rh + antibody.  While it may seem counter-intuitive to give the antibody that we are trying to prevent from forming the reason is quite clever.  This way, there is some, but not much, of the antibody floating through mom's body.  If any of the Rh + baby blood cells get into the mom's blood stream the antibody binds them before mom's body is able to react so that mom never forms antibodies to the red cells.  Now, on to the indirect coombs test.  There are two types of coombs test (direct and indirect).  The direct test looks for the antibodies to the Rh + antigen in the baby and the indirect looks for it in the mom.  When your wife was tested she was initially negative indicating that she had not formed antibodies to the Rh + cells.  This indicates that the Rhogam can protect her from forming these antibodies.  She was subsequently appropriately given the Rhogam shot.  After this she was tested again and found to have a positive indirect coombs test.  This subsequent positive test is expected because she was given the Rh+ antibody (in the Rhogam).    I am uncertain why the cesarean section was recommended.  The subsequent + test would not be indicative of the mother developing an Rh antibody.  The titer was low suggestive that the Rh antibody present was from the Rhogam.  Generally, a second test is not done because it will be positive.    Please do not take this to mean that I am second guessing your obstetrician.  If the obstetrician suspected the baby may have been in danger and was developed enough for delivery, the decision was probably made that it was safest to deliver the baby.  I suspect that there was more involved in the decision than just the Rh factor.  I hope this helps some and isn't too confusing.  Please feel free to ask any follow up questions if this doesn't make sense.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by Ranjith » Tue Nov 13, 2007 3:42 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Advise on healthy child
content: It would be recommended that you have genetic counseling because first cousins are more likely to have similar genetic makeup making it more likely to have the same abnormal gene that might not appear in either of you.  This is because there are recessive genes and it sometimes takes the same defective gene from each parent to show up as a defect in the child.  Other than this, I know of no way that you could effect the outcome by any behavior or precautions.  If you are near a university, this might be a place to start looking for a genetic counselor.    Good luck.

posted_time: Post  by redfuzzybubbles » Mon Nov 12, 2007 12:30 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Fertilaid
content: It is very unlikely you need to use any fertility aid.  At your age, a normal, sexually active woman will likely achieve pregnancy within the year.  Chances are you are already ovulating so why would you want to take a supplement that is supposed to help you to ovulate?  I would not take anything now except a multivitamin containing at least 400 mcg folate (folic acid).  This has been shown to decrease serious birth defects considerably when it is taken from the very time of conception.    If you want to try particularly when you are fertile and if you have a normal 26 to 32 day cycle, you should have regular sex (like every other day) between days 8 and 19.  Start counting on the first day of your last period.    Meanwhile, relax and let nature take its course.  Eat well, stop any bad health habits like smoking, drinking and drugs.  See a doctor for a preconception visit to see if you have any immunizations due or any underlying health problem that should be addressed.  If you are overweight, the doctor will likely advise you to lose a bit (being overweight alone can decrease fertility and cause complications in pregnancy).  Make sure you and your boyfriend are mentally and emotionally ready to handle the stress of parenthood.  Read some books about parenting or consider taking a class.  You won't have much time for this once your baby is here.  But, it's good to know what to expect in the way of crying, sleeping and eating patters of newborns, how your life will change, etc.  Some people do not have realistic expectations about this and they have trouble with a demanding infant who requires frequent feedings and does not sleep through the night for several months.    Also, study about breastfeeding so you will be prepared to give your baby the best possible nourishment.  It's also very good for you in several ways.  It is natural and normal but still there is a learning curve and you will be most successful if you prepare.    Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: What are the chances of my being pregnant?
content: It would be impossible to say because your symptoms can be present in either case.    Try to be patient as it usually takes a few months for conception even when you are trying.  All conditions must be just right and there's a certain amount of luck that is unpredictable.  So, while you were likely having sex during your fertile time, you still may not achieve pregnancy at this time.  Keep in mind also that there is a high rate of miscarriage, often occurring before you even know you are pregnant.  For this reason, getting a very early test can sometimes be painful.  If you actually do miscarry, you might have a harder time than if you didn't know it.    What you can do now is prepare yourself to be in the best possible physical health by taking a multivitamin which contains at least 400 mcg folic acid or folate daily.  You should be eating healthy food, exercising, losing a little weight if you are overweight, and stopping any bad health habits such as smoking, drinking or drugs.  Then try to relax and let things happen naturally.  This is usually how it happens!  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: BIRTH CONTROL POSSIBILITY OF PREGNANCY
content: I assume you mean you had unprotected sex on the Tuesday and Wednesday following your period which started on Oct. 31- with the patch being applied on Nov. 4? You did not specify which days those were but assuming that it was Nov. 6 & 7 I would say pregnancy is not too likely, but possibly could happen.    The fact that you did have the hormonal patch at that time, along with the fact you most likely would have just been moving into the time when you might be fertile on Nov 7- assuming the hormone does not suppress ovulation this time and that it occurs at the expected time (day 8 through 19 of your cycle).  The 7th would put you into your first of about 12 days where ovulation would be most likely to occur.  This puts you in a pretty safe situation.    The backup recommendation for the first week following the Sunday start is to avoid the very small risk of ovulating early prior to the beginning of the method. If by chance you are breastfeeding, your risk of pregnancy is even lower but I suspect that is not the case.  The only thing you can do now is wait for a pregnancy test to say for sure, assuming your period does not start as expected when you stop the patch for week four.  Meanwhile just continue the patch with weekly changes as prescribed.    Good luck and best wishes as you serve your country.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 5 weeks pregnant
content: This is very confusing to everyone so don't feel badly.  Pregnancy is counted in weeks from the last period; not from the actual conception date.  We don't really know what day you conceived but when the doctor gives you this conception date it is likely based on the assumption you conceived around day 14 of your cycle.  That means when you count weeks (starting at the period onset - the only real date we have) you actually get a "freebie" of about two weeks.  In other words you are counted as having completed two weeks before you even conceived.  That's just the way it's done.  Logical perhaps from the need for a beginning date to count from, but confusing as to weeks' gestation.   I hope this makes sense.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Sun Oct 21, 2007 12:37 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: D&C after miscarriages
content: Hello, I am sorry for your loss.  Of course you are worried about future pregnancies. You didn't say if your first two were normal deliveries or not.  But either way, it is difficult to suffer through this.    I do think that if there had been a serious complication such as a puncture, your doctor would have informed you.  I also think you would have had more severe symptoms.  The first thing I would do is ask the doctor for a complete explanation of how the procedure went, if there were any complications, how much blood was lost (and if this is within the normal range) and you could even request a copy of the report of the surgery to read yourself.  If there had been a puncture, it would be written along with what was done for it.  I hope this helps you to feel more confident.  For future planning, I would recommend that you continue to take a prenatal or multivitamin to help you prepare for your next pregnancy.  Take care and good luck.
