author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Taking Clomid
content: I believe your doctor is just making sure you have sex during your most likely time for fertility.  Any additional days prior to that would be a bonus for you but should not interfere with your efforts at all.  Of course I do not know your situation and cannot know what your doctor means for sure, but this is my speculation.    Good luck in your efforts.  Meanwhile, I have to remind you to take a multivitamin which contains at least 400 mcg folate if you aren't already.  If you do conceive you should have adequate folic acid stores in your body from the very moment of conception and most people's diet alone is not enough to help reduce the risk of some serious birth defects.  Folic acid taken from the outset has been shown to reduce neural tube defects such as spina bifida by 2/3.    Also, keep in mind that with clomid your chances of conceiving multiples are greatly multiplied.  Take this medication cautiously, and with the knowledge that multiples, especially more than two, are high risk for many problems, mostly relating to preterm delivery.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 28 weeks and suspected fratured ribs
content: It is not a good idea to deliver earlier than a week before your EDD unless there is a good reason, such as the baby would have a better chance outside than inside the womb.  There is always the chance the dates are of a bit and the baby might have breathing difficulties due to prematurity.  We come up with a guesstimate based on typical conception date and measurements but it can still be off by a week or two.  If the doctor did decide there was a good reason to do it earlier, they would likely check for lung development first.  The risks to the baby are so great.  Even though they can save many premature babies, there are often long-term consequences.  The closer your baby is born to term, the better his/her chances for health.  Even though the mother's comfort is important, it is not the highest priority.  I would ask your doctor for a prescription cough suppressant to  help with that part of the problem.  Also, you could inquire about an alternative allergy medication that might be OK in pregnancy.  I know it is hard to do this but it will be good for your baby if you can endure to the end of the pregnancy.  Hopefully you can get some relief to make it easier for the last trimester.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: C-Section - Leaving Umbilical Cord & Placenta attached?
content: Your doctor should be able to leave the placenta in place for around five minutes (the time frame within which you would normally deliver it if having a vaginal delivery).  There are even some women who deliver the placenta naturally even after a c-section removal of the baby.  Any longer wait would be unnatural so if you are opting for going more with nature here for bleeding concerns , the five minutes should be adequate.  I hope this answers your question.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: You should still be able to do this snuggling part.  The placenta in a vaginal birth is delivered and cord cut, sometimes as baby is placed on the chest and sometimes before that.  It is not necessary to delay that in order to get the baby on your chest or even to nurse.  A c section does mean a little more awkwardness due to positioning but the same bonding events should take place.  Let the staff know your desires so they can accommodate as much as is feasible.  I guess what I'm saying is the suturing/closing will take place right away and delaying delivery of the placenta is not going to make a difference there except for the possible five minutes.    In a vaginal birth, you sometimes are getting stitched from the episiotomy or tear while holding your baby.    Good luck with your birth plans.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Norm HCG and progestrone, is there a good change of fetal HB
content: The hCG levels will peak at about 8-12 weeks of pregnancy and then will decline, remaining at lower levels throughout the remainder of the pregnancy. Ultrasound findings are much more accurate at diagnosing pregnancy viability after 5-6 weeks gestation than hCG levels are.  Here are guidelines based on gestational age determined by last menstrual period (LMP) #  3 weeks LMP: 5 - 50 mIU/ml # 4 weeks LMP: 5 - 426 mIU/ml # 5 weeks LMP: 18 - 7,340 mIU/ml  Good luck with your pregnancy

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: I knew the doctor was wrong!!! i need to rant!
content: I am sorry you have had such a terrible experience.  I would have expected the doctors you saw would have been the most expert on your case since they have the exam, history, labs, xrays, ultrasounds on their side.  The best we can do here is advise based on limited information and typical case scenarios.    Yes, healthcare providers need to really listen to their patients.  Unfortunately people do fall through cracks sometimes when their case is different from the "norm."  It is good you are persistent in following up for good care.  Yours is not a typical case of ectopic pregnancy.  It is an emergency and usually it is more clear so you get the right treatment early on.    Good luck to you today with your procedure and recovery.  You have traveled a very rocky road when it comes to reproductive health.  Perhaps you will want to search for a doctor you feel is better able to relate to you and maybe your brother could refer you to someone you could feel good about for your future efforts - perhaps a specialist in high risk pregnancies and repeated loss patients.    Thank you for sharing your experience here.

Of course you can seek another opinion and given your pregnancy history you may wish to consult with an OB who specializes in high risk pregnancies/early losses.  There is not a lot that can be done to prevent miscarriage but with your history it might be worth examining the value of what is available now.    Best wishes.

author: ThreePrinces  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Fri May 04, 2007 5:49 pm
title: [no title]
content: Mslayla~  I was thinking about your post today while I was driving and a couple of thoughts occurred to me:  First, do you know what cycle day you ovulated by chance?  Because how many days past ovulation you are could really effect beta #s.  If your beta is 4000+, then you're probably around 20 days past ovulation or so, so about 5 weeks gestation.  Second, any chance there could have been twins?  I was just thinking about how close you were to doubling, even though it was 3 days and not 2 days.  Sometimes if you had the beginning of a twin pregnancy, and then one of the babies dies; your betas can slow down.  So if you had 2 babies there for little while, and say one died in between these two beta draws you had; then your number would not double.  I don't know if that's making any sense.  I read somewhere that a lot more twins are conceived than people think; and one of the babies dies before it is ever discovered.  Most women do not get betas drawn, and do not have ultrasounds before 8 weeks.  (that's mainly reserved for those of us with infertility and recurrent pregnancy loss.)  ..and you're right, after your beta reaches 2000 the pregnancy should be visible by ultrasound.  However, at this point you'd probably only be able to see a fetal pole and yolk sac.  It might be best to wait another week so that you can (hopefully!) see a heartbeat.  That will give you a lot of peace of mind.  I'm not a doctor, I've just spent a very long time dealing with infertility/recurrent pregnancy loss and seeing a Reproductive Endocrinologist.  I learned a lot.  =)   I'd love to help in any other way I can!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Do all women spot blood when prego?
content: No, but many do and it can be perfectly normal.  In some cases it can lead to a miscarriage, especially if there is cramping along with the spotting, if it gets heavier, etc.  It can be associated early on with implantation of the placenta.  It can also be due to a small placental tear or in later pregnancy it can suggest a low-lying placenta.

content: how can you determine your conception date if you do not have regular periods?
posted_time: Post  by firstlady125 » Sat Oct 20, 2007 5:36 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Conception
content: It is not really possible to determine the exact date of conception.  The period dates give us a general idea and that is give or take two weeks since each woman ovulates on her own schedule (not necessarily on day 14 for instance).  The ultrasound can give a pretty accurate picture based on measurement if it is done at the optimal time when accuracy is achieved.  Late in pregnancy it is less accurate.  In the first trimester crown-rump measurement can give a good idea of the gestational age of the fetus.    If everyone had regular, 28 day cycles and always ovulated on day 14 and the woman could remember the exact dates, then it would be easier to know the conception date but there are just too many variables in real life.  Also if a woman got pregnant after having just one sexual encounter (the only one that occurred that month) it would also be easier but there would still be a window of a few days when actual conception might have occurred.  Sperm has a period of viability as does the released egg, so it will vary.  I hope this helps.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Sat Oct 20, 2007 8:14 pm

author: ThreePrinces  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Fri May 04, 2007 5:49 pm
title: Confused about a possible pregnancy.
content: I would not worry too much about early menopause.  Yes it is possible but I think it's more likely that you're just having irregular periods.  If you last had unprotected sex on August 5th (that would put you at approximately cycle day 15) and have had negative pregnancy tests, I really doubt you are pregnant.  SInce your periods are so irregular, your symptoms you are having now COULD be ovulation or they could just be the symptoms that occur during an annovulatory cycle (which it sounds like you may be experiencing.)  I have irregular cycles because I have PCOS.  I am not your classic PCOS though, as I do not have weight problems (I am 110 pounds) or the other "symptoms" routinely associated with the disorder.  But my lab results and ultrasounds have not lied and I have PCOS.  My point is, there are so many different factors that could be the cause of your irregular cycles.  I would seek the advice of a OBGYN as soon as possible.  In order to rule out early menopause, ask for cycle day 3 labs of FSH and Estradiol.  These will help determine a lot of what is going on.  I doubt you are pregnant.
posted_time: Post  by ThreePrinces » Mon Oct 08, 2007 11:30 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: It is possible to have negative pregnancy tests while still being pregnant so having a serum test with your doctor or family planning clinic might be your safest course.  It sounds like an evaluation of your hormones might be in order anyway.  Has your family doctor ever suggested birth control pills as a way to regulate your periods?  If I were you I would schedule a gynecological exam now to check your overall health.  It is possible you could have something else that is causing your distress such as PCOS or thyroid/other endocrine problems.    Also, if you do not already do it, you should be taking a multivitamin during your childbearing years.  This will assure the best outcome if and when you do become pregnant one day.  Meanwhile, consider birth control in some form for future sexual encounters to give you peace of mind.  It's no fun to worry every month about the possibility of an unplanned pregnancy.  Condoms will also help reduce your risk for sexually transmitted infections and these are rampant right now so it doesn't hurt to be safe here.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Cycle Change after miscarriage
content: Hi Momoftwins,  Following a miscarriage it is very common for a woman's cycle to be irregular or change from its previous pattern for a while.  Often it will return to normal but this may take several (meaning >6 in some cases) months.  Regarding your question about ovulation, ovulation is generally thought to occur 14 days before the next period is expected.  With a 28 day cycle this is mid-cycle.  With a 24 day cycle, ovulation would be expected on day 10, slightly earlier than mid-cycle.  Best wishes.

author: ThreePrinces  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Fri May 04, 2007 5:49 pm
title: Is it too soon for an Ultra Sound? have had 7 miscariages
content: I'm not a doctor, but have experience with this.  First of all, I am so sorry to hear about your losses.  I myself have had 4 miscarriages in the midst of 2 years of infertility, and I understand the heartache that comes with such a devastating loss.  Here's the deal:  a pregnancy is not able to be seen until the HCG reaches a certain number.  I cannot recall exactly what that number is, (I think it's over 2000), but it won't be that for about another week.  I can only compare to my IUI baby, and at 18 days past ovulation (so that would be approximately 4 weeks 4 days, somewhere around there), my HCG number was 937.  I had a bleeding episode that day and went to the ER.  They performed an ultrasound and saw...absolutely NOTHING.  There was nothing to be found and the jerk ultrasound tech said to me "You're not pregnant, lady."  Oh yes I was....my HCG did not lie.  (and that baby is now 3 years old.)  With my second and third children, I had ultrasounds around 5.5 weeks where we could see the fetal pole and yolk sac.  Around 6.5 weeks, we saw the heartbeat.  I'm sorry but it's probably just too early to see anything on ultrasound this early.  You need to wait another week or so.  And believe me, I know how hard that is.  Beat of luck!
posted_time: Post  by ThreePrinces » Sat Oct 06, 2007 8:03 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello, I know this can be very frustrating, considering your history, but ThreePrinces is correct and you will need to be patient and give this time.  Early pregnancy tests can sometimes give false negative results and a too-early ultrasound is also not necessarily diagnostic.  There is not much you can do except wait it out.  Hopefully you will have a good outcome this time.    When you do see a doctor, I would recommend your regular OB or family practitioner who is best able to follow your pregnancy all the way through.    Best of luck to you.

title: When did I get Pregnant?
content: Assuming you have regular cycles, I would think the 15th is the most likely date of those you have suggested. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: RE:
content: Spotting is very normal at that stage of early pregnancy.  I would not expect any adverse reaction for the babies as a result of your diet pills, including size.    If you were overweight before becoming pregnant, your gaining only a little weight can still be normal.  You are able to function by using stored body fat.  Your baby gets your nutrients from food, then you rely on the stores.  You should be eating healthy foods and the goal is not to lose weight or even stay the same, but you don't necessarily have to gain very much to still have a healthy baby (babies).  You will probably gain more from this point on, as the babies put on weight with all the body organs formed now.  I do hope you plan to breastfeed your babies to give them the best start in life.  There is nothing better.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 3 mo. Pregnant lots of problems.
content: I can't say exactly what is wrong since that would require an physical examination, history and possibly lab work.  But, you should get in for prenatal care as soon as possible.  If you need a referral, call a local health department or hospital referral service.  If you have insurance coverage, check with their customer service or member handbook.    Pregnancy can be a time of many changes in your body that are perfectly normal but only your doctor can determine what is going on for you.  Getting early prenatal care has been shown to improve the outcome for pregnancy.  In the meantime, try to get adequate rest, do not become dehydrated (drink lots of water), get moderate exercise with walking, eat healthy foods and avoid junk food, take a multi vitamin every day, and stop any bad health habits such as alcohol, tobacco, and street drugs.    Good luck and best wishes for you and your baby.

content: Hello,  Wondering if someone could help me decipher some wording on my surgical report from my first cesarean.  (I have had 3 total, and hope for 1 more.)  It says toward the end of the report:  "The uterus was closed using one layer of #1 chromic suture.  The right half of the incision was a little ragged.  It was imbricated with a second layer of #1 chromic suture.  At this time, there was good hemostasis from this layer."  My question is this:  Does it sound to anyone like the doctor only double sutured the right half (that was ragged) or the whole thing?  So is the left half only closed with one layer of sutures but the right half is closed with two?  Or did he do 2 layers on the whole thing?  I'm thinking \it sounds like he did the whole thing with 2 layers, but I'm unsure as the wording is really not very clear.  This cesarean was an emergency cesarean performed almost 7 years ago in another state.  My OB at the time did not perform this c-section, a doctor whom I had never met did it because it was an emergency and there was no time to call my doctor.  My oldest son almost lost his life, and the c-section saved his life.  This is actually very important to me, to know if it was double sutured or not.  I would love to have another child and have the blessing of my current obstetrician.  I am terrified, however, of a placenta accreta even though I have no history of placental problems.  I have read that having your uterus double sutured after a cesarean lowers the risk of an accreta.  My last 2 cesareans were definitely double sutured, as it is noted in my surgical reports.  Thank you if anyone can help!
posted_time: Post  by ThreePrinces » Fri Oct 05, 2007 10:40 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Question about surgical report (c-section)
content: Hello, I can certainly understand your concern and, while having the double sutures is an extra measure, it certainly is no guarantee for a problem-free next pregnancy anyway.  There are risks involved with future pregnancies following a c section and for this reason I would never recommend doing c sections on demand (i.e. no medical need or indication).  But the vast majority of pregnancies following either a planned or emergency cesarean delivery result in a healthy baby.  You do not need to worry based on the report.  These are usually never even reviewed in subsequent pregnancies.  If it was a big concern, all doctors would require this information to base a decision on.  It is not that relevant.    If you are concerned about placenta accreta, the best thing to do would be to have a high level ultrasound done during your next pregnancy.  Even accreta (very rare) can have a good birth outcome if the doctor knows about it prior to delivery.  This worry should not prevent you from having another child if you desire to do it.  It is even possible you could have a vaginal delivery (VBAC) if things look good at the time of labor.  The risk of rupture is EXTREMELY low.  Thank goodness we have the ability for emergency c sections when they truly are needed, as with your first child.    Trust your OB who has given his/her blessing for your next pregnancy.  You have had a good spacing for healing and there is no reason one would expect any greater complications than anyone has when contemplating pregnancy.  Good luck!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: taking progesterone with all pregnancies?
content: Hi, Not necessarily.  There is no way to know if the progesterone is what made the difference but if your levels were low it was certainly good advice.  Perhaps your doctor will check the levels next time as well;  if normal, you may not need to, but that would be a call your doctor and you will need to make at the time.  There is no guarantee you can avoid a miscarriage, even taking the medication.  Most miscarriages occur for unknown reasons, perhaps because the fetus is not developing properly.  Progesterone cannot prevent such an event from occurring; it can only boost your levels to the normal range to give you the best possible chance.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: pregnancy and a period?
content: Hi, Your friend is not likely pregnant.  The day before the period is generally a very safe day (not 100% but close).  Having gotten her period on schedule, she should be able to relax on this one.  Your situation is also unlikely since you have been on birth control (I assume the pill or something similar), assuming you have been taking the pill faithfully. posted_time: Post  by Lowkie » Sat Sep 22, 2007 12:12 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Getting pregnant again
content: Hi Lowkie,  The rhogam shot helps prevent the mother's body from forming antibodies against Rh + blood that the baby may have.    This should not affect the ability to conceive.  If the rhogam was unsuccessful at preventing the formation of the antibodies it can cause significant problems for the baby after it begins making red blood cells several weeks afer conception.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Sex after a tubal
content: First off, I don't think you did anything to hurt yourself by having sex when you did.    The abdomen has many organs and problems can arise in any of them.  This does not mean cancer.  There are other conditions of the bowel, the pancreas, the liver, the gallbladder, the uterus, appendix, etc. that can act up at times for various reasons.  You need to get this checked out so you can have relief.  You could have something like irritable bowel syndrome causing the pain and gas.  Menstrual irregularities are generally hormonally caused and this may be happening following the birth of your baby when hormones are getting back to normal.  At any rate, seeing your doctor is the best plan and it may take a work up to find the problem, so be patient and make sure you let your doctor know all the symptoms you are having.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: drinking while pregnant
content: You sound like a very caring and responsible mom who wants to do the best thing for her baby.  That is very commendable.  Of course if you can quit these habits at any time, even this late, it will help your health and improve your baby's chances.  Second hand smoke has also been shown to be very harmful, especially to babies.  These would be good reasons to get help through tobacco control programs such as with your local health department or American Lung Association, etc.  There are good programs to help you stop smoking and to stay smoke free.  You will probably never have more motivation to do it than when you are having a baby.  As for damage already done, it is unknown what level of alcohol use is relatively safe.  Of course ideal is none.  But, there are plenty of examples of perfectly healthy children born after such binging episodes as you describe.  It is believed that quantity does play a role here so continual drinking will definitely increase the odds of harm.  There is also a genetic component and birth defects may result from a combination of genetic makeup or predisposition to certain problems, and exposure to toxins, especially in large amounts.  The best thing you can do now is concentrate on getting you well.  Alcoholism affects children in many ways so join AA and make a commitment for your baby's future.  Stop smoking to be an example to your children as well as to decrease risk.  You can be the link that breaks the chain of family alcohol use.  This will be tremendous for your child.  There is nothing you can do now about the past but there is plenty of reason to expect your baby will be OK - there is a certain amount of luck and/or divine intervention involved.  Some babies have problems even without toxin exposure.  Your baby might have an increased risk but that does NOT mean the baby will definitely have problems.  Congratulations on your desire to be a good mom.  I wish you the best.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Sun Sep 16, 2007 3:35 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Miscarriage
content: You should be fine to try again right away.  Had you carried the baby to term, you would likely be advised to wait a little bit to give your body a chance to recover but miscarriage, which is very common, should not require such a recovery period.  Many women achieve pregnancy right after miscarriage and of course this does help east the pain of the miscarriage, giving you something to look forward to again.    It will be easier to determine when you would be fertile once your periods begin in earnest, but if you just proceed with your normal sexual activity (Every other day would be good) the chances are you will become pregnant again.  Good luck!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: It is possible you can ovulate before you have your next period so pregnancy could be possible.  If you want to avoid it you should use contraception from the outset.  The abnormal shape of your uterus can contribute to pregnancy problems but I would not expect it in connection with early miscarriage loss.  More likely to be a problem later and there is an increased risk for a breech baby, necessitating a c section delivery.  I'm sure your doctor will discuss any complications he or she may foresee.    Repeated pregnancy loss is certainly heartbreaking and I can understand you being a bit gun-shy at this point.  And, in the majority of cases, the cause of the miscarriage is unknown.  Good luck in your efforts.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Update
content: That could very likely have been your first period following the miscarriage.  Trying again should be fine whenever you are ready as long as you are in good overall health.  If you are already anemic, it would be wise to wait and get your iron levels up but early miscarriage does not usually take much of a toll on your body (more on your emotions).    If you had carried the baby nearly to term, the advice would be to wait a little while but they have not seen an increase of problems with closely spaced pregnancies in this situation (miscarriage) so we have no reason to suggest waiting as long as you are emotionally ready.  To be sure your body is in good condition, continue to exercise, take a multi-vitamin containing at least 400 mcg folic acid (or folate), eat a healthy diet and avoid any bad habits like smoking, drinking, and drugs.  Your fertile period is likely to begin next week, assuming ovulation has resumed and this was indeed a period you had on August 2-4.  But, don't be discouraged if it takes a few months to get pregnant.  Sometimes it occurs effortlessly, but often it happens on a schedule outside your control so patience is in order.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: The test is measuring hormone levels which can stay in range for a few days.  Having intercourse on those days will increase your chances of pregnancy.  The predictor is most effective when you use afternoon urine (not first morning) and you should try to check about the same time each day that you monitor.  You can also monitor your vaginal secretions.  Women naturally have an increase around the time of ovulation.  If you noticed secretions yesterday or today (on any given day, monitor both two days), there is a high likelihood of ovulation.    Some pink discharge after sex is nothing to be concerned about.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Preeclampsia?
content: The hallmark sign of preeclampsia is high blood pressure so I can confidently answer no here.    You should discuss these symptoms with your doctor but it does not look like preeclampsia at all.    I believe you are referencing sugar in the urine, which could be an early warning sign of other problems such as gestational diabetes.  Your doctor will probably order a glucose test in a few weeks to screen for that.  You are probably confusing this with protein in the urine, which can be related to preeclampsia (along with high blood pressure) but would not be related to what you ate.  Good luck with your pregnancy.  If you are concerned about symptoms and cannot reach your doctor, go to your hospital's labor and delivery unit to be checked.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Intercourse first day of period...
content: Because we do not know exactly when a woman will ovulate, there is literally no "100% safe" days when you definitely would not get pregnant.   But, with that disclaimer, if your period occurred right at the time you had intercourse (it sounds like within hours) it is very unlikely you would be pregnant from that encounter.  If I understand the time frame correctly, it would be too soon for the bleeding to be due to implantation, unless you had actually become pregnant a few weeks prior to this "period" and it actually is implantation bleeding.  If that is the case, a home pregnancy test would be able to determine.   Use first morning urine and follow directions as to when it should be "read."

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: 3rd Mo of Clomid No period
content: The pregnancy test measures the level of the hormone hCG and people vary in how much of this may show up at what time.  Most people can get an accurate test within a couple of days of the missed period but some women's levels do not rise as quickly.  They may still be pregnant but the test doesn't detect it yet.  We advise repeating a negative test after a week if there is still no period.  Be sure to follow the directions exactly for best results (first morning urine, read promptly, etc.).  Good luck.

title: Aprrox. 5 weeks preg. Hurting badly.
content: Hi Nescrew,  Your pain sounds much more severe than typical.  I would strongly recommend that you see a doctor. If you have an attack of pain or severe shortness of breath that does not rapidly resolve you should be seen in the emergency room. content: Depending on your area you may be able to stop in to the local health department.  They may be able to direct you.  Another option may be to ask the local emergency room staff. Ok, so my mom went through fertility treatments to get pregnant, and about two weeks after they did the embryo transfer they tested her and she was in fact pregnant, with an hcg level of 16. Three days later (day 17), it had only risen to 24, so they were worried it might end up being a miscarriage. Then, two days later (day 19), it rose to 59. Two days after that, 21 days after the embryo transfer, it rose to 176. Then, three days later (day 24), it was 756. Because it was rising so quickly, they actually thought that my mom might have twins, that one attatched later than the other or something to that extent. However, my mom had been experiencing light bleeding and so they decided to have her come in again, two days later (day 26), and the level had dropped to 550 something. Two days later, the level was 394.  (day 28)  This was friday.  It is now twenty minutes from monday, and my mom has not been taking progesterone shots because they told her to stop.  Did they do the right thing?  Do you think my mom may have had twins, and if so, don't you find it strange that she would have miscarried both at almost the same time?  Is it possible for the mother to miscarry one twin but to sucessfully deliver the second, and most importantly of all, what should be happening with the hcg level if that happens.  I know this is probably too late already but I just wanted to understand...thanks in advance...
posted_time: Post  by Jaime » Sun Aug 12, 2007 10:44 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Is it possible to miscarry one twin but deliver the second?
content: Thanks for your concern about your mother's pregnancy.  You have good questions.  I would, however, caution you to be careful in trying to interpret the numbers.  The "normal" levels are always a range and they vary hugely between women.  Rapidly rising hormones can result from multiples or even from a molar pregnancy, that would never have resulted in a fetus anyway.  Yes, it is possible to miscarry one twin, but deliver the other successfully.  It is also more common to miscarry twins than singletons (higher risk).  Your mother is currently in the "wait and see" period since anything could happen, yet there is little you can do to intercede.  As for the progesterone shots, it is difficult to say what "should" be done from here.  Her doctor obviously knows her situation best and wants a good outcome so I think she can follow the doctor's instructions with confidence.  Use of progesterone in the early weeks to prevent miscarriage is still under some investigation and it has been suggested that it may not actually help the outcome anyway.  There is a question about whether the decreased progesterone levels is the body's natural response to an inevitable pregnancy loss rather than low levels being the cause of the miscarriage.  If your mom is still pregnant with one fetus, the hormone levels will continue to rise, but not as fast as with twins.  At around 12 weeks the maturing placenta takes over the role of producing the hormones to support pregnancy.  I hope this helps.  We wish your family the best possible outcome.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Mon Aug 13, 2007 11:50 am

author: Jaime  Guest Posts: 8 Joined: Sun Aug 12, 2007 10:36 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi.  Thanks for the quick response.  You cleared up quite a few things.  Abot the progesterone shots, however.  The reason my mother was taking them was because her normal levels were low (from the very start, although the shots were able to bring them up to a normal level), but the doctor attributed this to the fact that this was not a "natural" pregnancy, considering that fifteen eggs were taken out of my mother's body, fertilized, and the best ones (2) chosen to be implanted a few days later. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: The placenta, once functioning, takes over the job of sustaining the pregnancy, so the additional progesterone is not needed for very long in this capacity.  It is needed at the beginning so if levels are low, artificially adding them can make up the difference.  But, once the placenta can do the job, that's the way it should be.  Again, best wishes!

My husband says that "we just need to do it and hope to be the best we can be, because if we kept thinking about the negative, and if the rest of the world thought the same, nobody would have any children!" posted_time: Post  by kandy » Fri Aug 17, 2007 11:41 am

author: Jaime  Guest Posts: 8 Joined: Sun Aug 12, 2007 10:36 pm
title: Baby or not?
content: I can't help you with your other two questions...But I can offer my advice for your last one...  3) This question is more general than medical.  My husband and I can financially support a child. But what's stopping us is the fear of first having a "bad/uncontrollable..." child, and second, of not being 24/7 emotionally/mentally available.Well.  First of all, there are no guarantees in children.  There are kids from upper class, well to do, very well educated, etc etc families who fall into the wrong crowds, and end up screwing up their lives, and there are kids who do just the opposite.  No matter how much you put it off, that simple fact will never change.  The only thing you can do, is do your best.  Treat your child like you would want to be treated in their place, try to anticipate possible issues/problems by putting yourself in his/her place, etc.  The end result may not be perfect, but as human beings, nothing we do is.  All we can do is try our best, cross our fingers, and hope.  Also, keep in mind that although in the end, a lot comes down to the child, the way you raise him/her does make a huge impact on his/her behavior, personality, etc.  Many psychologists agree that behaviors and personality quirks are learned from people with whom children interact with.  So if your child is doing something wrong, keep in mind that sometimes it may require you to look at yourself and ask whether or not you are setting the best possible example.  And this is coming from an only child who spent a decent amount of time alone...  Your kid/s will not expect you to be there for them 24/7.  In fact, they probably won't want you there for them 24/7, especially when they get older.  However, what is important is that you are always within reach, and that you are around when they need you.  Working is something that we all have to do, and juggling family, work, and friends can be difficult at times...but we really don't have any other alternatives, do we?  So my question is: Do most people have kids after having clearly thought it thru, or do they just "do it"? Because I'm affraid I'll never be ready to conceive.. From what I understand, it is a combination.  Some people, generally those who like to have everything "under their control" hesitate to bring children into their lives because they represent a possibly unpredictable factor in their set-in-stone lives.  The only thing I can say is that if you want to have kids, then you shouldn't delay.  My parents wanted a second child, but by the time they got around to trying, my mother was 40, my father 50, and they had to resort to in vitro fertilization.  And after two attempts, and thousands of dollars spent, it looks like my mother miscarried (on the second attempt.  The first one did not even implant.)  My point being, don't wait around forever.  Before you know it, it might be too late.  Obviously, make sure you are reading for a child...  Meaning that you need to be able to afford not just food, but clothes and diapers and perhaps some kind of nanny to help you out.  And you will want to be living in a location suitable for kids as well...  But once you have that done, all you can really do is close your eyes and take the plunge.  Hope I helped..
posted_time: Post  by Jaime » Fri Aug 17, 2007 8:11 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Baby or not?
content: I do not know of any way to determine if you are actually physically capable of having a child unless you were to do fertility testing and I would not invest that kind of money, time and stress if I hadn't yet actively tried naturally (i.e. using no birth control and having regular intercourse).  Sometimes we over-analyze things and my experience is that we never can accurately predict how we will handle something before we actually are there.  We often surprise ourselves and see we have strengths we never would have thought we had when faced with challenges.  If you think you would like to be parents, trust your instinct and your ability to adapt to the necessary changes and personality interactions that will take place.  Parenthood can be difficult, but amazingly rewarding.  There are aspects of it that nobody could have ever told you about (both positive and negative I'm sure).  But I personally would not have missed it for the world.  Good luck.

content: I am 27 years old and I recently had my wisdom teeth taken out. It has been almost two weeks ago. I was sadated during the procedure. Last night I took a pregnancy test and it was positive. Is there any chance I could of her my baby if I was pregnant when the procdure was done?

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: wisdom teeth taken out while pregnant
content: While there is no guarantee about this, the chances are very good that your baby will be fine.  Many pregnant women have to undergo surgery under general anesthesia and they do well.  Keep in mind that with every pregnancy there is a 2-5% chance of a birth defect occurring no matter what you do or don't do so some things cannot be helped and are usually genetic in origin, rather than caused by preventable exposure.  Also, there is greater risk with prolonged and frequent exposures as opposed to one-time events such as surgery.  Since I don't know where you live, I don't have a local agency number but you can check with the Organization for Teratology Information online at http://www.otispregnancy.org  for more information.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Prolapsed Uterus and Pregnancy
content: Surgical intervention can help to raise the uterus up in the pelvis (suspension) to help you to have a healthy baby.  This procedure might be sacrospinous uterosacral ligament fixation.  A pessary is also often employed in an effort to hold things in their proper place.   Sometimes the doctor can even do physical maneuvers to move it up a bit.  Once the uterus grows large enough that it can no longer protrude (18 to 20 weeks), it is likely that it will stay in place.    There is some increased risk of preterm birth and/or bladder problems because the organs have shifted out of their usual position, so a pregnancy would be considered high risk and you should have a competent obstetrician caring for you.  There may even be activity restriction - perhaps bedrest- to help assure a good outcome.    Being in the hands of a good doctor will be your best chance for success here.  Best of luck to you.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Am on the pill, skipped my week break and now my period late
content: A delayed period would not be cause for alarm as you have manipulated your cycles a bit hormonally.  There is nothing wrong with this.  It is not necessary to have monthly periods and some oral contraceptives are designed for you to only have four periods a year.  I suspect your period will begin shortly.  If not, a pregnancy test would be indicated and should be accurate at least by a week after your period should have started.    Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Risk of pregnancy for missed pills?
content: If I am understanding the time frame here it sounds like you were having sex during the time of the month you would be least likely to be fertile.  The average ovulation day would be day 14 when counting from the first day of the period but women vary considerably so we usually consider fertile days to be 8 through 19.  Unprotected sexual intercourse during those days would be the most risky for pregnancy.  It sounds like you were within this safer time frame and by using "withdrawal" you do improve your odds.  While this is not a reliable method of birth control by itself, in conjunction with the pill and "safe" days, I would not be very worried if it were me.    I'm sure you will feel more comfortable when you get your next period and there are always exceptions, but if I make a guess I would say I do not expect pregnancy from this.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: I am assuming you are talking about light, painless bleeding, rather than heavy.  Yes, this can continue for a while if you have a subchorionic hemorrhage.  Your risk for other complications are a bit higher, but these things do sometimes heal over and you can go on to have a healthy pregnancy.    Of course you are worried.  Unfortunately it's one of those things where you have to just wait and see what happens since you can't do anything about it.  Just take it easy with light activity, avoiding strenuous, physical lifting, etc.  This is just to prevent aggravating the situation.    But if you have strong cramping and/or heavy bleeding  call your doctor.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Can u misscary w/ little or no pain
content: It is not unusual to have spotting and/or cramping in early pregnancy.  At this point it could go either way.  Many women have implantation bleeding and then go on to have a healthy pregnancy.  But, you are in the high risk time frame for miscarriage as well. It is believed that as many as 25% of pregnancies end in miscarriages - some before the woman even knows she is pregnant.  Unfortunately there is not much you can do to prevent miscarriage from happening.  Most likely it is a defect or placenta problem that doesn't allow the baby to develop normally so mother nature takes care of things, heartbreaking though that is for many women.  So, it's a "wait and see" kind of thing.  It doesn't hurt to take it easy and not do anything to aggravate the situation, but don't stress too much.  Good chance things will be fine.    Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Could I be Pregnant?
content: As you know, pregnancy is certainly likely, given the symptoms you describe and many women experience some light bleeding (periods) even when pregnant.  You have not indicated if pregnancy is a welcome condition or not.  If you are sexually active and not desiring pregnancy, I hope you will discuss contraceptive options with your health care provider.  Also, if you do not use birth control, knowing you could be pregnant at any time, it would be especially important for you to maintain good health and nutrition, including taking a multi-vitamin containing folic acid (400 mcg).  Since pregnancy could occur without your knowledge, being in good health will help ensure a healthy baby.  It would also be wise to avoid any unhealthy habits such as smoking and alcohol.  Since you have a history of low hCG levels in pregnancy, you should see your doctor to determine pregnancy.  There are other ways to do this through examination and/or ultrasound technology.    As for other causes of your symptoms - mostly they would likely be hormonal in nature, so once again, a doctor's consultation would be recommended.  There is also the possibility these symptoms have other causes but the cluster does suggest something related to the reproductive system.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Medication while you are pregnant
content: I would not worry too much about the medications.  Pregnant women often require even strong pain relievers that are considered safe in pregnancy when they have a condition that indicates their use.    In the ideal world, we would recommend that you take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as the first line in pain relievers but others are considered safe when necessary.  Usually we advise you to stay away from aspirin and ibuprofen because your blood clotting could be affected.    Whenever you take medications in pregnancy it is wise to consult with the doctor or nurse midwife who is caring for you.

title: [no title]
content: I have a garden bed made of pressure treated lumber.  Are the vegetables harvested from this area safe for pregnant women?  I know there are toxins in pressure treated lumber, but don't know if that would have any effect on the foods.  Thank you
posted_time: Post  by smoozi » Tue Aug 07, 2007 2:26 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Food Toxins & Pregnancy
content: From extoxnet.orst.edu: "Pressure treated lumber containing arsenic, copper and chromium (CCA) may be used safely in food gardens. The arsenic, copper and chromium do leach into the soil over time, however, and may be transported into food crops grown close to the treated lumber... With time, small amounts of arsenic, chromium, and copper will leach out to the surrounding soil. Soil migration is limited, however, depending on the soil type. Although arsenic, chromium, and copper are commonly found in all soils, the levels surrounding treated wood, up to a distance of approximately 6 inches away, will likely exceed normal background levels of these elements. Therefore, because some garden plants will accumulate these elements, do not plant close to treated wood. Alternatives to CCA treated wood include the heartwood of cedar or redwood."  I hope this answers your question.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Dealing w/ heat
content: This is a very normal response to pregnancy for most women, especially in the summer.  It's like you have a little "heater" inside.  Just usual cooling tricks are about all you can do.  Use fans, light, loose clothing - try summery dresses instead of pants.  Take cool baths or showers and when you take walks, don't avoid the sprinklers you pass.  Drink lots of cold water, popsicles, etc.  Try to take advantage of the early morning and later evening hours so you can avoid the heat of the day for activities and errands.  This will change once you deliver.  Hormones and blood supply are the main culprits, along with extra body weight.  Sorry I can't give you a magic solution here.  I wish I could.

title: bleeding after labor
content: When periods resume following childbirth, they can be quite irregular.  Typically they are absent during the breastfeeding period. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Pregnant - worried it could be ectopic and no Dr will see me
content: I understand your concern.  The good news is that you are not experiencing pain, which is typical of an ectopic pregnancy.    While you are at increased risk, it is still quite rare but these are symptoms you should watch for:   - colicky, crampy pain with tenderness low in the abdomen, typically one side but can radiate. - heavy bleeding - nausea and vomiting - dizziness or weakness - shoulder pain - feeling of rectal pressure.  Keep in mind, every woman does not experience all these symptoms but any of them could be associated.  It is considered an emergency condition so if you feel pain, you should have it evaluated at once.  Ligament stretching pain can also occur normally so it can be hard to distinguish.  When in doubt, check it out!  In the absence of symptoms, you should be fine to wait out the week to see the doctor as scheduled.  Usually by the 8th week of pregnancy the danger has passed.

title: [no title]
content: 23, male   i have a question about my daughter.  my daughter has light brown hair and light blue eyes.  with somewhat darker skin then her mother.   and i have very dark brown hair with black hair and dark skin.  her mother has has green eyes with blond hair and very light skin.   my question is my daughter has virtually no features of mine and looks exactly like her mother... with blue eyes  and brown.   i was always under the impression that brown is a dominant trait....   should i be worried that she might not be my child?
posted_time: Post  by user2009 » Wed Jul 25, 2007 12:37 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: question about my child
content: I would not worry based on your information.  Many children will look strikingly like only one parent.  It is confusing when you think of dark being dominant but that is not always the case.  The genes come in pairs and each parent sends a dominant and recessive gene for eye color, for example.  If you send a recessive gene for blue eyes and your wife sends a recessive gene for blue eyes, your child can have blue eyes, even if both of you had brown eyes.  This is because of the two genes you received from your parents, brown WAS dominant of the two and so you have brown, but if you did get that recessive blue gene for eye color, when you pass the gene for eye color on to your daughter, you could send EITHER the dominant (brown) OR the recessive (blue).  Then, if you daughter doesn't get a dominant brown from your wife either, she has blue eyes, which came from the two blue (recessive) genes that she got from each parent.     I hope this simplified explanation makes sense.  Genetics is truly a fascinating subject.  A great-grandmother's red hair could also suddenly appear, even though neither parent (or even grandparents) have red hair.  Traveling up the family tree can shed some light on these mysteries.  Enjoy your child!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Can hemorrhaging during delivery cause later complications?
content: Without knowing the exact cause of your hemorrhage, it is difficult to say if this is something to be expected again.  However, each woman who delivers a child should be viewed as "at risk" for this and should be managed carefully in the third stage of labor (placenta delivery).  Be sure the staff at the hospital are aware of your history when you are admitted so they will be extra vigilant about this.    Scarring in the uterus can make a difference in placental attachment, possibly increasing your risk of a low-lying placenta.  But, aside from this I know of no reason why this should be a concern.  Since you didn't have a C/S you should not have to be especially concerned about the scar being a problem.    Good luck in your efforts to conceive.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Do you think I am Pregnant?
content: I certainly understand your anxiety about miscarriage and your frustration with your atypical pregnancy signs.  Unfortunately there is little that can be done to prevent miscarriage so your purpose in getting this information early is probably mostly for curiosity.   If  you have a regular OB/GYN doctor to see, you could ask for an appointment.  Of course they will ask for your last menstrual period date to determine estimated due date.  Explain your history and anxiety about this so they understand why you need a doctor's evaluation to confirm pregnancy.  You should be able to determine pregnancy by ultrasound quite early but this is no guarantee that there will not be a miscarriage as occurs in approximately 25% of cases, most often by 12 weeks.    In the meantime, make sure you are getting a good mulitvitamin containing at least 400 mcg folate or folic acid, eat a healthy diet, stop any bad habits such as smoking, alcohol or drugs so you will be in your best condition for a healthy baby.  Good luck.

title: Have IUD - Pregnancy Symtpoms - VERY RARE
content: Rarer things have happened.  If you are pregnant with the IUD in place you need to see your doctor as this can cause complications. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Also...
content: Hi Beckie,  Of course pregnancy is a possibility and everyone's symptoms vary so this could be the course of yours.  You can do a home pregnancy test around one week after you would expect your period to occur.  Be sure to read the instructions and follow them exactly, using first morning urine and reading the results right away, in order to get the most accurate result.    A tampon would not dislodge anything relating to pregnancy, including the mucus plug.  Mucus is normally present and varies in amount from day to day, so it is likely just the normal discharge.  There also tends to be an increase in vaginal discharge near ovulation.   Let us know if you have other questions.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Loss of pregnancy Symptoms
content: Yes, it is possible that your body can adjust to these hormones in a way that allows you to experience pregnancy without the nausea, even when you had hyperemesis in previous pregnancies.  Whether or not this is the case here is yet to be seen since it is early.  Basically, it could go either way but if miscarriage is imminent you will likely experience symptoms soon such as cramping and/or bleeding.  You're in a "wait and see" stage because there's really nothing you can do to affect the outcome anyway.   Best wishes for success here.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Generally, if you have been exercising prior to pregnancy and are already accustomed to this, you can continue as before.  In the case of a threatened miscarriage, doctors usually advise caution and reduced activity, though there is no guarantee it will make a difference.  It seems that most cases of miscarriage are from a problem with the developing fetus. - something even strict bedrest won't change.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Taking vitamin/mineral supplements while pregnant
content: This should be OK for you to resume the supplements as long as you do not take excessive amounts.  It is important for you to be healthy in pregnancy and in preparation for delivery so if the additional magnesium and potassium does stabilize you this way, it would be good to resume.  Generally the recommended daily for Magnesium in pregnancy is 350 to 400 mg. Consider the amount already in your vitamin and that should give you an idea.  The primary side effect of excessive amounts is diarrhea and no effects with the babies have been noted.   Of course studies with high levels of supplements are not available so it's good to stay within the recommended amounts unless your doctor advises otherwise.  As for safety in general, these are naturally occurring substances (as you know, are present in foods as well) so there is not a great concern for using in pregnancy.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Nuchal fold Thickening
content: Hi, I would like to explain a little bit about this screening in hopes that it will somewhat answer your question even though I am not able to tell you exactly what it "should" be at a given point in time.  Screening tests determine risk but do not actually diagnose a problem.  Because of this, telling you what the measurement should be would only say what measurement would put it into an average or a better than average chance of occurring in this pregnancy.Even if the measurement increases your risk, that still doesn't mean your baby has Down Syndrome.  So, if the typical risk, given your age were one in 250, that still means that in 249 of that total the baby would NOT have it.   The nuchal cord marker might increase the risk, say to one in 125.  Still 124 to one that the baby does not have it.    What I'm saying is the fact that the number may be high for nuchal fold measurement does not indicate that the baby is abnormal - just that the odds are a little greater.  This helps people to decide if they want to pursue additional screening tests (which come with a little more risk) that are more definitive.  In same cases this eases a person's mind and in other cases the abnormal screening just causes unnecessary stress since there are many false positives where the parents worry a lot but then delivery a perfectly healthy baby.    Since I am not expert in neonatology and ultrasound measurement interpretation I cannot give you the figures you are asking for but I hope this somewhat clarifies the screening to help you understand the results you have been given.  The screening is done at the time in the pregnancy when it is most likely to be helpful so a later measurement may not even correlate in the same way.  Again, it is only with more extensive testing CVS or amniocentesis you find actual occurrence - the screening is merely statistical risk assessment.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Nuchal fold thickening
content: I understand your frustration, Regina,  I guess the big question for me would be why would you get the amnio?  If you would not abort anyway, the slightly increased risk of miscarriage may not be worth it and you could watch for additional soft signs of Down's (or lack) which might satisfy your need for that information well enough.  If you would definitely abort a baby with such a defect, it would probably be worth the risk to get this firm information.     Some people choose to do this so they will be prepared in the event that they have a child with such a handicap and want a firm answer about it in advance.    One reliable source, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, MO, reports equal to or greater than 6 mm as the optimal threshold for greatest predictability in the 14-18 week timeframe.  (PubMed reported: Am J Obstet Gynecol. 1994 Nov;171(5):1282-6.  I hope this eases your mind somewhat - I think it would for me if I were in your place.  Good luck and please let us know how things go for you. Debbie

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hello, I would agree with Debbie that the risk of the amniocentesis may not be worth the benefits.  If there are concerns about heart issues they should be able to see the heart extremely well with a level 3 ultrasound.    If there are concerns, a pediatric cardiologist trained in fetal echocardiography can also evaluate the baby.  I would ask for clarification from your obstetrician about why they would want to do the amniocentesis since I can't think of anything about they heart they would learn from the amnio that they cannot get from an ultrasound.  Also, keep in mind that all our screening tests for Down syndrome before pregnancy are really just that-screening tests.  They are in no way 100% accurate.  If you needed to know if Down syndrome was present for sure an amniocentesis is really the only way.    In fact, most of the time, when a screening test indicates a possible case of Down syndrome the baby is normal.  The tests are made this way so they don't miss cases but at the expense of producing more false positives.  Best wishes.

I did not miss any pills and I take them all within 1-2 hours of 8 am.  My withdrawal week started Monday and now, on Thurs still no period.  I have all the signs of PMS...but no period. posted_time: Post  by jbubs » Thu Jul 05, 2007 2:18 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Pregnancy is possible.  If your period does not start by the time you are supposed to start your next pack I would recommend that you take a pregnancy test.    If it does start, you have two options.  You can start your next pack when you normally would have or wait until the first Sunday after starting (depending on which you prefer).    If you do not start by the time you are due to take your next pill I would recommend that you start taking them and take a pregnancy test.  Taking the pills during the first few weeks of pregnancy is not dangerous to the baby.  This way, if you are not pregnant you are not off track.    Some irregularity like this is common during the first few cycles on a new pill.  Best wishes.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Nicole23wa, I can appreciate that you do not have insurance at this time, but I believe you have enough unpleasant symptoms at this time to warrant a closer evaluation by a doctor.  Of concern are:  over due menses coupled with low back pain and general feelings of illness.  I am concerned about the bursts of hot and sick feelings, the tiredness, the stronger body smells.  There are different diseases that can give you all these symptoms. PID is one of them: Pelvic inflammatory disease. Another can be simply a urinary tract infection. And there are others. It would be in your best interest to present to the local urgent care center or emergency room, or local health clinic (in the US) where they can set up payment options or even a sliding scale based on income. The doctor at these facilities can run tests that will determine why you feel so sick, and then give you treatment options.  I think it would be well worth the time and money to find out while it is still early.  Sometimes waiting too long can cause further complications!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi, Yes, it is very confusing.  The reason you have to find other sources for information about this such as teratology organizations, is because medications are not tested in pregnant or breastfeeding women. Therefore, the manufacturers cannot claim safety so they state "do not take when pregnant or nursing" and this covers them.  But, the truth is, many medications are considered safe in pregnancy so you really have to talk with the doctor or someone in hi office and let them know you have the photos.  When it comes to package inserts, this can be very deceiving because even when they are found to be safe in pregnancy, the labeling does not change in the USA.    I would feel confident about Metformun.

author: Dr. A. Rajput  Medical Doctor Posts: 74 Joined: Fri Apr 11, 2003 10:16 pm Gender: Male Location: India  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Rajput       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: As far as possible, its always better to avoid fetus to drug exposure (even though it has not been proven to be teratogenic) during pregnancy. So if you can switch over to a drug which won't cross placental barrier, it will avoid any untoward effects, if any.  Its a routine practice in most of the countries to swich over to insulin during pregnancy for a simple reason that insulin doesn't cross placental barrier.   I'd like to post a relevant para from a pharmacological book:- In summary, although the use of metformin may be beneficial for decreasing the incidence of fetal and/or newborn morbidity and mortality in developing countries where the proper use of insulin is problematic, insulin is still the treatment of choice for this disease. Moreover, insulin, unlike metformin, does not cross the placenta and, thus, eliminates the additional concern that the drug therapy itself is adversely affecting the fetus. Carefully prescribed insulin therapy will provide better control of the mother's blood glucose, thereby preventing the fetal and neonatal complications that occur with this disease. High maternal glucose levels, as may occur in diabetes mellitus, are closely associated with a number of maternal and fetal adverse effects, including fetal structural anomalies if the hyperglycemia occurs early in gestation. To prevent this toxicity, most experts, including the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, recommend that insulin be used for types I and II diabetes occurring during pregnancy and, if diet therapy alone is not successful, for gestational diabetes  - Drugs in Pregnacy and Lactation, 6th edition: Gerald G Briggs BPharm, Roger K Freeman MD, Sumner J Yaffe MD

author: NikkyLeClair  Guest Posts: 45 Joined: Mon Jan 24, 2005 12:56 pm
title: Tubal reversals
content: I got my tubes tied when I was 25, because I was having a lap anyways for endometriosis.  I regretted it soon after and now know I want more children.  What are possible options for getting pregnant?  I know tubal reversals aren't covered by insurance, so what is their success rate?
posted_time: Post  by NikkyLeClair » Tue Jun 12, 2007 10:44 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi, You didn't give much information about your present circumstances and this can make a difference in your success for pregnancy.    You mention that you were 25 when you had your tubes tied but your age now is one factor to consider.  Women over 40 should discuss their personal chances with their health care provider before seeking the reversal because other factors will affect fertility besides the tubal.    Another important factor relates to the type of procedure you had.  Women with the best chances had a preocedure which involved removal of a small section of the fallopian tubes or those whose tubal involved clips or rings around the tubes.    The overall success rate varies considerable, from 20 to 70 % of those desiring reversal and pregnancy.     It would probably be good to get a copy of your surgical report to take to the surgeon who would be doing the reversal so they could deternine if yours is one that would be likely to be successful.  Size of the tube also makes a difference and this is why a small missing segment will be easier than one which took a larger segment.    The other option for you would be In Vitro fertilization.  In this procedure your egg is fertilized with your husband's sperm outside the body and then transplanted into the uterus.    Good luck.

title: had linine in uterus removed can i still get pregnant?
content: In jan. i had surgery to remove the lining in my uterus and my husband and I want to have another baby is this possible? I am 30 years old and have 2 children 3 and 11 years old.
posted_time: Post  by eafrench » Tue Jun 12, 2007 2:32 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: If what you had was an endometrial ablation, I would say you are not likely to be able to bear another child.  This procedure is damaging to the uterine lining, it often results in cessation of menstruation and I would not expect pregnancy to occur.  In fact, if it should occur, serious complications could arise.  For this reason, women are advised to use contraception if they are still fertile.  If you wish to increase your family you probably should look into adoption or other options.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Based on a 25 day cycle, ovulation would be expected on day 11 of your cycle.  This puts the "fertile" days starting at day 4 if one assumes that sperm can survive for 7 days in the vaginal/uterine tract.  7 days is probably about the longest that sperm would be expected to survive (if that long).  Using this calculation (which is a rough calculation), one would expect your risk of pregnancy to begin increasing around March 28th with the chances being much more around April 1st.  I hope this helps a little.  Best wishes.

content: This is a difficult question. posted_time: Post  by Cutiepie » Mon Jun 04, 2007 8:05 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: This may or may not have been indicative of ovulation.  Even if it were not, ovulation would still have been expected around this date based on your cycles.  Unfortunately, it may not help much with determining paternity since it is possible for sperm from both men to still be viable and able to fertilize the egg during this time.  It is a little more likely that the contact on the 3rd was the one that caused fertilization compared to 3/29 simply because the sperm cells will be more healthy at that point and more apt to successfully achieve fertilization.  Fertilization typically does not occur on the exact day of ovulation.  Instead it usually occurs a day or several days later as the egg travels down the fallopian tubes.  This extra time makes it less likely that sperm from 3/29 would continue to be viable.  This is in no way a guarantee, though.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Basically, ovulation would be expected 14 days before the start of your next period.  So for a 28 day cycle this would be 14 days after the last period.  For a 25 day cycle it would be 11 days after.  For a 30 day cycle it would be 16 days after the start of the last period.  This would put your expected ovulation day around April 8th or 9th based on the math in my head.  Fertility would be expected to begin around April 2nd or so based on this.  These are rough estimates and aren't always accurate but can at least give some fairly solid estimates.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: It seems, based on your MRI, that you have some mild disk encroachment on the spine and possibly on the nerve leaving the spine.  It's likely that this is contributing to your back pain some.  It doesn't seem severe but probably enough to cause pain.  Pregnancy can worsen back pain because the spine begins carrying more weight from the baby and the weight is shifted forward so the spine is having to compensate more.  I would recommend that you discuss your MRI findings with a neurosurgeon or spine surgeon to see if anything needs to be done.  Often, for back injuries, physical therapy is the most helpful.  Surgery is generally a last resort because the surgeries often have complications and varied success rates.  You may want to ask the surgeon their opinion of pregnancy.  I suspect that while it may cause some increased pain it would not be dangerous.  Best wishes.

title: Miscarriage after emergency visit
content: Hello,  I'm a 25 year old woman and I found out that I was pregnant about 4 weeks ago. I felt fine. No problems and no excessive cramping. For this they gave me an antibiotic. They also gave me a pelvic exam. At this time they said that everything was fine and they were happy that my uterus was still closed. Two days later I miscarried. posted_time: Post  by rturner » Sat Jun 02, 2007 8:37 pm

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Rturner, It is unlikely that the pelvic exam contributed to the miscarriage.  While you express concern about the "pap smear", It is not routine for an actual pap smear to be done during a ER visit pelvic exam.  I do not know if in reality, the spotting you experienced that precipitated the ER visit, may have been an early sign of the body's intent to miscarry.  Many times a problem with the developing fetus may signal the body that this is not going to be a viable birth, and the body eliminates it.  I would convey this occurrence to your OB/GYN because this puts you into a category of "high-risk" pregnancy, a category that means you need close monitoring the next time you become pregnant.  You were right to have the UTI evaluated by the ER MD.  And based on the little information you have presented, I doubt that you did anything to cause the miscarriage. I wish you well with your next pregnancy.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Probably the most common cause for the need for a hysterectomy immediately following birth (but still rare) would be the inability to stop bleeding from the uterus after birth.  In this case, the baby is generally well and not affected.  There are instances where there may also be issues with the placenta as well as the uterus that could result in bleeding from the uterus and placenta causing blood loss from the baby as well.  These cases could potentially cause trouble for the baby.  Unfortunately, really each case is individual.  It is possible for the issue to be related solely to the uterus or involve the uterus and the baby.  If you have more specific questions please feel free to post a follow up.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by kitty0611 » Tue May 29, 2007 8:16 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Home pregnancy tests generally become the most sensitive during the 5th week after the last pregnancy.  Your doctor often will do a urine test; however, if there is suspicion of pregnancy and the urine tests are negative, a blood test can be done which is much more sensitive.  It may also be that the hormone level in the patch was a little low and your body's hormones took over again.  This may have changed the expected due date for your period.    If your period doesn't start in the next week you should follow up with your doctor.  In the mean time, it is OK to replace the patch as you normally would.  If you are pregnant, the exposure to the estrogen from the patch is not harmful during the short time until pregnancy is diagnosed.  Best wishes.
