author: kaitka  Guest Posts: 20 Joined: Sun Dec 17, 2006 12:58 am Location: Ohio  Contact:   Contact kaitka       AOL
title: Blood pressure irregularities during pregnancy
content: Hi.  I'm a 23-year-old female with a 17-month-old daughter.  She was born in December 2005.  During my pregnancy with her, I had horrible bouts of dizziness, and could barely get out of bed after the 3-month mark.  I had to stop working because I would pass out after standing for about 15 minutes.  The doctor told me my iron levels were slightly low, but nothing to worry about.  At 40 weeks pregnant, I developed preeclampsia.  I was induced on my due date because there was a significant amount of protein in my urine.  There was no prior incidence of blood pressure problems through any of that pregnancy.  At the time of my daughter's birth, my iron levels were dangerously low and the doctors wanted to do a blood transfusion.  I refused, and the levels returned to normal very shortly following.    I am currently 21 weeks pregnant with my second.  I'm having the same repeat dizzy spells.  My iron levels are normal, as well as my blood pressure while I'm at the doctor.  Last time I was at the grocery store (this is where I notice most of these problems since it involves walking), I tested my blood pressure while I felt fine, and it was 150/108.  My blood pressure is ALWAYS around 110/70 when I'm tested at the doctor.  I was shocked at how high it was, and how normal I felt.  Within about 15 minutes, however, I started feeling dizzy, had to sit down.  So I took my blood pressure again immediately, and found that it had dropped a significant amount.  It was 80/50.      I understand that blood pressure can change within just minutes, but it seems like an awfully dramatic change.  And I'm fairly certain now that it's my blood pressure causing this dizziness.  There is a very large family history of blood pressure problems and heart problems.  I have Mitral Valve Prolapse (was diagnosed at 18 years old), but am not on any medications for anything.  Normally, drinking tons and tons of water throughout my grocery store trips helps keep me from passing out.  Sometimes, though, it doesn't work.  How can I get this under control and what are the effects this will have on my 21-week-old fetus?    Any help is greatly appreciated, as this is an ongoing problem and I would like to have more children.  This problem makes it incredibly difficult to be pregnant.  I have no blood pressure problems when I am not pregnant.  But I do have very significant irregular heartbeat, which gets worse when I'm pregnant, probably because of these blood pressure irregularities.
posted_time: Post  by kaitka » Thu May 24, 2007 8:24 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi, I hope you are in good communication with your obstetrician or family doctor about your bothersome symptoms.  In addition to the classic hypertension (high blood pressure), there is secondary hypertension, where something else in the body is resulting in the high blood pressure (or fluctuating blood pressure).  Since your doctor will only see the results on the days you are in there, let him/her know what is happening, what the home monitoring is showing and you may be recommended to have your pressure measured even several times daily using a home monitor.  The overall pattern is important so your doctor needs to know what is going on.  Some conditions that can affect blood pressure include glandular problems (thyroid, adrenal gland, parathyroid, diabetes, etc.), kidney problems, sleep apnea, obesity, medications (including supplements), and pregnancy induced hypertension.  This is why it is important for you to communicate with your health care provider so if additional testing is necessary it can be arranged.    Additionally, blood pressure fluctuations are usually without symptoms (as you noticed when you discovered the episode of high blood pressure) so it is possible your symptoms are caused by something else entirely which should be checked out.  Gestational diabetes is another common pregnancy complication which can cause some very uncomfortable feelings.  This is generally checked near the beginning of the third trimester because it most often appears in the latter part of pregnancy but it can occur sooner too.    Please let us know what you find out.  This is definitely not a normal pregnancy reaction.  Even if it turns out to not be serious at all, it is important to be sure.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Fri May 25, 2007 4:49 pm

Should i wait until after the birth to remove it? Does it pose much of a risk? posted_time: Post  by jean123 » Sun May 20, 2007 9:35 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: It is a little difficult to say whether the catheter is related to the high WBC count.    In general, if possible surgery should be postponed during surgery.  If the surgery is necessary, the physicians will take special precautions to make it as safe as possible for both mom and baby.  In these situations it comes down to risks vs. benefits.  In some cases it will be necessary to take the risks due to the need for the surgical treatment and in some cases the benefits will not be worth the risks.  I would recommend following up with your obstetrician to try to identify why your WBC count is high.  I think it is unlikely that the catheter is the source of your WBC count but be sure to get your doctor's opinion since I cannot examine you.  Also you should discuss the risks of surgery during pregnancy with your obstetrician.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: It can take several months of trying before conception actually occurs.  The most fertile time is about a week after the menstrual cycle; the least fertile time is just before and during the menses.   I would recommend that you try to plan your sexual intercourse to coincide with the fertile period (and any additional you want besides that) just relax and see when it happens - it may be a pleasant surprise when your wife misses a period and she is actually pregnant.  Unfortunately we do not have as much control in this matter as we wish we did.  Good luck and enjoy the experience!

author: ThreePrinces  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Fri May 04, 2007 5:49 pm
title: [no title]
content: Well I am apparently quite good at conceiving boys, since I have 3 beautiful sons.  =)  Honestly, I don't think there's much you can do.  Some people believe in the Shettles Method, which is timing intercourse as close to ovulation as possible for a boy and as far away as possible for a girl.  This is from the theory that Y chromosome carrying sperm (boys) swim faster and don't' live as long as the girl sperm.  I have seen far too many Shettles opposites to put any faith in this method.  My sister-in-law, in fact, is due with my new niece in August and they only had intercourse the day before ovulation, which according to Shettles is definite boy territory.  My first son is also a Shettles opposite.  We were not trying to get pregnant at the time but he was conceived with intercourse 4 days prior to ovulation, which would put him in the girl territory according to Shettles.  What really gets me about Shettles is that there are other methods that outright contradict it and they also prove a high success rate.  This leads me to believe that it's a crapshoot.  You do, afterall, have a 50/50 chance of it working since there are only 2 genders.  =)  I have heard of some people douching with an alkaline douche (baking soda) prior to intercourse in hopes to make a more suitable environment for the boy sperm.  You might try doing a web search to find out more information on this.    In the end, I think you're going to get what you get; unless you see a doctor and do a more scientific approach such as Microsort or the Ericsson Albumin method of sperm spinning.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: It is very possible that this is ligament pain.  Since you describe it as burning I think it is unlikely it is anything serious but if it gets worse, doesn't abate or you have any other symptoms you should call your doctor right away or go to the hospital if not available.  Otherwise, let your doctor know at your next appointment.  You should also be monitoring the baby's movements and if there is any concern go to the hospital.  I would expect about 10 kicks in a two hour time frame.  It's a good idea to do "kick counts" and pick a time each day to count these during a two hour period. posted_time: Post  by confused86 » Mon May 14, 2007 6:11 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: It is certainly a possibility that it could be a miscarriage.  It is thought that many miscarriages occur before the woman even knows she is pregnant and she just assumes it is a heavy period.  In these cases there are not usually any complications.  But, if bleeding becomes especially heavy you would definitely want to be checked out in case you are miscarrying and everything is not expelled.  In some cases it is necessary for the doctor to do a D&C so the best plan would be to call your doctor and see what he/she suggests for you.    It would also be a good time to discuss some acceptable birth control options with your doctor to be sure you don't get into this situation before you are ready for it.  When you say you and your boyfriend are pretty careful but you don't remember if you used protection each time, that brings up a red flag that this method is not the best for you.  There are some methods that don't require thinking about it each time.  Condoms also work well to protect from STDs and that is also important.  But, if you don't use them, they can't do their job.  Good luck.

title: Rh negative and Desperate
content: I am at 33 weeks pregnant and rh negative. I have been waiting on medicaid to approve for months, but they keep putting me off. I have tried going to every clinic in the area. No one will accept me until medicaid comes through or I can pay for an initial pregnancy visit. Which of course, is outrageously expensive. I need to know what complications can come of not getting this shot. Is it something I can go to the hospital and get, because no doctor will do just the shot, I have called all around to get it and no one will see me.
posted_time: Post  by amie91872 » Tue May 15, 2007 11:21 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi, I'm sorry you are having trouble getting important prenatal care.  Here are a few thoughts.  First of all, the most important shot for you when Rh negative is the one given within 72 hours of you giving birth.  The prenatal shot is kind of an emergency just-in-case backup.  They give it close enough to delivery that it would likely be effective in the case of a premature delivery that may be emergency without medical care or for some other reason you were unable to get the Rhogam after delivery.  So, to ease some of your fears, just make sure you get the Rhogam after delivery if you are a candidate.  If your baby's blood is tested and found to be negative you don't need the shot at all.    Secondly, have you tried contacting your local health department to ask if there are any community clinics you might be able to use, where doctors work on a sliding fee schedule or in other ways help people like you who are uninsured?  I would check in the State or County listings (often in your phone book under government related services) for Health and just start asking questions.  Also, check with your Medicaid office to find out what is holding up your benefits.  Are they waiting for any information you need to provide?  Is there a case worker assigned to your case?  If so, you want to speak to that person or their supervisor.   Some states have additional support services for pregnancy that helps expedite the Medicaid process so your care does not have to be held up waiting for this.  Call your Medicaid office to find out and be sure to tell them you are pregnant.    Good luck and let us know how it works out.

author: ThreePrinces  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Fri May 04, 2007 5:49 pm
title: [no title]
content: I'm not a doctor, but I am pretty well versed in fertility problems (it took me over 2 years to conceive my second child-I had to seek assistance and finally conceived with fertility treatments.)  It is perfectly normal for a healthy, normal couple to take up to a year to conceive.  You are only at 7 months.  That is not considered a fertility problem, although I know how heartbreaking it is to keep trying and trying.    Are you certain that you are timing intercourse correctly?  You may be missing your ovulation all together.  The average cycle is 28 days, but cycles vary from woman to woman and even month to month for the same woman.  I recommend the book "Taking Charge of your Fertility" and using an ovulation predictor kit to ensure that you are timing intercourse appropriately.  Good luck

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Yes, I agree, this is probably just a normal timing situation.  Because of the very short life of an egg (and usually only one is released each month) it can take a while for everything to work out just right for pregnancy.  Up to a year is a common time frame for pregnancy to occur.  In actively trying to become pregnant, you should make good use of the time from one week to two and a half weeks after the beginning day of your period.   This would be your most fertile time period.    Good luck.

author: ThreePrinces  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Fri May 04, 2007 5:49 pm
title: Multiple cesareans
content: Hello,  I am 27 years old with 3 prior cesarean births.  My first son was born in March 2001 Second son born in August 2004 Third son born in May 2006  My first cesarean was an emergency after 44 hours of labor, my son becoming very distressed.  He was also acencletic, and an attempt to turn his head into the proper position failed.  Baby 7 pounds 15 ounces.  My second cesarean was a repeat, as the hospital does not allow VBAC.  It was uncomplicated.  Baby 9 pounds 3 ounces.  My third was another repeat, and it was uncomplicated.  In fact my OB said it was "a piece of cake."  Baby 8 pounds 1 ounce.  I did have a minor subchorionic hemmorrage during that pregnancy, which resolved itself by 12 weeks gestation.  All 3 boys born healthy  During my third cesarean. I asked him if it looked okay in there for me to have a fourth and he gave me a thumb's up.  It was noted that I had minimal scar tissue given the number of cesareans I have had, my uterus has not thinned and I had no bleeding issues.  My OB has said that he does not foresee me having any complications with a fourth, (but was quick to say that things happen and you never know.)  So now for my question:  I have been given the green light to have a fourth.  My husband and I would like a fourth (AND LAST) child.  This will be the last one.  I understand that maternal and fetal risk goes up with each cesarean, yet I have also been told by a labor and delivery nurse that if you are cut in the same place each time (as I have been..there is only one scar on my uterus), that is a good thing and a 4 cesarean may not be any more risky than a second.  Is any of this true?  How common are issues such as placenta accreta?  What precations can one take to help ensure a safe delivery?  Thank you!
posted_time: Post  by ThreePrinces » Fri May 04, 2007 5:58 pm

author: ThreePrinces  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Fri May 04, 2007 5:49 pm
title: [no title]
content: one more question, if I may (sorry that I forgot to include it in my original post)  Is there any testing that can be done prior to conception to help ensure that the uterus is fit to handle one more pregnancy?  An ultrasound to look for excessive scar tissue, thin uterus?  Again, thank you.
posted_time: Post  by ThreePrinces » Fri May 04, 2007 6:00 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: I'm sorry there is no test and it seems the jury is still out about whether or not there is increased risk.  While all surgery comes with risk, and any cesarean is riskier than most vaginal delliveries, one study reported in PubMed indicates there is little risk posed with a fourth cesarean delivery as opposed to a second or third and some other sources have also put the risk at a comparable level with the third.  There are a few more complications that accompany multiple c/sections such as placental problems relating to attachment, placenta  previa, etc.  Given your history I would see no reason why you would expect problems but of course nobody can guarantee this in any circumstances.   Good luck with your decision.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I can't definitively answer your question; however, I am aware of case reports of women that have low levels of hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) in their urine as compared to "normal standards".  Because of this, these women will test negative using urine pregnancy tests for longer than typical.  I do not know why this is the case.  In your case, the low hormone levels may be tied to the miscarriages.  You may wish to talk with a Reproductive/Infertility endocrinologist.  These are obstetricians that have specifically trained in infertility and reproductive hormonal problems.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: In general, your risk of pregnancy is low based on a few reasons but not zero.  There is often some sperm in the pre-ejaculatory fluid.  The amount is low so pregnancy from solely this fluid is unlikely but again, possible.  Also, based on your menstrual cycle, if you are less than one week from starting your period it is unlikely that you are currently "fertile".  Generally, roughly speaking, the week after the start of your period and the week before are less fertile and the middle two weeks are more fertile.  (Don't base a rhythm method of contraception on these estimates.)  If you do not start your period as expected you should take a pregnancy test.  Also, incidents such as you are describing can be very traumatic to deal with emotionally.  If you find yourself having trouble I strongly recommend you see a counselor or talk to someone you trust about it.  Sometimes just having someone to talk to can make things so much better.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi, You do not indicate the first day of your last period but based on  your regularity and expected period I would say it was around March 22.  This would meant your most likely conception would have occured sometime around April 5 (though this can vary considerably).  Then, on May 7 the fetus should have been 6 weeks by gestation age (the two weeks prior to conception are actually added because gestation is calculated from the first day of the last period).  April 21 (the day before your period was due) would not be a likely time for pregnancy.  For instance, it would be considered one of the "safe" days if you were using a natural method of birth control such as cycle beads.  So, while that is not a completely reliable method, it does work pretty well in predicting fertility times and you should not have been fertile then.  Based on your doctor's impression that the fetus was 3.5 weeks (was this by ultrasound?), that would have meant conception occurred about April 12.    If conception had occured on April 21, the doctor would be seeing a fetus almost 4.5 weeks.  You didn't say exactly how the doctor was determining this developmental age.  If April 21 was the only day you had sex, that would change the picture of course.  I hope this makes sense.  Feel free to write back if you still have questions.

author: Triceratops  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed May 02, 2007 10:59 am
title: Pls reply...Missed menses = premature menopause or thyroid?
content: Hi,  I would like to seek second opinion.  I have missed my menses for two months.  I have also done several pregnancy tests at different intervals but all the results were negative.  However, it appears that I am experiencing some pregnancy symptoms (like the stomach feeling a little bloated, some dizziness and I get very sleepy at night).  I have also been told by my doctor to wait and see.  I just want to know if I am getting a premature menopause (I am only 34 years old this year) or have I developed thyroid?  Or could I be pregnant with the foetus developing outside my womb?   Would greatly appreciate if someone could reply because I am really anxious now!  Thanks a zillion in advance!
posted_time: Post  by Triceratops » Mon May 07, 2007 11:07 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Menopause or thyroid issues could certainly account for your symptoms.  Pregnancy is also a possibility.  An ectopic pregnancy is less likely but some women seem to have lower amounts of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in the urine.  hCG is the hormone produced by the placenta that is tested for with urine pregnancy tests.  It's pretty rare but some women don't have a postiive urine test for 8-10 weeks.  A serum pregnancy test is much more sensitive.  If there is concern for pregnancy a serum test can be done as well as an ultrasound to look for an intrauterine or extrauterine pregnancy.  Testing the thyroid is quite easy.  A TSH and T4 level can be drawn from the blood to assess this.  Menopause can be tested for by checking FSH and estrogen levels.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Mon May 07, 2007 3:51 pm

posted_time: Post  by juliet » Mon Apr 30, 2007 12:40 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: At this point, if you are pregnant a home pregnancy test should be accurate.  Based on your last period, it has been 6 1/2 weeks since your period.  Generally by 5 weeks, home pregnancy tests are around 99% accurate.  Several factors can result in a false negative, including very dilute urine, testing too early (i.e. before 4-5 weeks), and incorrectly performing the test.  I would recommend you repeat the pregnancy test now using the first morning void.  If this is negative it is likely to be a true result.  There are several things that can alter a normal period including stress (good stress as well as bad stress) and illnesses.  If your pregnancy test is negative and you do not have your period by 8 weeks I would recommend you see your doctor for an evaluation.  Best wishes and congratulations on your recent marraige.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: By definition, ovulation is when the egg is released from the ovaries.  At that point it becomes able to be fertilized.  Sperm can remain viable for several days (with reports of up to a week) after deposition in the vaginal tract.  It sounds as if your ovulation was at the correct time for the sperm to successfully fertilze the egg and result in pregnancy.  Generally, pregnancy tests are accurate within the 4th to 5th week after the last pregnancy.  I hope this helps some.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi, I would continue to have every other day sexual intercourse from about day 8 or 10, through about day 20 (but of course you don't need to stop then - you would just be less likely to be fertile and the idea is not to miss the most fertile time.  Stopping at that point won't do anything to improve your chances so relax and enjoy it).  Not everyone ovulates at the same point in the cycle.  A fertile woman, regularly engaging in sex will likely become pregnant within the year and it would not be considered abnormal for it to take the full year.  You were very lucky the first time - it just doesn't always work according to our calendar and planning.  Good luck!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi, Since you have regular 30 day cycles, you were probably at the last day of the time before your most fertile period would begin.  The next two weeks beginning on the 24th would be the most likely time for pregnancy. For instance, if you were carefully practicing the rhythm method using cycle beads to monitor the times you would especially want to use a backup method of birth control that time would begin on the 24th.  Used correctly in women with regular cycles, this can be a pretty good method, so based on that, you were still in the "safe zone" and pregnancy would not be likely (possible, but not likely). author: Gueniviere  Guest Posts: 7 Joined: Tue Apr 24, 2007 2:52 pm
title: pregnancy test
content: is 3 weeks really the earliest that one can get a test done to determine pregnancy?  When you really want to know that sounds like a very long time.  Also, what are the risks of taking bc pills when you are pregnant?   This can damage the fetus, correct?
posted_time: Post  by Gueniviere » Wed Apr 25, 2007 2:04 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: No, there is no evidence that taking the pill when pregnant will cause birth defects or other problems for the fetus.  They consist of hormones just as your body makes.  They interfere with ovulation primarily and if you have ovulated in spite of the pills or because of inconsistent use, you do not need to worry about damage.  Once pregnancy is confirmed you will be advised to stop taking them to allow your normal hormones to do their work to sustain the pregnancy but if you are not pregnant, you would want to keep taking them on the recommended schedule anyway.    If you think you may be pregnant, be certain you are taking 400 mcg folic acid (perhaps as part of a multivitamin) because this has been shown to decrease risk of birth defects when taken early in pregnancy.  Women of childbearing age should consistently take a vitamin daily as described because 50% of all pregnancies are unintended.

author: ammedle  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed Apr 25, 2007 10:30 am
title: Unprotected sex with two partners - who is the father?
content: Hi im 36 years old and have a problem. I just found out im pregnant. My last period started on March 26 and lasted three days. I had unprotected sex on March 31&april 5 with one guy and had unprotected sex with another on April 8th who may b the father? Partner A or B
posted_time: Post  by ammedle » Wed Apr 25, 2007 10:56 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Unfortunately there is not an easy answer here.  You could have been fertile during the time frame that covered both the 8th and 14th.  The reason it is hard to say is that not everyone ovulates at exactly the 14th day.  If you have regular menstrual cycles between 26 and 32 days, your most likely ovulation date would be April 9 making intercourse on the 8th the most likely conception. Sperm can live in the fallopian tubes up to five days.  But eggs do not last so long (around 12 to 24 hours).  Again, since you don' t know exactly when you ovulated, you can't be sure which it is.  Only paternity testing later could most certainly verify who is the father.  I hope this helps, even if it doesn't give you a definite answer.  Good luck.

author: LD1120  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Apr 24, 2007 5:10 pm
title: Over the counter meds while pregnant
content: I am 34 yrs. old and pregnant for the first time.  I have had very bad sinus problems for years and with pregnancy, it is worse.  Can I use over the counter nasal decongestant being 10 weeks pregnant?
posted_time: Post  by LD1120 » Tue Apr 24, 2007 5:19 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Usually the over-the-counter decongestants contain either pseudoephedrine or phenylephrine.  There is simply not enough data on phenylephrine to really say if it is safe or not, so it has received a pregnancy class C rating.  If possible, this drug should be avoided since we just don't know for sure.  Pseudoephedrine has a bit more data.  It has had some small trials in pregnant women and has been found safe in these studies.  The problem is that the studies were small so a danger may have been missed.  It is rated class C (not enough data) by the US and class B2 by the Australian data system (Probably safe but not certain).  Some obstetricians OK the use of pseudoephedrine and some do not.  It's probably safe but we can't say for sure.  If there is an allergy component, diphenhydramine (commonly called Benadryl) is safe to use in pregnancy (US class B and Australian class A).  As a summary: Class A-safe Class B-probably safe Class C-uncertain Class D-evidence suggests drug is unsafe Class X-definitely not safe  The Australian system tends to have better data than the US system at this point.  Sorry, it's a long answer to a short question.  Here's a summary.  I would recommend avoiding phenylephrine, pseudoephedrine is probably safe but I would recommend waiting until after the first trimester, diphenhydramine is safe.    Saline nasal sprays are always safe and may provide a little help.  Your obstetrician may have a list of safe medicines for you take as well.  Best wishes.

author: Gueniviere  Guest Posts: 7 Joined: Tue Apr 24, 2007 2:52 pm
title: how can I be pregnant?
content: I'm a 37 yo female who's been on the Pill for years.  I understand that it works by preventing ovulation  If that's correct, then how can one get pregnant by missing a pill if I don't ovulate?    The reason I ask is b/c for the first time EVER I missed 2 pills and had unprotected sex b/c I didn't realize i had missed 2 pills.  What is the liklihood that I am pregnant?
posted_time: Post  by Gueniviere » Tue Apr 24, 2007 3:02 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: The rational behind using oral contraceptives is that the hormone in the pill "overrides" the bodies natural hormone levels causing the hormones FSH and LH to be suppressed.  This suppression prevents the surge of LH that is involved in ovulation, thus preventing ovulation.  If one misses taking the birth control pill, the levels of estrogen or progesterone may drop below the threshold for suppression and allow the body to "take over" again.  At this point, ovulation may occur and the chance of pregnancy increases.  While the likelihood is less than not using the oral contraceptive at all, the chance of pregnancy does go up.    The general recommendation if you have missed more than one pill is to start a new pack of birth control pills and use an alternative method of contraception for the next month.  If your menses are not on time as expected you should take a pregnancy test.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Tue Apr 24, 2007 3:47 pm

author: Gueniviere  Guest Posts: 7 Joined: Tue Apr 24, 2007 2:52 pm
title: [no title]
content: and the risk of pregnancy can go up as quickly as  1 or 2 days without a pill?  I can ovulate that quickly?
posted_time: Post  by Gueniviere » Tue Apr 24, 2007 4:00 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: It would depend on when in your cycle the missed days occurred, but yes, it is possible and it has happened to others.  Missing one day is not as likely to result in ovulation but two or more does raise your risk.  If you miss a day, you should take the missed dose along with the regular dose on the day you remember.  If you only miss one, the likelihood of pregnancy is not great so you don't need a backup method of birth control - just take two the next day when you remember.  With two or more missed, you would be wise to use a backup until you start your next package of pills.  I hope this is clear for you.  Let us know if you don't understand it - I know it sounds complicated.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: I would recommend a workup with your OB/GYN who can better determine what kinds of fertility challenges you have.  I see no reason why the procedures you have had in the past would affect fertility, but if you have been sexually active for three years, attempting pregnancy, there is cause for concern.  Getting the right diagnosis is essential.    While clomid has helped many women who have trouble with ovulation, it is not without its risks (especially for multiples and their resulting preterm deliveries).  You would only want to take this under a doctor's care and only if this is the actual problem with your fertility as determined by your doctor. Progesterone is an important hormone in pregnancy but it too should be used only with your doctor's knowledge and encouragement.    Good luck in your attempts, but please schedule a visit with your health care provider or fertility clinic.

Then i squeezed the nipple and to my surprise started leaking a small amount of clear liquid.  What do you think is wrong, should i go see a doctor?

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Nipple discharge such as you describe is rarely a sign of a  serious problem and often considered a normal part of your breast's function, especially in a woman who has breastfed a baby. If that's the case, the discharge might resolve on its own. Avoid nipple stimulation — such as by frequently checking for discharge — because stimulation actually makes the discharge persist.   You may get some relief from your symptoms by applying a warm compress and taking a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medication such as aspirin or ibuprofen.  Breast tenderness can also be an early sign of pregnancy.    Another possible cause of discharge is hormonal (excess prolactin) and can result from birth control pills or other medications, frequent breast self-exam, sexual activity, thyroid or pituitary gland disorder. Some women experience such symptoms during menstruation.  Other causes usually are found in older women such as tumors (typically non-cancerous).    If the problem persists, it's best to check it out with your health care provider to be on the safe side and of course it is always important to have regular physical exams where you should report any unusual symptoms to your doctor.

author: ethie118  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sun Apr 15, 2007 7:59 pm
title: Can blood in urine interfere with pregnancy test?
content: I read online that having blood in your urine or protein in your urine can interfere with the results of a Pregnancy test. Is that true????
posted_time: Post  by ethie118 » Sat Apr 21, 2007 9:03 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: If you have visible blood in the urine this may interfere with the test simply because the blood may cover up any color change that is occuring.  If the hormone human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is present in the urine the test should still be accurate if only microscopic blood or protein is present in the urine.  The tests are quite sensitive and specific as long as the concentration of hCG is high enough (usually by the 5th week after the last menses).  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Yes, breasts can leak in a non-pregnant woman with stimulation, as with foreplay and this is within the normal range.  It could be due to the normally present duct-blocking keratin being dislodged.  All women (pregnant or not) have fluid in their breasts but usually the ducts are plugged when the woman is not pregnant or breastfeeding.    This can also be a sign of a hormonal imbalance, medication side effects or other abnormal condition so if it continues, she should seek an examination by her health care provider to be sure it is not a problem.  Most likely this is benign.  The greater issue I see here is a matter of trust, which is essential in a good relationship.  Hopefully you can work through this concern, but if not, this may be a red-flag for future relationship challenges.

posted_time: Post  by zeth385 » Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:14 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: It is rare to get chickenpox a second time, but some people who have immune disorders may not develop antibodies to the disease, thus they can contract it again.  Has your wife actually been exposed to a known case of chicken pox?  Until recently, when the vaccine became available, chickenpox was almost always out there in the general population and it was almost impossible to avoid exposure.  The vast majority of adults are already immune.  Vaccination has decreased the incidence and therefore will have a positive effect on pregnancy risk.  Keep in mind that 3 to 5% of babies in the general population are born with congenital defects and your baby's risk with this exposure would be only about 2%.  So try not to stress too much about this.  It doesn't carry the high risk of defects found with prenatal rubella exposure.  The doctor can give your wife ativiral drugs to reduce the severity of the illness, but it sounds like she is not having a bad case anyway.  OTIS (Organization of Teratolgoy Information Services) has a fact sheet about chickenpox at http://www.otispregnancy.org (English, Spanish and French languages).  Good luck and keep us posted on your wife's condition.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: It sounds very consistent with pregnancy.  The urine pregnancy test is quite specific for human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), a hormone made by the placenta.  It is possible that the pregnancy is too early along to see the fetus developing yet.  In this situation, your obstetrician will likely want to follow the specific amount of hCG in your wife's blood.  With a normal intrauterine pregnancy, the hCG amount rises very predictably.  If it is not rising as expected (too fast or too slow) this can indicate the presence of other conditions such as ectopic pregnancy or fetal demise.  Of note, it is possible to have elevated hCG levels and not be pregnant.  In particular, there is a type of tumor, known as choriocarcinoma, that secretes hCG.  If pregnancy is ruled out by other means, this should be looked for.   Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: There are several possible explanations, including pregnancy.  Oral contraceptive are quite effective but only when taken consistently.  Missing an occasional pill is OK-just take it the next day with that day's pill.  Consistently missing pills makes the contraceptive ineffective and other methods should be used.  You may also be having some side effects from starting the pill.  It will often take 2-3 months for women to become acclamated to the pill.  If there is concern about pregnancy you should take a pregnancy test.  They become accurate during the 5th week after the start of your last period.  Also remember that birth control pills do not protect against STD's.  Best wishes.

title: Missed pill for 2 days - missed my period - am I pregnant?
content: ok i am a 23 year old female ive taken three pregnancy tests and they all came out blank i am on the pill i missed two days and took them the next day what are the chances of me being pregnant and yes i missed my period
posted_time: Post  by november1112 » Mon Apr 02, 2007 10:02 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: To answer this, I need to know what you did after you missed the pills.  I.e. did you take extra pills or restart a new pack, etc?  Generally for 2 missed pills, the recommendation is to take 2 pills on the day you remember, 2 pills the next day, then 1 pill a day until you finish the pack.    If you miss the pills the pills during the 3rd week of the pack after taking the 2 days of 2 pills, take one pill a day until the end of the week if you start your packs on Sunday then start a new pack.  If you don't start on Sunday you can just start a new pack.  In these situations you may not have a period that month.    It is generally recommended that if you miss more than one day in your packet you should use a back up method for the next 1-2 weeks.  If you are concerned about the possibility of pregnancy you should repeat your pregnancy test in the 5th week after your last period or see your doctor for a blood test.  Best wishes.

author: Shana Johnson, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 356 Joined: Sat Sep 03, 2005 5:13 am Location: Las Vegas, NV
title: [no title]
content: It's very possible you are pregnant, but it's a little to early for an HPT to be accurate, even with the early detection tests. The soonest an early detection HPT may be accurate is 5 days before your missed period but even then, you could still get a false negative. Your best bet is to wait until April 9th, and test then. If you do try to test sooner, use first morning urine, and do not get discouraged by a false result, it may just be to soon.  Good luck!

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Depo-Provera can do just about anything to a woman's normal cycle.  This can range from no bleeding to severe bleeding and just about anything in between.  After about 6 months on the medication about 1/2 of women will no longer have a monthly cycle.  After 12 months almost all women will stop having their monthly cycle.  It will return after stopping the depo-provera.  I suspect that you may be experiencing some symptoms related to your medicine; however, this is a little soon.  If you were ready to start your regular cycle it may be your normal cycle with some medication effect.  The medication does not start preventing pregnancy right away.  I recommend that women use another form of birth control for 1 month after starting the medicine.  So if there is a possibility of becoming pregnant I would recommend you take a home pregnancy test.  The medication will not interfere with the test.    If your symptoms do not improve over the next few days I would recommend you see your doctor for an evaluation.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Home pregnancy tests are generally most reliable beginning the 5th week after the start of the most recent menses.  Given that you have had 2 tests come back positive (even though it was a late response) I would be suspicious of pregnancy.  Generally, home pregnancy tests can miss pregnancies but when they are positive they are usually accurate.  The late response may indicate that your hormonal levels are still low (as would be expected in that you are about 1-2 weeks earlier than the test would typically pick up).  I would recommend you repeat the test closer to April 1st when your period should be starting or during the 5th week after your last period started.  This will give a much more reliable result.  Alternatively, if your doctor is willing, a blood test can be done that is more sensitive and picks up pregnancies earlier.  Best wishes.

title: taking lunesta during first trimester
content: I am 27 female and I am 10 weeks pregnant and just found out.  I was taking lunesta every night to help me sleep and now that I know I am pregnant I am so scared of what I have done to my baby.  Could it be deformed due to what I had taken... I am very scared of what could happen.
posted_time: Post  by kmhammonds » Sun Mar 04, 2007 7:58 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: The data is still unclear about lunesta during pregnancy.  It currently is labeled as category C which means that there aren't enough studies to prove it safe or not safe.  There have been some studies done in rats that showed that dosing of 800-1000 X normal levels did not cause increases in birth defects.  There were a few studies showing that lower doses but still well above the recommended dosing did cause some low birth weight rat pups and a slight increase in failure to implant of the embryo.  All these studies were done at very high doses and none showed a definite danger.  One must be careful when interpreting studies in animals for human usage.  The results don't always correlate.    Unfortunately there isn't data to give you a definite answer; however, based on the few studies that have been done I think that it is quite likely no harm has been done.  I would recommend that you discontinue use of the medicine during pregnancy due to the lack of information about it.    In general, it's best to avoid medicine while pregnant but if you do need some there are meds that can be safely taken.  Your obstetrician can give you a list.  Be sure to let your OB know about the lunesta, but I really think everything will turn out fine.  Best wishes.

I feel like I have to pee when I don't and when I finally do, it burns and is somewhat cloudy.  I rarely ever want to eat which is odd for me and I have a slight fever and continuous headache. Because of this, I scheduled an appointment with my gyno for later this week.  My breasts have been very slightly swollen and tender for the past month.  My period is also a day late.  To settle my mind, I took a pregnancy test and it came back negative.  My stress level has also been the highest ever with money issues this month.  Ovarian and cervical cancer run in my family.  I was just wondering if anyone had any suggestions as to what could be wrong with me, if it could be a urinary tract infection, if my gyno can help me or if it could possibly all just be in my head.  Thank you for your time!
posted_time: Post  by Young and Scared » Sat Mar 03, 2007 7:19 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Your symptoms are very consistent with a urinary tract infection.  Evaluation for this is relatively simple.  Your regular doctor or gynecologist can usually do the first part of the test in the office (a simple urine dip stick) to see if the urine is consistent with an infection.  Then treatment is anywhere from 3 to 7 days depending on the preference of the doctor.    Other possibilities should you find that you do not have a UTI would be STD's, in particular chlamydia and gonorrhea.  Your gynecologist can test for these as well, if needed.    UTI's are quite common in girls, especially those that are sexually active.  You may want to ask your doctor about a medication called phenazopyridine (it's more commonly known by its brand name, pyridium) to take for a day or two.  This will help with the burning with urination until the infection is clearing.  Just note that it will turn your urine and tears orange (something to remember if you wear contacts as it will stain them).  Hope this helps.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Let's start with discussing a commonly held assumption about pregnancy (not that you necessarily have this assumption).  Often, women believe that they cannot become pregnant without having a period.  The truth is that this may or may not be true-depending on the cause of the absent menses. Pregnancy generally will result in a cessation of ovulation for a time period after birth but that time period is quite variable.  It is possible to have an egg released and become fertilized on the first occurrence, thus leading to pregnancy without a period.  To more specifically answer your question there are a few possibilities for your symptoms.  One possibility is that you have a urinary tract infection.  Your obstetrician can test for this.    If you are concerned about pregnancy it is probably still a little early to use a home pregnancy test.  Generally these become positive about 5 weeks after the start of your last period or about 3 weeks after ovulation (generally about 2 weeks after the last period).  So, if it has only been 2 weeks and we assume that fertilization occurred you may need another week or so to have the home urine pregnancy tests be more accurate.    Frequent urination can also be a result of your body returning to its prepregnancy state.  During pregnancy, blood volumes as well as many other things increase.  The excess water will be slowly excreted back to the prepregnancy state via urination.  I would suggest you discuss your symptoms with your obstetrician or primary care doctor and have a physical exam if your symptoms persist for more than a day or two.    Regarding the Medrol, the data about use in pregnancy is mixed.  Most studies say it is probably safe.  There are a few studies that show it increases risks of some birth defects.  In general, we recommend that women who are pregnant do not take any medication unless they have to.  If this is not an option, careful decision making with your obstetrician will help avoid any unwanted effects.  So to summarize all this... I recommend you talk with your obstetrician about using the Medrol if you are pregnant.  Hope this helps.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I'm not an obstetrician, but I'll give my best attempt to answer your question.  The term friable essentially means easily damaged.  If your daughter's umbilical cord broke during delivery the term friable certainly fits.  This is a bit unusual.  Generally, the umbilical cord is quite strong.  Obstetricians often pull gently on the cord to help deliver the placenta.  When a cord breaks, doctors must work quickly to clamp it so that significant blood loss does not occur.  If there were other circumstances that may have caused the cord to break it is less likely to happen again.  With the family history of retained placenta I would be a bit suspicous of some underlying cause.  Unfortunately I do not know what this may be.  I would recommend that you discuss this with your obstetrician.  You can make an appointment just to talk with her about your future risks.  I am unable to make any estimation of future risks for you (sorry).  If your obstetrician is unable to help you she may refer you to a perinatologist that specialized in high risk pregnancies.  Best wishes.  Hope this helps some.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I.U.D.'s  can increase the risk of retained placenta as you have mentioned.  Also, abnormal uterine shape can increase risk due to less effective contractions aiding in placental separation.  There are a few rare conditions known as placenta acreda, percreda, etc. where the placenta grows into the wall of the uterus making separation without hemorrhage difficult.  The more controllable cause would be overactive manipulation of the cord/placenta by the delivering doctor.  If the cord is pulled on too hard it may break or the placenta may tear.  There are also associated problems with uterine prolapse from pulling too hard on the cord.  These causes are unlikely to recur.  Unfortunately, this is about where my knowledge of this issue ends.  Regarding your doctor, I would discuss the issues with him/her and if your doctor is not comfortable I would try simply requesting an opinion from a high risk obstetrician.  At that point, if your doctor refuses I suggest you continue to talk with him and see if there is a reason for the refusal.  Most doctors are very willing to send a patient to another doctor if it means the patient will get safer, more specialized care.  Sorry I can't be of more help.  Perhaps some of my colleagues may be able to help more.  Best wishes.  Let us know if we can be of any other help to you.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: The amount of vaginal discharge that is "normal" can vary from woman to woman.  Aditionally, cervical/vaginal mucous can change through out the monthly cycle to be more watery vs. thicker.  Typically, however, "normal" vaginal discharge is not malodorous.  Excessive discharge that has a bad odor can be a sign of a yeast infection, bacterial vaginosis, or another infection.  These can be tested for by doing a microscopic evaluation of the discharge to look for yeast or excess bacteria.  As you are not sexually active, STD's such as chlamydia and gonorhea are essentially ruled out.  Any sexual contact can put you at risk for acquiring an STD, however; so if you have had any chance of being exposed I would recommend being evaluated for these as well.  I would suggest following up with your gynecologist for reevaluation.  If your doctor is in agreement it may be worthwhile to try an emperic treatment for a yeast infection since they are so common.  Hope this helps.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  A pregnancy test is a test that examine for a hormone called human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) that is positive when women are pregnant. The test can be done using blood or urine sample. However, a blood test scan tell if the woman is pregnant or not few days (6-8 days) from ovulation and fertilization. The test can gives a clear answer for pregnancy, as well as an idea about the pregnancy duration in weeks by a quantitative analysis.  Testing for urine on the other hand, is better done one week after a missed period. One negative result (especially soon after a missed period) is not enough to exclude pregnancy and the test should be repeated there after or blood test is done. Some antibiotics and contraceptive pills interfere with the test and should be avoided.  The symptoms you have described although do occur in pregnancy, they are not specific and may occur due to several other causes even in stressed female. In addition too, spotting regularly for two days on monthly basis is less commonly seen in pregnant women, but may be caused by menstrual irregularities caused by the contraception pills.  You may either do a blood test or repeat your urine test as mentioned before.  Hope this information is useful.

posted_time: Post  by kandy » Wed Feb 07, 2007 1:49 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: The incidence of twin births has been increasing over the past several years.  In 1987 the incidence was reported at about 9 in 1000 births.  In 2003 the number had increased to about 17 in 1000 births (Australian data).    There are several factors that have probably contributed to this.  In particular, the use of fertility medications.    Really, there isn't much you can do to increase your chances of having twins.  It is possible for you, even if no one in your family has had twins before.  The rate is about 1% of all pregnancies that will result in twins.  So, if you become pregnant there is about a 1 in 100 chance you'll have twins, roughly.    Interestingly, we've also seen that taking folic acid supplementation leads to an increased risk of twins as well.  We now recommend that all women take folic acid if they are trying to conceive and throughout the pregnancy to help decrease the risk of neural tube defects.  Twin incidence also increase with increasing number of pregnancies (I.e. with each subsequent pregnancy the chances go up very slightly).  Best wishes to you and your husband on starting a family if you choose.  One word about the fertility drugs.  While they do increase the chances of multiple gestations (twins or even more), there are some pretty nasty side effects.  While I'm a pediatrician, not an obstetrician, I suspect that it would be difficult to find an OB that would be willing to prescribe them to help with conceiving twins.  They are generally reserved for couples that are having difficulty conceiving.  Hope this helps.

The following information may be helpful to give you an idea about the safety of the drugs you received in this period on your fetus.  According to the FDA: Bactrim is considered as a pregnancy category C which  means it is not known to be of harm on the fetus, but its effect on folic acid  which is important for the fetal development. Hycodan Tablets is not known whether it can or it can not cause harm to the fetus and is not recommended be many to be used during pregnancy. author: Archiebald  Guest Posts: 29 Joined: Sun Aug 28, 2005 11:20 am
title: fever during pregnancy
content: My kids have been sick with a viral thing and fever for 5 days, I just started with the fever, its now 99.3,   There fevers have been as high as 102.4.   How should I treat this fever, I just took a tynenol to reduce the fever, is there anything else I should do and if I get the same viral thing and have fever for 5 days, is that dangerous for the baby.  I am 19 1/2 weeks pregnant.  Thanks Debbie
posted_time: Post  by Archiebald » Wed Jan 31, 2007 4:40 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Colds during pregnancy are not particularly dangerous.  There are a few viruses that can be quite serious in pregnancy, such as the chickenpox and CMV.  Most viruses, however, are really just an ill-timed annoyance.  It's good to let your OB know about any illness that you have during your pregnancy so they are fully aware of any issues that might arise.  Fevers that typically go along with colds (101-102) are safe for your baby.  Some studies have shown an increased risk of birth defects if fevers above 102 are sustained for more than about a day in the first trimester.  Studies have also shown that after about 16 weeks the risk of high fevers goes down.  If you are having high fevers (upper 103's or above) it's probably a good idea to let your OB know just for caution's sake.  Treating a viral cold during pregnancy can be a bit tricky.  Tylenol is safe.  Beyond that, you have to be a bit careful.  Many cold medicines contain 3-4 different medications and not all may be safe during pregnancy.  Remember that any medication that contains a non-steroidal antiinflammatory (such as aspirin or ibuprofen) should not be taken.  A good resource is to talk with your local pharmacist if you are needing an over-the-counter cold medicine.  That way you can verify each medicine individually to make sure it is safe.  Also, if you ask your OB chances are she has a list of medicines she considers safe that you can have.  Above all, the best thing to help you get better is rest.  Drink plenty of fluids-all the old home remedies that make you feel better.  Hope you feel better soon.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Wed Jan 31, 2007 8:33 pm

author: Archiebald  Guest Posts: 29 Joined: Sun Aug 28, 2005 11:20 am
title: Braxton Hicks
content: Hi,  I am 19 weeks pregnant, is it normal to have Braxton hicks contractions this early?   I have had 3 today so far just want to know if I should be concerned.  Thank you Debbie
posted_time: Post  by Archiebald » Mon Jan 29, 2007 12:43 pm

author: Dr. Leigh Anderson  Medical Doctor Posts: 71 Joined: Sat Jan 20, 2007 5:04 am Location: United States
title: [no title]
content: t Hi Debbie,  These contractions start very early in pregnancy, most women do not really notice them until the second half of their pregnancy. These usually mild contractions are thought to play a part in toning the uterine muscles and promoting the flow of blood to the placenta.  Braxton-Hicks contractions can be triggered when you (or your baby) move or when your belly is touched. They may also occur when you are dehydrated. Each Braxton-Hicks contraction may last one to two minutes. During this time, the whole uterus becomes hard. This may feel strange and sometimes uncomfortable.  What distinguishes these contractions from real labor? When you are in labor, contractions last longer, occur more frequently, and become progressively stronger. However, Braxton-Hicks contractions come and go and may go away altogether if you change your activity (for example, rest or take a walk). Drinking a couple glasses of water may also help. If you are having difficulty distinguishing between Braxton-Hicks contractions and those of real labor, it’s important to contact your health   Take Care, and Best of Luck to you  Dr. Anderson

author: tabitharl  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Jan 20, 2007 9:18 pm
title: Rare Antibody Disorder
content: Hello,      I am 23 years old and 24 weeks pregnant.  My OB just told me that I have a rare antibody disorder that could be dangerous to the baby.  He set me up to see a specialist in one week.  My question is, do you have any idea what this could be (it is not RH incompatibility)?  More importantly, will my baby survive? I have had no surgeries or diseases to date.
posted_time: Post  by tabitharl » Sat Jan 20, 2007 9:29 pm

author: Dr. Leigh Anderson  Medical Doctor Posts: 71 Joined: Sat Jan 20, 2007 5:04 am Location: United States
title: [no title]
content: First, I'd check with your doctor to confirm that you have Rh E antibody and not Rh D, which is more common and has more treatment options available. Rh E antibody is a special marker that is sometimes found on red blood cells. It's fairly rare, but it's important to know about it because your doctor will want to monitor your unborn baby more closely.   It's difficult to say how you got this antibody, but it's more commonly found in women that have had prior pregnancies and also in women who have received blood transfusions in the past.   The antibody poses no harm to you directly. However, the concern is that this antibody in your bloodstream might attack and destroy the blood of the unborn baby. This process is called hemolytic anemia and can be extremely harmful to the baby.     The baby must be followed closely with specialized tests to watch for signs of hemolytic anemia. Most likely, your doctor will order additional ultrasounds and perhaps amniocentesis to check the amniotic fluid for signs of hemolytic anemia. If the baby begins to show signs of hemolytic anemia, certain treatment options are available. In some cases, the baby may be given a blood transfusion while still in your uterus. In other situations, the baby may be delivered earlier than the original due date so that it can receive necessary medical treatment in the nursery.   The best thing you can do is to educate yourself about this condition, (like you are doing!) and work closely with your doctor to assure that you and your baby receive the best medical care possible.   It is very important to communicate with your Doctor your concerns and have him/her answer your questions before you leave the office. Your Doctor is most qualified in narrowing down what his suspicion is or what type of antibody disorder he thinks it may be.  Dr. Anderson

I took a pregnancy test and it came back inacurate.  There is history of cysts and hystorectomies in my family.  We have just gone through a time here that was slightly stressful.  Could this cause they symptoms and causes of my period or lack there of?
posted_time: Post  by Sun » Sat Jan 20, 2007 6:18 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: When a woman of childbearing age has a delayed or absent period, pregnancy should be the first thought.  Home pregnancy tests are good, but should always be confirmed by a blood test if positive or if negative and suspicion still exists.  In your case, having a tubal ligation makes pregnancy much less likely-but it has happened before.  In the absense of pregnancy, there are several other causes of delayed menses.  It is not uncommon for women to occasionally miss a cycle, then return to normal cycles after this.  Also, stress can delay menses.  This includes "good" stress.    Early menopause is also possible.  If you are having other symptoms of menopause you should discuss this with your doctor.  Large amounts of exercise can also delay menses.    Most commonly this is a benign thing.  If your menses don't start in the next few days you may consider having your doctor evaluate you just to make sure that there is nothing more serious.  Hope this helps.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Sat Jan 20, 2007 7:59 pm

author: Dr. Leigh Anderson  Medical Doctor Posts: 71 Joined: Sat Jan 20, 2007 5:04 am Location: United States
title: [no title]
content: Absolutely ,Exercise, diet and stress can delay the onset of menstruation or alter cycles once they've been established.  Some women also have very light bleeding, or spotting, during ovulation.  . (Stress or other problems can sometimes cause a cycle to be shorter or longer.) .   Some women feel a period coming days before they get it.  both physically and emotionally. The menstrual cycle has its ups and downs of hormones, and different people react differently to hormonal swings. Just before and during menstruation, levels of the female hormones estrogen and progesterone are low. That's when some women feel bloated, irritable or blue, or "just crummy." Just crummy might mean cramps, sore breasts, backache, headache, nausea, and feeling tired.   An over the counter pregnancy test is not as effective in detecting the pregnancy hormone found in the urine when contraceptive is being used it tends to give a false/positive result. I suggest that if you do not have your period within the next 7 days see your physcian and have a blood test done to rule out pregnancy, if blood test is negative then your body is triing to stabilize your hormones with the given stress.  Good Luck Dr. Anderson

author: lisakay1111  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Jan 09, 2007 8:55 am
title: getting pregnant without having periods
content: Hi, i am a female and im 28 years old.  I havent been regular with my periods since after my son was born 7 years ago.  The only time I can have a period is while im on birth control.  I stopped birth control since we want to have a baby and yet again I'm not having my periods.  My question is can you get pregnant while not having a period?  Also, I recently had a hernia surgery and they found endometriosis.  Can that affect getting pregnant also?  Thanks so much!
posted_time: Post  by lisakay1111 » Tue Jan 09, 2007 9:04 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Endometriosis can have a significant impact on the ability to get pregnant.  It can also have an impact on the menstrual cycle if severe enough.    As for being able to get pregnant without a period, it is possible but given your situation less likely.  What would essentially happen is that ovulation would occur and if the egg was not fertilized, a period would ensue.  However, if during the random cycle that did result in ovulation also resulted in fertilization, the embryo may successfully implant and suppress the period that would have occurred.  In someone who has had absent periods for a long time, it is most likely that ovulation is not occurring, making pregnancy not possible.  Simply not having a period for several months does not, however, guarantee that ovulation will not occur with the next cycle so pregnancy cannot necessarily be considered impossible.  I would recommend talking with your OB if you are trying to get pregnant.  There are treatments for endometriosis that can help increase the odds of pregnancy.  Also, you'll want to find out why you are not having regular periods as this may impact your ability to conceive.    Hope this helps.

title: Possible ectopic preg.?
content: A similar question was asked before, but no reply.  I had a partial hysterectomy 6 years ago.  My uterus was removed, everything else was left.  I am 35 years old now.  Is it possible to have an ectopic pregnancy?  For the past week I have had symptoms of morning sickness - nausea, dizzy, slight cramping in abdomen area.  Is this probably just a virus, or could it be an ectopic pregnancy?
posted_time: Post  by cchipman » Tue Jan 09, 2007 10:08 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: To my knowledge when the uterus is removed the fallopian tubes are ligated.  At that point, they no longer have a connection to the vagina.  As such, there should anatomically be no way for pregnancy to occur as the sperm cannot reach any eggs that are released.  It should be virtually impossible to become pregnant for you.  That being said, ectopic pregnancy is a serious matter.  So if you are concerned about the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy I recommend urgent evaluation to rule this out.  Hope this helps.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: One dose at 8 weeks is unlikely to cause problems.  The manufacturers of Provera state that even a few doses while pregnant can cause birth defects. author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  A pregnancy test is a test that examine for a hormone called human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) that is positive when women are pregnant. The test can be done using blood or urine sample. However, a blood test scan tell if the woman is pregnant or not few days (6-8 days) from ovulation and fertilization. The test can gives a clear answer for pregnancy, as well as an idea about the pregnancy duration in weeks by a quantitative analysis.  Testing for urine on the other hand, is better done one week after a missed period. One negative result (especially soon after a missed period) is not enough to exclude pregnancy and the test should be repeated there after or blood test is done. Some antibiotics and contraceptive pills interfere with the test and should be avoided.  The symptoms you have described although do occur in pregnancy, they are not specific and may occur due to several other causes even in stressed female.  You may either do a blood test or repeat your urine test as mentioned before. Hope this information is useful.

posted_time: Post  by Elizabeth2 » Thu Dec 21, 2006 4:58 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Generally most pregnancy tests are positive at 5 weeks.  This is when most women decide their period is late and do the test.  There are several pregnancy tests now that are able to detect pregnancy earlier, but generally they still won't be definitely accurate until 2-3 days before your period would normally start.  2-3 weeks is probably too early for most tests, so a negative test result should be repeated if there is suspicion of pregnancy.  Ovulation is generally about 14 days from the start of your period.  Fertilization may not occur for another few days.  By about 3 weeks, the new baby is just barely getting a foothold and hasn't really had time to begin making enough HCg to turn a test positive.  Also, the first AM void is more likely to be positive than at other times as the urine is generally more concentrated.  Best wishes for your new family.

author: deeloman57  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Dec 07, 2006 5:54 pm
title: female reproduction
content: Please help us settle a debate....How many eggs does a woman reproduce monthly?
posted_time: Post  by deeloman57 » Thu Dec 07, 2006 5:58 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Each woman is born with millions of immature eggs that are awaiting ovulation to begin.   After menarche, in each menstrual cycle a few follicles will develop and proceed toward ovulation.  Normally only one egg reaches maturation and is released each time of ovulation to be picked up by the fallopian tube waiting for fertilization.  Some exceptions are known and more than one egg is released in one cycle, results in non identical twins .  For more information you can visit our webpage: http://www.doctorslounge.com/fertility/ ... /index.htm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Fallopian tubes help eggs to move from the ovary to the uterus each cycle (month). Tubal ligation is a procedure done for women who chose not to become pregnant (permanently). There are different surgical procedures that are used to achieve this purpose like cauterization and tying (clips). Failure rates are reported in some cases and pregnancy could occur  in 1 out of 200 women. Causes of tubal ligation failure may include: incomplete closure of the tubes, slipping out of the tying clips. Reversal procedures of tubal ligation are also available and only specialists can advise which is more convenient if any is possible. However, attention should be paid to exclude ectopic (tubal) pregnancy if pregnancy occurs after a tubal ligation due to an increased risk from the damaged tubes.

author: spensaid0003  Guest Posts: 17 Joined: Tue May 31, 2005 10:55 am Location: Sarasota
title: How many C-Sections are OK?
content: I had an emergency c-section with my first child (6/00).  I had an elective c-section with my second child (7/03).  We are thinking of having a third child and I worry about having too many c-sections.  I do not really want to have a vaginal delivery (I am afraid of uterine rupture  - and the birth itself).  I am wondering if a third c-section is safe (aside from the usual risks).  Would this be a better option over a VBAC since I have already had 2 surgical deliveries?  A vaginal delivery scares me immensly and I think it would impair my labor if I chose a VBAC... but I am not 100% opposed to it.  (This would be our last child).    My first c-section was due to failure to progress (I was induced & went from 1 to 3cm and back down to 1cm after 14 hrs of labor), meconimum aspiration, and irregular heart beat in my son.  I have a fibroid or two around 3cm (thought I would mention it incase it is relevent to your reply).  I also get ovarian cysts monthly (some up to 7cm)... so I may even have trouble conceiving.      I am 35 (36 in Feb).  Past surgeries include appendectomy (1981) and the c/s listed above.  No meds.      Thanks for any insight you can provide!
posted_time: Post  by spensaid0003 » Sun Oct 01, 2006 7:52 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi spensaid0003, It would be very difficult to actually assign a "number" as being safe. This depends on many factors, the woman's health, what type of incision was made in the past, etc. A C-section is of course a major abdominal surgery, which pose a risk of complications in itself. The more often this surgery is performed, the greater the risk of uterine rupture. Your physician who knows your history etc. would be the most reliable person to answer whether your health and your own personal situation would warrant the risk. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN
posted_time: Post  by Theresa Jones, RN » Sun Nov 19, 2006 7:41 am

author: mtstanley  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Sat Nov 18, 2006 8:17 am
title: # OF C SECTIONS
content: Spensaid003, I wrote about your son I think.  Anyway, in my residency (surgery) and med school, there were some women who had previous c-sections and deliverd vaginally with no problems.    I don't understand all of the decision making, obviously rupture of the uterus and health of the baby are prime considerations.  I don't know if there is a number as Teresa said.  If you are reasonably good health, your uterus is healthy (not too much scar tissue), and the nature of the previous incision--vertical/horizontal.  ALl of these factors play a role and this is the turf for a skilled ob/gyn.  I would talk to your doctor, and trust him or her to guide you.  Worrying about it will only cause undue stress and pressure on you.  I wish I could just say a number to make you feel better, but one woman might only be able to have one, and another 5.  Its so complex.  Best wishes to you!

content: Hi Archiebald, In some women, palpitations tend to worsen during pregnancy, partially due to the fact that there is an increase in blood volume/flow. author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Renae, History of a previous miscarriage may raise the risk factor of a future miscarriage. Many of the women whom experience a miscarriage do so before they ever have any knowledge of being pregnant. Taking into consideration of what you stated, heavy vaginal bleeding, with the passage of tissue/clots, may have very well been a miscarriage. I certainly hope that you followed up with an evaluation by a physician. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

title: Pregnancy symptoms post-hysterectomy
content: I have two children but I had to have a hysterectomy in 2000.  For the past week or so I've had feelings in my lower abdomen that feel exactly like the movements you would feel in the 15th or 16th weeks of pregnancy.  They are sporadic and strong enough that my husband has been able to feel them.  I have gained about 15 pounds in the last 3 months or so.  I feel like I tire easily as well.  I have not been nauseated as I was with my second child, but I was not nauseated at all with my first child.    I feel like I'm crazy for even thinking that I could be pregnant, but other than when I was pregnant for my two children, I've never felt these things before.  I took a home pregnancy test that came back negative.  I've done some research and while pregnancy post-hysterectomy is not unheard of, it is extremely rare.  Since the possibility of being pregnant is highly unlikely, is there any other medical condition that could explain these symptoms?  Should I explore the pregnancy possibility any further by scheduling an appointment with my doctor or does the negative pregnancy test totally rule out that possibility?  I do not think this could be something psychosomatic because my husband and I do not even want more children, so it's not been an unfulfilled dream.  Any advice or education you could provide would be greatly appreciated.  Thank you for providing this service to those of us with questions.
